Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" added the former \"24\" star.\n\nDonald Sutherland died Thursday in Miami after a long illness, NBC News confirmed.\n\nThe Canadian-born actor shot to stardom in the late 1960s and early 1970s by starring in hits like \"The Dirty Dozen\" and \"M*A*S*H.\"\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland would deliver critically acclaimed performances in Hollywood blockbusters, including \"Klute,\" \"1900,\" \"Animal House, \"Ordinary People,\" \"JFK,\" \"Pride & Prejudice\" and \"The Hunger Games\" franchise.\n\nHe was also an award-winning television actor, winning a Golden Globe for the TV movie \"Path to War,\" as well as an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe award for his performance in the mini-series \"Citizen X.\"\n\nIn 2016, Donald Sutherland and Kiefer Sutherland co-starred in director Jon Cassar's Western film \"Forsaken,\" marking the first time father and son appeared in a movie together.\n\n\"Working with him is something I have wanted to do for 30 years,\" Kiefer Sutherland told People magazine at the time.\n\nHe won an honorary Oscar for his body of work in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland shared Kiefer Sutherland and a daughter, Rachel Sutherland, with his ex-wife Shirley Douglas. {"uri": "2024-06-396328577", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:27:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:27:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:13:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.khq.com/lifestyles/entertainment/donald-sutherland-dies-dirty-dozen-hunger-games-star-father-of-kiefer-sutherland-was-88/article_7a9f2d91-651c-5a4b-b7bb-6a31f20f1244.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland Dies: 'Dirty Dozen' & 'Hunger Games' Star, Father of Kiefer Sutherland Was 88", "body": "Emmy and Golden Globe-winning actor Donald Sutherland has died at the age of 88. The beloved actor, father of Kiefer Sutherland, was known for roles in Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Pride & Prejudice, The Hunger Games franchise, and more.\n\nSutherland died on Thursday, June 20 in Miami, Florida after a long illness, per Deadline. His death was announced by his talent agency, CAA. Sutherland's son, Roeg Sutherland, is an executive at CAA.\n\nKiefer paid tribute to his father on social media shortly after the news of his death.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, with a childhood photo. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nWith a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more... pic.twitter.com/3EdJB03KKT -- Kiefer Sutherland (@RealKiefer) June 20, 2024\n\nSutherland was born on July 17, 1935 in Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada. Acting was part of his upbringing in Canada, but he was studying to become an engineer until he moved to the United Kingdom in his early 20s. He trained at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art while living in London in the 1950s, which led to his first roles in British media, including The Castle of the Living Dead (1964) and an adaptation of A Farewell to Arms (1966).\n\nSutherland's breakout role was in the Oscar-nominated ensemble film The Dirty Dozen (1967), which led to roles such as Hawkeye in Robert Altman's M*A*S*H (1970) and Oddball in Kelly's Heroes (1970). The 1970s was a noteworthy decade for the star, who starred in Don't Look Now, 1900, and National Lampoon's Animal House. His performance in 1980 Oscar-winning film Ordinary People alongside Mary Tyler Moore received acclaim.\n\nRelatedKiefer Sutherland by the Numbers: Looking Back on His Career Milestones\n\nThe '90s were a busy decade for Sutherland, who starred in Backdraft, JFK, the Buffy the Vampire Slayer movie, Outbreak, and Without Limits. The year 1996 became a banner year for the star. After son Kiefer made his film debut in Max Dugan Returns alongside his dad, the father and son co-starred in the legal drama A Time to Kill. The same year, Sutherland won an Emmy and a Golden Globe for his performance in HBO's Citizen X. He would act again with his son in the 2015 western Forsaken.\n\nHe starred in the 2003 remake of The Italian Job and 2005's Oscar-nominated Pride & Prejudice. Sutherland won another Golden Globe in 2003 for Path to War. He earned nine total Golden Globe nominations throughout his career and two total Emmy nominations. He received an Honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nOne of the most famous roles of the later stage of his career was as the villainous President Snow in The Hunger Games franchise. The character became the subject of the franchise's prequel film, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. One of his most recent roles was in Lawmen: Bass Reeves alongside David Oyelowo.\n\nSutherland was married three times. He was wed to Lois Hardwick from 1959-1966 and actress Shirley Douglas (mother to Kiefer and Rachel Sutherland) from 1966-1970. Sutherland had been married to Canadian actress Francine Racette since 1972 at the time of his death. Sutherland and Racette are also parents to Rossif, Angus, and Roeg Sutherland.\n\nMore Headlines:\n\n'The Penguin': Everything We Know About 'The Batman' Spinoff Series So FarSee Kiefer Sutherland's {"uri": "8187466772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:28:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:28:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:28:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://theblast.com/606592/the-hunger-games-actor-donald-sutherland-passes-away-at-age-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland Passes Away At Age 88", "body": "\"The Hunger Games\" actor Donald Sutherland has passed away at the age of 88.\n\nSutherland gained significant recognition in the 1960s and 1970s with standout roles in films such as \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), \"MAS*H\" (1970), and \"Kelly's Heroes\" (1970).\n\nHe also starred in \"Don't Look Now\" (1973), \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" (1978), \"Ordinary People\" (1980), \"JFK\" (1991), \"A Time to Kill\" (1996), and \"The Hunger Games\" series (2012-2015), where he played the role of President Snow.\n\nA cause of death for Donald Sutherland was not made public.\n\nDonald Sutherland has received numerous awards throughout his career, including a Primetime Emmy Award and a Golden Globe Award for his role in the television film \"Citizen X\" (1995).\n\nHe was also awarded an honorary Oscar in 2017 for his contributions to cinema.\n\nThe actor is the father of actors Kiefer Sutherland and Rossif Sutherland. Kiefer is also well-known for his role in the television series \"24\".\n\nKiefer released a statement shortly after the news broke. \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nOther tributes poured in from fans after hearing the news. \"Rest in peace Donald Sutherland, my favorite role of his was the big hearted girl dad Mr Bennett,\" one user wrote. \"So much grace and tenderness in this performance, this scene makes me emotional every time.\"", "source": {"uri": "theblast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Blast"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kelly_coffey_behrens@theblast.com", "name": "Kelly Coffey-Behrens", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hunger_Games", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "The Hunger Games"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heroes_(American_TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Heroes (American TV series)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Time_to_Kill_(Grisham_novel)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "A Time to Kill (Grisham novel)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiefer_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kiefer Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "2024-06-396279516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:23:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:23:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:13:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/entertainment/donald-sutherland-dies-dirty-dozen-hunger-games-star-father-of-kiefer-sutherland-was-88/article_d6cf551d-23b4-5834-b986-cb9bd853cc43.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland Dies: 'Dirty Dozen' & 'Hunger Games' Star, Father of Kiefer Sutherland Was 88", "body": "Emmy and Golden Globe-winning actor Donald Sutherland has died at the age of 88. The beloved actor, father of Kiefer Sutherland, was known for roles in Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Pride & Prejudice, The Hunger Games franchise, and more.\n\nSutherland died on Thursday, June 20 in Miami, Florida after a long illness, per Deadline. His death was announced by his talent agency, CAA. Sutherland's son, Roeg Sutherland, is an executive at CAA.\n\nKiefer paid tribute to his father on social media shortly after the news of his death.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, with a childhood photo. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland was born on July 17, 1935 in Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada. Acting was part of his upbringing in Canada, but he was studying to become an engineer until he moved to the United Kingdom in his early 20s. He trained at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art while living in London in the 1950s, which led to his first roles in British media, including The Castle of the Living Dead (1964) and an adaptation of A Farewell to Arms (1966).\n\nSutherland's breakout role was in the Oscar-nominated ensemble film The Dirty Dozen (1967), which led to roles such as Hawkeye in Robert Altman's M*A*S*H (1970) and Oddball in Kelly's Heroes (1970). The 1970s was a noteworthy decade for the star, who starred in Don't Look Now, 1900, and National Lampoon's Animal House. His performance in 1980 Oscar-winning film Ordinary People alongside Mary Tyler Moore received acclaim.\n\nRelated\n\nKiefer Sutherland by the Numbers: Looking Back on His Career Milestones\n\nThe '90s were a busy decade for Sutherland, who starred in Backdraft, JFK, the Buffy the Vampire Slayer movie, Outbreak, and Without Limits. The year 1996 became a banner year for the star. After son Kiefer made his film debut in Max Dugan Returns alongside his dad, the father and son co-starred in the legal drama A Time to Kill. The same year, Sutherland won an Emmy and a Golden Globe for his performance in HBO's Citizen X. He would act again with his son in the 2015 western Forsaken.\n\nHe starred in the 2003 remake of The Italian Job and 2005's Oscar-nominated Pride & Prejudice. Sutherland won another Golden Globe in 2003 for Path to War. He earned nine total Golden Globe nominations throughout his career and two total Emmy nominations. He received an Honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nOne of the most famous roles of the later stage of his career was as the villainous President Snow in The Hunger Games franchise. The character became the subject of the franchise's prequel film, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. One of his most recent roles was in Lawmen: Bass Reeves alongside David Oyelowo.\n\nSutherland was married three times. He was wed to Lois Hardwick from 1959-1966 and actress Shirley Douglas (mother to Kiefer and Rachel Sutherland) from 1966-1970. Sutherland had been married to Canadian actress Francine Racette since 1972 at the time of his death. Sutherland and Racette are also parents to Rossif, Angus, and Roeg Sutherland.\n\nMore Headlines:\n\n'The Penguin': Everything We Know About 'The Batman' Spinoff Series So FarSee Kiefer Sutherland's {"uri": "8187484975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:43:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:43:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:43:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://omaha.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_86881934-3591-5d89-bbeb-6798126d6926.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: {"uri": "2024-06-396289334", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:35:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:35:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:13:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/arts_and_culture/entertainment/donald-sutherland-dies-dirty-dozen-hunger-games-star-father-of-kiefer-sutherland-was-88/article_cb273f38-4d2c-579f-92f2-ad78f3e629d6.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland Dies: 'Dirty Dozen' & 'Hunger Games' Star, Father of Kiefer Sutherland Was 88", "body": "Emmy and Golden Globe-winning actor Donald Sutherland has died at the age of 88. The beloved actor, father of Kiefer Sutherland, was known for roles in Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Pride & Prejudice, The Hunger Games franchise, and more.\n\nSutherland died on Thursday, June 20 in Miami, Florida after a long illness, per Deadline. His death was announced by his talent agency, CAA. Sutherland's son, Roeg Sutherland, is an executive at CAA.\n\nKiefer paid tribute to his father on social media shortly after the news of his death.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, with a childhood photo. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland was born on July 17, 1935 in Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada. Acting was part of his upbringing in Canada, but he was studying to become an engineer until he moved to the United Kingdom in his early 20s. He trained at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art while living in London in the 1950s, which led to his first roles in British media, including The Castle of the Living Dead (1964) and an adaptation of A Farewell to Arms (1966).\n\nSutherland's breakout role was in the Oscar-nominated ensemble film The Dirty Dozen (1967), which led to roles such as Hawkeye in Robert Altman's M*A*S*H (1970) and Oddball in Kelly's Heroes (1970). The 1970s was a noteworthy decade for the star, who starred in Don't Look Now, 1900, and National Lampoon's Animal House. His performance in 1980 Oscar-winning film Ordinary People alongside Mary Tyler Moore received acclaim.\n\nRelated\n\nKiefer Sutherland by the Numbers: Looking Back on His Career Milestones\n\nMore from this section\n\nTravis & Taylor's date night dish revealed.\n\nJustin Timberlake's shocking mugshot.\n\nMy Bizarre Collection: The owner of 300 pairs of sneakers\n\nThe '90s were a busy decade for Sutherland, who starred in Backdraft, JFK, the Buffy the Vampire Slayer movie, Outbreak, and Without Limits. The year 1996 became a banner year for the star. After son Kiefer made his film debut in Max Dugan Returns alongside his dad, the father and son co-starred in the legal drama A Time to Kill. The same year, Sutherland won an Emmy and a Golden Globe for his performance in HBO's Citizen X. He would act again with his son in the 2015 western Forsaken.\n\nHe starred in the 2003 remake of The Italian Job and 2005's Oscar-nominated Pride & Prejudice. Sutherland won another Golden Globe in 2003 for Path to War. He earned nine total Golden Globe nominations throughout his career and two total Emmy nominations. He received an Honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nOne of the most famous roles of the later stage of his career was as the villainous President Snow in The Hunger Games franchise. The character became the subject of the franchise's prequel film, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. One of his most recent roles was in Lawmen: Bass Reeves alongside David Oyelowo.\n\nSutherland was married three times. He was wed to Lois Hardwick from 1959-1966 and actress Shirley Douglas (mother to Kiefer and Rachel Sutherland) from 1966-1970. Sutherland had been married to Canadian actress Francine Racette since 1972 at the time of his death. Sutherland and Racette are also parents to Rossif, Angus, and Roeg Sutherland.\n\nMore Headlines:\n\n'The Penguin': Everything We Know About 'The Batman' Spinoff Series So FarSee Kiefer Sutherland's Touching Tribute to His Father Donald Sutherland Following His DeathDonald Sutherland Dies: 'Dirty Dozen' & 'Hunger Games' Star, Father of Kiefer Sutherland Was 88'Yellowstone' Finally Sets Return He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. {"uri": "8187498401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:54:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:54:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:53:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://missoulian.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_35de7bbd-59b6-5701-98f6-48da69fd09d5.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 2005: Donald Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8187499815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:55:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:55:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:54:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_dc501614-f755-5fb9-a7b4-f47e75bdf0b3.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading... Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in {"uri": "8187525662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:16:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:16:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:15:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/entertainment/mash-actor-donald-sutherland-dies-at-88-post-5672320", "title": "'M*A*S*H' Actor Donald Sutherland Dies at 88", "body": "Actor Donald Sutherland died at age 88, his son announced on June 20.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" actor Kiefer Sutherland wrote on social media.\n\nDonald Sutherland, a Canadian native, acted in major films for decades, including M*A*S*H, The Italian Job, and the Hunger Games movies.\n\n\"I personally think [he's] one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" his son said. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nThe elder Sutherland leaves behind a number of family members, including five children and his wife, Francine Racette.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiefer_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kiefer Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series)", "type": {"uri": "8187630051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:49:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:49:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:48:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/news/entertainment/canadian-actor-donald-sutherland-whose-career-spanned-mash-to-hunger-games-dies-at-88/", "title": "Veteran actor Donald Sutherland dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from M.A.S.H. to The Hunger Games, has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's M.A.S.H., the hippie tank commander in Kelly's Heroes and the stoned professor in Animal House.\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomised the unpredictable, anti-establishment cinema of the 1970s.\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down - but still eccentric - parts in Robert Redford's Ordinary People and Oliver Stone's JFK. More, recently, he starred in the Hunger Games films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, Made Up, But Still True, was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom - time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nLiam Hemsworth, Jennifer Lawrence and Donald Sutherland at the premiere of The Hunger Games: Catching Fire in LA on November 18, 2013. Photo / AP\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told the New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was The Dirty Dozen (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn Kelly's Heroes and M.A.S.H., an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told the Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nDonald Sutherland appears at the Oscars in Los Angeles on March 4, 2018. Photo / AP\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from M.A.S.H. He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors - even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's Fellini's Casanova), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's 1900), Claude Chabrol (1978's Blood Relatives) and John Schlesinger (1975's The Day of the Locust).\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's Klute (1971). It was during filming on Klute that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, Castle of the Living Dead.\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (Don't Look Now); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nDonald Sutherland and his son Kiefer Sutherland pose for a portrait in Los Angeles to promote the film Forsaken. Photo / AP\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's Ordinary People. Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film Citizen X and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in M.A.S.H. and Ordinary People), winning two -- again for Citizen X and for the 2003 TV film Path to War.\n\nOrdinary People also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's Lolita, and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire Gas and the 1984 comedy Crackers.\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's JFK (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie Six Degrees of Separation. He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's Without Limits.", "source": {"uri": "newstalkzb.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewstalkZB"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-396254335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:54:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:54:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://journalstar.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_1059fa6b-e628-5be0-b9f8-c14fd422a3d9.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nLincoln ABC affiliate KLKN parts ways with evening anchor "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 214, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187576358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:59:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:59:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:58:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/entertainment/celebrities/actor-donald-sutherland-death-june-20-2024/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, star of 'Ordinary People' and 'The Hunger Games,' dead at 88", "body": "'He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,' Donald Sutherland's son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, writes on social media\n\nDonald Sutherland, one of Canada's most versatile and gifted actors, who charmed and enthralled audiences in movies such as \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute,\" \"Ordinary People\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at the age of 88.\n\nThe actor, whose lengthy career spanned from the 1960s into the 2020s, died on Thursday, June 20, his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, said on social media.\n\nA tall man with a deep voice, piercing blue eyes and a mischievous smile, Donald Sutherland switched effortlessly from character roles to romantic leads opposite the likes of Jane Fonda and Julie Christie. He also played his share of oddballs and villains.\n\nOne of the biggest stars in Hollywood in the 1970s, he remained in demand for film and TV projects into his 80s. Known for his unconventional looks and his versatility as an actor, Sutherland played a wide range of memorable characters.\n\nThese included a rascally Army surgeon in \"M*A*S*H\" (1970), a quirky tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" (1970), a small-town detective in \"Klute\" (1971), a stoned and libidinous professor in \"Animal House\" (1978), a local official facing an alien presence in \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" (1978) and a despairing father in \"Ordinary People\" (1980). He won a new generation of fans with his glorious portrayal of a despotic president in \"The Hunger Games\" (2012) and its sequels.\n\n\"I wish I could say thank you to all of the characters that I've played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life,\" Sutherland said in his speech accepting an honorary Academy Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.\n\nKiefer Sutherland said his father was \"never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\"\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nDonald Sutherland was born on July 17, 1935, in Canada's New Brunswick province, and was raised in Nova Scotia. He performed in school productions in college, moved to Britain to hone his craft, then moved to the United States, where his first big break came as a member of a top-notch ensemble cast in the war film \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967).\n\nHe rocketed to fame three years later playing nonconformist surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in director Robert Altman's Korean War satire \"M*A*S*H\" (1970). The film - later spun off into a TV series - depicted hijinks at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital, tapping into the anti-war sentiment among many Americans during the Vietnam War era.\n\nAlso in 1970, Sutherland starred alongside Telly Savalas and Clint Eastwood in \"Kelly's Heroes\" as Sergeant Oddball on a mission to steal gold from the Nazis.\n\nThe following year, he was paired with Fonda, one of Hollywood's luminaries, in \"Klute,\" and then in 1973 played a grieving father in \"Don't Look Now\" that included a sizzling sex scene with Christie. \"Klute\" sparked a romance with Fonda, with whom he was active in the anti-Vietnam War movement.\n\nHis 1978 films could not have been more different. In the uproarious comedy \"Animal House,\" Sutherland played a professor who sleeps with the girlfriend of a fraternity member. \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" was a successful sci-fi remake of a classic 1956 original, telling the story of alien pods that take over human beings.\n\nSutherland's performance in \"Ordinary People,\" Hollywood superstar Robert Redford's directorial debut, helped the 1980 film win four Academy Awards, including best picture. Sutherland starred alongside Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton in this exploration of the splintering of a Midwestern family.\n\nIn the 1990s he appeared in films including \"JFK\" (1991), \"Backdraft\" (1991), \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer\" (1992), \"Outbreak\" (1995), \"A Time To Kill\" (1996) and \"Instinct\" (1999) and won an Emmy Award for his performance in the 1995 HBO TV movie \"Citizen X.\" In the 2000s, he appeared in the acclaimed \"Cold Mountain\" (2003) and \"Pride & Prejudice\" (2005).\n\nIn the \"Hunger Games\" films in the 2010s about a dystopian future in which teenagers are sent into a deadly competition as mass entertainment, he reveled in playing the villainous President Coriolanus Snow.\n\n\"The reality was he had a country to run. At least he was running it, which is more than you can say for some people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times in 2017.\n\n\"It was funny at the beginning with 'The Hunger Games' to walk through an airport and suddenly you feel this tug and you look down and it's some young person - always a girl, never a boy,\" Sutherland said. \"And her mother is standing there and they say, 'Could you take a photograph with my daughter?' And we'd be standing beside each other and I'd be looking at the camera and the girl would say, 'Could you look mean?'\"\n\nTributes to Sutherland came in across Hollywood and Canada on Thursday.\n\nRon Howard, who directed Sutherland in \"Backdraft,\" called him \"one of the most intelligent, interesting and engrossing film actors of all time.\"\n\nSutherland had \"incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence,\" Howard wrote on X.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, speaking to reporters in Nova Scotia, said Sutherland \"was a man with a strong presence, a brilliance in his craft and truly, truly a great Canadian artist.\"\n\nSutherland was considered among the best actors to never receive an Academy Award nomination for any of his roles. He was married three times and had five children, including Kiefer. - Rappler.com", "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rappler"}, "authors": [{"uri": He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. He saw a resurgence in popularity with a younger audience in recent years thanks to his role as the evil President Snow in The Hunger Games franchise.\n\nHe was discussing his role as Nicole Kidman 's father in HBO's The Undoing, which follows her character after her husband, played by Hugh Grant , is accused of murder\n\nThe actor, whose death was announced on Thursday, last spoke to the press via Zoom in March of 2021. He is seen with his honorary Oscar in 2017\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n'I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,' Kiefer Sutherland said on X. 'Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.'\n\nIn 2022, Sutherland appeared on what would be his last projects, Lawmen: Bass Reeves and Swimming With Sharks.\n\nSutherland was set to star in upcoming apocalyptic flick Heart Land, which is in pre-production.\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's M.A.S.H., the hippie tank commander in Kelly's Heroes and the stoned professor in Animal House.\n\nSutherland's career spanned over 60 years and he saw a resurgence with a younger audience in recent years thanks to his role as the evil President Snow in The Hunger Games franchise\n\nDonald Sutherland making point while sitting in a scene from the film 'MASH', 1970\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s.\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's Ordinary People and Oliver Stone's JFK. More, recently, he starred in the Hunger Games films.\n\nHe never retired, working regularly up until his death.\n\nA memoir, Made Up, But Still True, was due out in November.\n\nHis first American film was 'The Dirty Dozen' in 1967, in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic.\n\nAngus Sutherland with date, Roeg Sutherland, Donald Sutherland, Rachel Sutherland, Rossif Sutherland at the Hollywood Walk of Fame Star Ceremony honoring Donald Sutherland in 2011\n\nThe year 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn Kelly's Heroes and M.A.S.H., an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\nSutherland won an Emmy in 1995 for his role on Citizen X, and was nominated in 2006 for Human Trafficking, as reported by Variety.\n\nThe actor also won a Golden Globe for the miniseries Citizen X and for the television movie Path to War.\n\nIn 2017 he received an Honorary Award from the Academy.\n\nHe also leaves behind his wife Francine Racette and their three adult sons. The couple is seen in 2016\n\nSutherland is survived by Keith and his twin sister Rachel from his marriage to ex-wife Shirley Douglas.\n\nHaving been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after.\n\nThey had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (Don't Look Now); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nSutherland also leaves behind four {"uri": "2024-06-396242560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:41:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:41:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_44f6f518-7925-587d-8621-c7205c3ac391.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nIowa DCI: Wall Lake trucker David Schultz's death 'not a I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film.\"\n\nHe continued: \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more.\"\n\nSutherland was considered one of the greatest actors to never have received an Academy Award nomination. His career stretched from 1970s to the 2020s. He received an honourary statute in 2017.\n\nSutherland emerged as an actor in the 1960s and later starred in \"Klute\", \"MASH\", \"Don't Look Now\" and \"Animal House\".\n\nA statement from the CAA group added: \"Acclaimed actor Donald Sutherland died today in Miami, Florida, after a long illness. He was 88 years old.\"\n\nSutherland has almost 200 credits to his name, including The Dirty Dozen. {"uri": "8187497247", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:53:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:53:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:52:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://qctimes.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_83c41bea-25e6-5968-ae40-f5811c1cf38f.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "By JAKE COYLE AP Film Writer\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading... {"uri": "8187496730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:52:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:52:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:52:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_e98f44b7-df32-5089-991c-3f526ac670a4.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading... {"uri": "2024-06-396244413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:43:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:43:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_35f28111-7d66-58d6-b300-16878921cc67.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nPizza Hut restaurants abruptly close across Northwest {"uri": "2024-06-396241452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:39:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:39:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://richmond.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_8444e906-898f-5d95-be5d-011e0a9d5e76.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nNEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nVirginia ABC lays off 25 as it prepares for independent future These companies top list of Richmond eviction filers, public records show Virginia swimmer Gretchen Walsh breaks world record in 100-meter butterfly New Swiss production facility to bring 180 jobs to Chesterfield Virginia's Elijah Gertrude will miss season after scooter wreck UPDATE: Police identify victim of Henrico homicide State pulls Ferrum College lab school application; president says no explanation offered Good, McGuire primary in 5th District too close to call Chesterfield schools employee charged with possessing child porn Pro hockey return to Richmond area? "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 213, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-396250896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:50:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:50:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:49:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://eu.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2024/06/20/donald-sutherland-dead/9126944002/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, chameleon actor of 'Ordinary People' and 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "Emmy Award-winning actor Donald Sutherland has died. He starred in more than 200 movies and TV shows.\n\nDonald Sutherland, the versatile Canadian actor whose prolific career in TV shows and movies showed a diverse range, from authority-loathing surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in the \"M*A*S*H\" movie to authoritarian villain President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise, has died. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" his son Kiefer posted on social media Thursday along with a black and white photo of the father-son pair.\n\nHe added: \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nUSA TODAY has reached out to reps for Sutherland.\n\nStarring in more than 200 TV and movies, Sutherland beat an indelible and idiosyncratic path during his six-decade career. He was the pot-smoking professor in 1978's \"Animal House,\" the titular detective John Klute starring alongside then-lover Jane Fonda in the 1971 thriller \"Klute,\" a pod person in the 1978 horror remake \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers,\" an 18th-century Venetian explorer in 1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\" with director Frederico Fellini, and an embattled father working to save his emotionally troubled upper-middle-class family in \"Ordinary People.\"\n\n\"I've always had a horizontally organized career,\" Sutherland told USA TODAY in 2018. \"You've got a big plate of fruit and cheese, and you can take a piece here and there. You won't like all of it, but you'll like some of it.\"\n\nDonald Sutherland interview: Playing 'cold' billionaire Getty, and a pint-size 'Hunger Games' fan's request\n\nAn Emmy winner and the patriarch of his own family of actors and entertainment professionals (including son Kiefer Sutherland, star of \"24\" and \"Designated Survivor\"), Sutherland is inarguably the greatest Hollywood actor never to earn a single Oscar nomination. He was most egregiously overlooked for his widely praised \"Ordinary People\" role, which saw screen wife Mary Tyler Moore earning one of six Oscar nominations -- and newcomer Timothy Hutton winning one of four Oscars playing Sutherland's screen son.\n\nJohn Bailey, the cinematographer on \"Ordinary People,\" helped to correct this wrong as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences president in 2017, calling Sutherland personally to inform the actor that he would be awarded an honorary Oscar.\n\n\"Thank you for putting my name on this. This is very important to me, to my family,\" Sutherland said from the awards podium, looking at his Oscar. \"I wish I could say thank you to all the characters I have played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life.\"\n\nBorn to Dorothy and Frederick Sutherland in the seaport city of Saint John, New Brunswick, the young Sutherland found he was destined for character acting during an eye-opening discussion with his mother.\n\n\"I went to her and I said, 'Mother, am I good looking?' And my mother looked at me and went. 'Your face has character, Donald.' \" Sutherland recalled to \"60 Minutes.\"\n\nAfter studying drama and starring in London stage and TV productions, Sutherland earned the one-line part on \"The Dirty Dozen,\" portraying goofy felon Vernon Pinkey in an all-star cast that included Lee Marvin, Charles Bronson and Telly Savalas. But when Clint Walker declined to do a scene where his character impersonates a general, director Robert Aldrich looked at Sutherland.\n\n\"He went, 'You with the big ears, you do it.' I don't think he knew my name. But, you know. It changed my life,' \" Sutherland told 60 Minutes in 2018.\n\nSutherland shot into stardom brandishing his own brand of quirky Vietnam War-era contempt in war movie portrayals, starting as convict soldier Vernon Pinkley in \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967) and the comical tank driver Sgt. Oddball in the 1970s World War II heist comedy \"Kelly's Heroes.\" He ended the streak as the wise-cracking surgeon in Robert Altman's 1970 Korean War comedy-drama \"M*A*S*H\" (Alan Alda portrayed Hawkeye Pierce in the seminal 1970s TV series).\n\nDuring his starring role as the enigmatic private detective in the neo-noir hit \"Klute,\" (which earned Fonda a best actress Oscar) that Sutherland, still married to second wife (mother of twins Rachel and Kiefer), began his relationship with Fonda. The two hit the road in the 1971 anti-Vietnam War road show for GI's, the \"F.T.A.\" (\"Free the Army\"). But the relationship had crashed and burned by the end of the year.\n\n\"It broke my heart. I was eviscerated,\" Sutherland told The Guardian in 2008. \"It was a wonderful relationship right up the point we lived together.\"\n\nThe next year, Sutherland met and married actress Francine Racette, and remained married for the rest of his life, with three sons together: Roeg, Rossif, and Angus Sutherland.\n\nThe actor had a particular skill for playing villains, a spy in \"Eye of the Needle\" a sadistic warden in 1989's \"Lock Up\" a scheming software CEO in \"Disclosure\" opposite Michael Douglas and Demi Moore and the cruel Attila in Bernardo Bertolucci Italian epic \"1900.\"\n\nAfter turning 80, Sutherland took on the role of his most famous villain, President Snow in \"The Hunger Games,\" the arch-nemesis to Jennifer Lawrence's Katniss Everdeen for four box office record breaking films from 2012-2015.\n\n\"My agent sends me these things because I'm 80 and I still like to know what's going on,\" he told Britain's \"The Telegraph.\" \"I hadn't even heard of the books, but it became patently apparent to me that this was something. It was the first thing I'd read in years that could become a creative political stimulus for young people.\"\n\nSutherland found a new generation of fans eager to take pictures with him, describing one fan who approached him in an airport. \"As we're waiting for her mother to take the picture, the girl turned and whispered in my ear, 'Look mean.' \" Sutherland recalled with glee.\n\nFinally, accepting his Oscar, Sutherland look over his showbiz family, including Kiefer's \"Veep\" actress daughter, Sarah Sutherland, and dedicated the award to his wife. \"From whom everything has come, and to whom everything is owed.\"\n\nHe closed the speech quoting comedian Jack Benny when presented with an honor.\n\n\"He said, as I say to you now, I don't deserve this, But I have arthritis, and I don't deserve that either.\"", "source": {"uri": "azcentral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AZ Central"}, "authors": [{"uri": "arizona_republic@azcentral.com", "name": "Arizona Republic", "type":
