{"uri": "2024-06-396268122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:10:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:10:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:56:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/entertainment/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_c5c0c2a9-3819-583a-9262-798838bc29c4.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "FILE - Donald Sutherland, left, and his son Kiefer Sutherland pose for a portrait in Los Angeles to promote the film \"Forsaken.\" Donald Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two -- again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford. For a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187491583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:49:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:49:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:47:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_c4543684-93fd-54ed-9d3b-c2f08bcdc6c8.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.02745098039215677, "wgt": 211, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-396308485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:59:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:59:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:52:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://eu.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/entertainment/movies/2024/06/20/donald-sutherland-dead/9126944002/", "title": "Donald Sutherland death: Chameleon character actor known for 'MASH' dead at 88", "body": "Emmy Award-winning actor Donald Sutherland has died. He starred in more than 200 movies and TV shows.\n\nDonald Sutherland, the versatile Canadian actor whose prolific career in TV shows and movies showed a diverse range, from authority-loathing surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in the \"M*A*S*H\" movie to authoritarian villain President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise, has died. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" his son Kiefer posted on social media Thursday along with a black and white photo of the father-son pair.\n\nHe added: \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nStarring in more than 200 TV and movies, Sutherland beat an indelible and idiosyncratic path during his six-decade career. He was the pot-smoking professor in 1978's \"Animal House,\" the titular detective John Klute starring alongside then-lover Jane Fonda in the 1971 thriller \"Klute,\" a pod person in the 1978 horror remake \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers,\" an 18th-century Venetian explorer in 1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\" with director Frederico Fellini, and an embattled father working to save his emotionally troubled upper-middle-class family in \"Ordinary People.\"\n\n\"I've always had a horizontally organized career,\" Sutherland told USA TODAY in 2018. \"You've got a big plate of fruit and cheese, and you can take a piece here and there. You won't like all of it, but you'll like some of it.\"\n\nDonald Sutherland interview: Playing 'cold' billionaire Getty, and a pint-size 'Hunger Games' fan's request\n\nAn Emmy winner and the patriarch of his own family of actors and entertainment professionals (including son Kiefer Sutherland, star of \"24\" and \"Designated Survivor\"), Sutherland is inarguably the greatest Hollywood actor never to earn a single Oscar nomination. He was most egregiously overlooked for his widely praised \"Ordinary People\" role, which saw screen wife Mary Tyler Moore earn one of six Oscar nominations -- and newcomer Timothy Hutton win one of four Oscars playing Sutherland's screen son.\n\nJohn Bailey, the cinematographer on \"Ordinary People,\" helped to correct this wrong as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences president in 2017, calling Sutherland personally to inform the actor that he would be awarded an honorary Oscar.\n\n\"Thank you for putting my name on this. This is very important to me, to my family,\" Sutherland said from the 2017 Governors Awards podium, looking at his Oscar. \"I wish I could say thank you to all the characters I have played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life.\"\n\nBorn to Dorothy and Frederick Sutherland in the seaport city of Saint John, New Brunswick, the young Sutherland found he was destined for character acting during an eye-opening discussion with his mother.\n\n\"I went to her, and I said, 'Mother, am I good-looking?' And my mother looked at me and went. 'Your face has character, Donald.' \" Sutherland recalled to \"60 Minutes\" in 2018.\n\nAfter studying drama and starring in London stage and TV productions, Sutherland earned the one-line part on \"The Dirty Dozen,\" portraying goofy felon Vernon Pinkley in an all-star cast that included Lee Marvin, Charles Bronson and Telly Savalas. But when actor Clint Walker declined to do a scene where his character impersonates a general, director Robert Aldrich looked at Sutherland.\n\n\"He went, 'You with the big ears, you do it.' I don't think he knew my name. But, you know. It changed my life,' \" Sutherland told 60 Minutes.\n\nSutherland starred in 'The Dirty Dozen' and 'Kelly's Heroes'\n\nSutherland shot into stardom brandishing his own brand of quirky Vietnam War-era contempt in war movie portrayals, starting as convict soldier Vernon Pinkley in \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967) and the comical tank driver Sgt. Oddball in the 1970s World War II heist comedy \"Kelly's Heroes.\" He ended the streak as the wise-cracking surgeon in Robert Altman's 1970 Korean War comedy-drama \"M*A*S*H\" (Alan Alda portrayed Hawkeye Pierce in the seminal 1970s TV series).\n\nDuring his starring role as the enigmatic private detective in the neo-noir hit \"Klute\" (which earned Fonda a best actress Oscar), Sutherland, still married to his second wife Shirley Douglas (mother of twins Rachel and Kiefer), began his relationship with Fonda. The two hit the road in the 1971 anti-Vietnam War road show for GI's, the \"F.T.A.\" (\"Free the Army\"). But the relationship had crashed and burned by the end of the year.\n\n\"It broke my heart. I was eviscerated,\" Sutherland told The Guardian in 2008. \"It was a wonderful relationship right up to the point we lived together.\"\n\nThe next year, Sutherland met and married actress Francine Racette. He remained married for the rest of his life and had three sons together: Roeg, Rossif, and Angus Sutherland.\n\nSutherland played villain President Snow in 'Hunger Games'\n\nThe actor had a particular skill for playing villains, a spy in 1981's \"Eye of the Needle\" a sadistic warden in 1989's \"Lock Up\" a scheming software CEO in 1994's \"Disclosure\" opposite Michael Douglas and Demi Moore and the cruel Attila in Bernardo Bertolucci's Italian epic \"1900.\"\n\nAfter turning 80, Sutherland took on the role of his most famous villain, President Snow, in \"The Hunger Games\" -- the arch-nemesis to Jennifer Lawrence's Katniss Everdeen for four box office record-breaking films from 2012-2015.\n\n\"My agent sends me these things because I'm 80 and I still like to know what's going on,\" he told Britain's \"The Telegraph.\" \"I hadn't even heard of the books, but it became patently apparent to me that this was something. It was the first thing I'd read in years that could become a creative political stimulus for young people.\"\n\nSutherland found a new generation of fans eager to take pictures with him, describing one fan who approached him in an airport. \"As we're waiting for her mother to take the picture, the girl turned and whispered in my ear, 'Look mean.' \" Sutherland recalled with glee to USA Today in 2018.\n\nFinally, accepting his Oscar, Sutherland looked over his showbiz family, including Kiefer's \"Veep\" actress daughter, Sarah Sutherland, and dedicated the award to his wife Francine: \"From whom everything has come, and to whom everything is owed.\"\n\nHe closed the speech quoting comedian Jack Benny when presented with an honor.\n\n\"(Benny) said, as I say to you now, 'I don't deserve this, But I have arthritis, and I don't deserve that either,'\" said Sutherland.", "source": {"uri": "eu.montgomeryadvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Montgomery Advertiser"}, He was 88.\n\nHis death was confirmed on social media by his son Kiefer Sutherland, a well-known actor himself who starred in \"24\" and \"Designated Survivor,\" on Thursday. A talent agency that represents Sutherland also confirmed his death to CBS News.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland auditioned for his first role more than 50 years ago, he told Anderson Cooper during a 2017 interview on \"60 Minutes.\"\n\nHe went on to appear in more than 150 films and television shows, and has been called one of the greatest actors to never be nominated for an Oscar -- despite acclaimed performances in films like \"Ordinary People,\" which won best picture.\n\nIn 2017, the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts & Sciences presented Sutherland with with an honorary Oscar at its Governors Awards ceremony.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8187483926", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:43:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:43:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:42:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_4f8e48b4-00c3-5a1d-ac9e-a6d4c825c525.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... Buffalo Schools release plan for heat wave, but Regents exams an 'X factor' NFL power rankings: Kansas City, San Francisco lead way entering training camp Erie County real estate transactions Five WNY sites recommended for listing on State Register of Historic Places\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "2024-06-396237652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:36:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:36:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:34:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://eu.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2024/06/20/donald-sutherland-dead/9126944002/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, chameleon actor of 'Ordinary People' and 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the versatile Canadian actor whose prolific career in TV shows and movies showed diverse range, from authority-loathing surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in the \"M*A*S*H\" movie to authoritarian villain President Snow in \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" his son Kiefer posted on social media Thursday along with a black and white photo of the father-son pair.\n\nHe added: \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nUSA TODAY has reached out to reps for Sutherland.\n\nStarring in more than 200 TV and movies, Sutherland beat an indelible and idiosyncratic path during his six-decade career. He was the pot-smoking professor in 1978's \"Animal House,\" the titular detective John Klute starring alongside then-lover Jane Fonda in the 1971 thriller \"Klute,\" a pod person in the 1978 horror remake \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers,\" an 18th-century Venetian explorer in 1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\" with director Frederico Fellini, and an embattled father working to save his upper-middle-class family in \"Ordinary People.\"\n\n\"I've always had a horizontally organized career,\" Sutherland told USA TODAY in 2018. \"You've got a big plate of fruit and cheese, and you can take a piece here and there. You won't like all of it, but you'll like some of it.\"\n\nDonald Sutherland interview: Playing 'cold' billionaire Getty, and a pint-size 'Hunger Games' fan's request\n\nAn Emmy winner and the patriarch of his own family of actors and entertainment professionals (including son Kiefer Sutherland, star of \"24\" and \"Designated Survivor\"), Sutherland is inarguably the greatest Hollywood actor never to earn a single Oscar nomination. He was most egregiously overlooked for his widely praised \"Ordinary People\" role, which saw screen wife Mary Tyler Moore earning one of six Oscar nominations and newcomer Timothy Hutton winning one of four Oscars playing Sutherland's screen son.\n\nJohn Bailey, the cinematographer on \"Ordinary People,\" helped to correct this wrong as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences president in 2017, calling Sutherland personally to inform the actor that he would be awarded an honorary Oscar.\n\n\"Thank you for putting my name on this. This is very important to me, to my family,\" Sutherland said from the awards podium, looking at his Oscar. \"I wish I could say thank you to all the characters I have played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life.\"\n\nBorn to Dorothy and Frederick Sutherland in the seaport city of Saint John, New Brunswick, to Dorothy and Frederick Sutherland, the young Sutherland found he was destined for character acting during an eye-opening discussion with his mother.\n\n\"I went to her and I said, 'Mother, am I good looking?' And my mother looked at me and went. 'Your face has character, Donald.' \" Sutherland recalled to \"60 Minutes.\"\n\nAfter studying drama and starring in London stage and TV productions, Sutherland earned the one-line part on \"The Dirty Dozen,\" portraying goofy felon Vernon Pinkey in an all-star cast that included Lee Marvin, Charles Bronson and Telly Savalas. But when Clint Walker declined to do a scene where his character impersonates a general, director Robert Aldrich looked at Sutherland.\n\n\"He went, 'You with the big ears, you do it.' I don't think he knew my name. But, you know. It changed my life,' \" Sutherland told 60 Minutes in 2018.\n\nSutherland shot into stardom brandishing his own brand of quirky Vietnam War era contempt in war movie portrayals, starting with convict soldier Vernon Pinkley in \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967) and the comical tank driver Sgt. Oddball in 1970's World War II heist comedy \"Kelly's Heroes.\" He ended the streak as the wise-cracking surgeon in Robert Altman's 1970 Korean War comedy-drama \"M*A*S*H\" (Alan Alda portrayed Hawkeye Pierce in the seminal 1970s TV series).\n\nDuring his starring role as the enigmatic private detective in the neo-noir hit \"Klute,\" (which earned Fonda a best actress Oscar) that Sutherland, still married to second wife (mother of twins Rachel and Kiefer), began his relationship with Fonda. The two hit the road in the 1971 anti-Vietnam War road show for GI's, the \"F.T.A.\" (\"Free the Army\"). But the relationship had crashed and burned by the end of the year.\n\n\"It broke my heart. I was eviscerated,\" Sutherland told The Guardian in 2008. \"It was a wonderful relationship right up the point we lived together.\"\n\nThe next year, Sutherland met and married actress Francine Racette, and remained married for the rest of his life, with three sons together: Roeg, Rossif, and Angus Sutherland.\n\nThe actor had a particular skill for playing villains, a spy in \"Eye of the Needle\" a sadistic warden in 1989's \"Lock Up\" a scheming software CEO in \"Disclosure\" opposite Michael Douglas and Demi Moore and the cruel Attila in Bernardo Bertolucci Italian epic \"1900.\"\n\nAfter turning 80, Sutherland took on the role of his most famous villain, President Snow in \"The Hunger Games,\" the arch-nemesis to Jennifer Lawrence's Katniss Everdeen for four box office record breaking films from 2012-2015.\n\n\"My agent sends me these things because I'm 80 and I still like to know what's going on,\" he told Britain's \"The Telegraph.\" \"I hadn't even heard of the books, but it became patently apparent to me that this was something. It was the first thing I'd read in years that could become a creative political stimulus for young people.\"\n\nSutherland found a new generation of fans eager to take pictures with him, describing one fan who approached him in an airport. \"As we're waiting for her mother to take the picture, the girl turned and whispered in my ear, 'Look mean.' \" Sutherland recalled with glee.\n\nFinally, accepting his Oscar, Sutherland look over his showbiz family, including Kiefer's \"Veep\" actress daughter, Sarah Sutherland, and dedicated the award to his wife. \"From whom everything has come, and to whom everything is owed.\"\n\nHe closed the speech quoting comedian Jack Benny when presented with an honor.\n\n\"He said, as I say to you now, I don't deserve this, But I have arthritis, and I don't deserve that either.\"", "source": {"uri": "freep.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Detroit Free Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187598077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:18:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:18:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:17:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/gooddaysacramento/news/donald-sutherland-dies-at-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, actor who starred in \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Hunger Games\" and more, dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, a multi-generational actor who starred in \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute,\" \"Animal House,\" \"Hunger Games\" and more, has died. He was 88.\n\nHis death was confirmed on social media by his son Kiefer Sutherland, a well-known actor himself who starred in \"24\" and \"Designated Survivor,\" on Thursday. A talent agency that represents Sutherland also confirmed his death to CBS News.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland auditioned for his first role more than 50 years ago, he told Anderson Cooper during a 2017 interview on \"60 Minutes.\"\n\nHe went on to appear in more than 150 films and television shows, and has been called one of the greatest actors to never be nominated for an Oscar -- despite acclaimed performances in films like \"Ordinary People,\" which won best picture.\n\nIn 2017, the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts & Sciences presented Sutherland with an honorary Oscar at its Governors Awards ceremony.\n\nOne of Canada's best-known actors, Sutherland was born in New Brunswick in 1935. After graduating with degrees in engineering and drama from the Unversity of Toronto, Sutherland moved to London to start his acting career.\n\nHe had small roles in Italian and British films, his official Oscar biography said, before making his feature film debut in the 1964 movie \"Castle of the Living Dead.\" His breakthrough role as Vernon Pinkley in the 1967 film \"The Dirty Dozen\" catapulted Sutherland to his first starring role in the acclaimed film \"M*A*S*H.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "Toronto"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Canada"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Brunswick", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "New Brunswick"}, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Canada"}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Filmmaking", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Filmmaking", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Organizations", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Organizations", "wgt": 22}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Education", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Education", "wgt": 22}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Acting", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Acting", "wgt": 26}, {"uri": "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://assets1.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2018/11/29/90ec28ed-7caa-49ae-96a7-0b65d8552017/thumbnail/1200x630/70691ea4725b8d952a1eff1edc37bce6/gettyimages-873076770.jpg?v=5842509bb796a146f9b20d3e8b03dac6", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.08235294117647063, "wgt": 210, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187617016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:37:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:37:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:36:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.wsfa.com/2024/06/20/donald-sutherland-known-mash-hunger-games-dead-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, known for 'M*A*S*H' and 'The Hunger Games,' dead at 88", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Sutherland, the Canadian actor whose wry, arrestingly off-kilter screen presence spanned more than half a century of films from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nSon Kiefer Sutherland confirmed the death Thursday. No details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Sutherland, who flashed a grin that could be sweet or diabolical, was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s. He never stopped working, ultimately appearing in nearly 200 films and series.\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- roles in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" is due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at age 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959 but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art to study acting. He began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis breakthrough was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopath. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" a smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He was unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations.\n\nSutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, he along with actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\n\"I thought I was going to be part of a revolution that was going to change movies and its influence on people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times.\n\nHis career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900''), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. He and Douglas divorced in 1971 after having twins: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nNicolas Roeg's psychological horror film \"Don't Look Now\" (1973) was another high point. Sutherland starred with Julie Christie as a grieving married couple who move to Venice after their daughter's death. The film included a famous, explicit sex scene, artfully edited.\n\n\"Nic and I thought that maybe I would die in the process of it, so much were we committed,\" Sutherland once said. His admiration for the film and Roeg was such that he and his next wife, actress Francine Racette, named their first-born child Roeg.\n\nSutherland married Racette in 1972 and remained with her the rest of his life. She survives him. They had two other children together: Rossif, named after the director Frederic Rossif; and Angus Redford, named after Redford.\n\nRobert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" (1980) also dealt with the loss of a child. His directorial debut, starring Sutherland as the father of a family destroyed by tragedy, won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was never nominated for an Oscar but received an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and won two Golden Globes for \"Citizen X\" and the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\nSutherland's New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances. A down period in the '80s followed, with failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily and increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's defense secretary, Clark Clifford.\n\nAfter son Kiefer emerged as a star, Sutherland appeared in numerous films with him, including the 1996 thriller \"A Time to Kill\" and 2015's \"Forsaken.\" But he turned down the chance to play the father on the hit series \"24.\"\n\nTo a younger generation, Sutherland was most familiar as President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise beginning with the 2012 original. Sutherland sought out the part.\n\n\"The role of the president had maybe a line in the script. Maybe two. Didn't make any difference,\" Sutherland told GQ. \"I thought it was an incredibly important film, and I wanted to be a part of it.\"\n\nIn his final years, the nonstop actor mused about dying onscreen, for real.\n\n\"I'm really hoping that in some movie I'm doing, I die -- but I die, me, Donald -- and they're able to use my funeral and the coffin,\" Sutherland told the AP. \"That would be absolutely ideal. I would love that.\"", "source": {"uri": "wsfa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "https://www.wsfa.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series)", {"uri": "2024-06-396268552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:10:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:10:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:34:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/donald-sutherland-dead-hunger-games-mash-actor/507-b35ab281-c6d9-4b63-b362-59e12182141e", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland has died at age 88, family says", "body": "Sutherland's son Kiefer Sutherland confirmed the seasoned actor's death in a statement on X, formerly known as Twitter.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two -- again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford. For a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.", "source": {"uri": "weareiowa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local 5 - weareiowa.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-396282248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:26:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:26:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:27:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.ktsm.com/news/donald-sutherland-celebrated-actor-from-mash-hunger-games-dies-at-88-son-kiefer-announces/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, celebrated actor from 'M*A*S*H,' 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88, son Kiefer announces", "body": "(NEXSTAR) - Donald Sutherland, the prolific actor who starred in such films as \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Ordinary People\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at the age of 88, son Kiefer Sutherland revealed Thursday.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland, originally from Canada, rose to fame with a string of well-received roles in movies such as \"The Dirty Dozen,\" \"M*A*S*H,' and \"Klute.\" His resume in the 1970s also included appearances in cult films including \"Don't Look Now,\" \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" and \"National Lampoon's Animal House.\"\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing,\" the latter of which earned him a Critics Choice Award for Best Supporting Actor.\n\nSutherland had also earned an Emmy for his role in the miniseries \"Citizen X.\" He was bestowed an honorary Oscar in 2017 for his body of work.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nSutherland is survived by his five children and wife Francine Racette, Variety reported.", "source": {"uri": "ktsm.com", {"uri": "8187560860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:45:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:45:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:44:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/entertainment/2990065-donald-sutherland-a-legendary-career-remembered", "title": "Donald Sutherland: A Legendary Career Remembered | Entertainment", "body": "Donald Sutherland, one of Canada's most versatile actors, has passed away at 88. Known for roles in 'M*A*S*H,' 'Ordinary People,' and 'The Hunger Games,' his career spanned six decades. Tributes hail his incredible range and dedication, marking him as a true legend in the industry.\n\nDonald Sutherland, one of Canada's most versatile and gifted actors, who charmed and enthralled audiences in movies such as \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute,\" \"Ordinary People\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at the age of 88. The actor, whose lengthy career spanned from the 1960s into the 2020s, died on Thursday, his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, said on social media.\n\nA tall man with a deep voice, piercing blue eyes and a mischievous smile, Donald Sutherland switched effortlessly from character roles to romantic leads opposite the likes of Jane Fonda and Julie Christie. He also played his share of oddballs and villains. One of the biggest stars in Hollywood in the 1970s, he remained in demand for film and TV projects into his 80s. Known for his unconventional looks and his versatility as an actor, Sutherland played a wide range of memorable characters.\n\nThese included a rascally Army surgeon in \"M*A*S*H\" (1970), a quirky tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" (1970), a small-town detective in \"Klute\" (1971), a stoned and libidinous professor in \"Animal House\" (1978), a local official facing an alien presence in \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" (1978) and a despairing father in \"Ordinary People\" (1980). He won a new generation of fans with his glorious portrayal of a despotic president in \"The Hunger Games\" (2012) and its sequels. \"I wish I could say thank you to all of the characters that I've played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life,\" Sutherland said in his speech accepting an honorary Academy Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.\n\nKiefer Sutherland said his father was \"never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\" \"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nDonald Sutherland was born on July 17, 1935, in Canada's New Brunswick province, and was raised in Nova Scotia. He performed in school productions in college, moved to Britain to hone his craft, then moved to the United States, where his first big break came as a member of a top-notch ensemble cast in the war film \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967). He rocketed to fame three years later playing nonconformist surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in director Robert Altman's Korean War satire \"M*A*S*H\" (1970). The film - later spun off into a TV series - depicted hijinks at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital, tapping into the anti-war sentiment among many Americans during the Vietnam War era.\n\nAlso in 1970, Sutherland starred alongside Telly Savalas and Clint Eastwood in \"Kelly's Heroes\" as Sergeant Oddball on a mission to steal gold from the Nazis. The following year, he was paired with Fonda, one of Hollywood's luminaries, in \"Klute,\" and then in 1973 played a grieving father in \"Don't Look Now\" that included a sizzling sex scene with Christie. \"Klute\" sparked a romance with Fonda, with whom he was active in the anti-Vietnam War movement.\n\nHis 1978 films could not have been more different. In the uproarious comedy \"Animal House,\" Sutherland played a professor who sleeps with the girlfriend of a fraternity member. \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" was a successful sci-fi remake of a classic 1956 original, telling the story of alien pods that take over human beings. Sutherland's performance in \"Ordinary People,\" Hollywood superstar Robert Redford's directorial debut, helped the 1980 film win four Academy Awards, including best picture. Sutherland starred alongside Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton in this exploration of the splintering of a Midwestern family.\n\nIn the 1990s he appeared in films including \"JFK\" (1991), \"Backdraft\" (1991), \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer\" (1992), \"Outbreak\" (1995), \"A Time To Kill\" (1996) and \"Instinct\" (1999) and won an Emmy Award for his performance in the 1995 HBO TV movie \"Citizen X.\" In the 2000s, he appeared in the acclaimed \"Cold Mountain\" (2003) and \"Pride & Prejudice\" (2005). In the \"Hunger Games\" films in the 2010s about a dystopian future in which teenagers are sent into a deadly competition as mass entertainment, he reveled in playing the villainous President Coriolanus Snow.\n\n\"The reality was he had a country to run. At least he was running it, which is more than you can say for some people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times in 2017. \"It was funny at the beginning with 'The Hunger Games' to walk through an airport and suddenly you feel this tug and you look down and it's some young person - always a girl, never a boy,\" Sutherland said. \"And her mother is standing there and they say, 'Could you take a photograph with my daughter?' And we'd be standing beside each other and I'd be looking at the camera and the girl would say, 'Could you look mean?'\"\n\nTributes to Sutherland came in across Hollywood and Canada on Thursday. Ron Howard, who directed Sutherland in \"Backdraft,\" called him \"one of the most intelligent, interesting and engrossing film actors of all time.\"\n\nSutherland had \"incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence,\" Howard wrote on X. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, speaking to reporters in Nova Scotia, said Sutherland \"was a man with a strong presence, a brilliance in his craft and truly, truly a great Canadian artist.\"\n\nSutherland was considered among the best actors to never receive an Academy Award nomination for any of his roles. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. {"uri": "8187526416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:17:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:17:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:15:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.fox35orlando.com/news/actor-donald-sutherland-known-klute-hunger-games-many-more-dies-88", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland, known for 'Klute,' 'Hunger Games,' and many more, dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the actor known for his roles in M*A*S*H, The Hunger Games & Pride & Prejudice passed away at 88-years-old. Donald's son Kiefer shared the news on a statement posted on X, 'With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.'\n\nActor Donald Sutherland, known for his roles in films such as \"The Dirty Dozen,\" Klute,\" \"Hunger Games,\" and many more, has died. His son, Kiefer Sutherland, shared the news on X, formerly known as Twitter, on Thursday.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" the tweet read.\n\nNo further details on his death were immediately shared. Sutherland was 88 years old when he passed.\n\nBorn in Saint John, Canada, Sutherland barely survived a series of childhood diseases, including infantile paralysis, rheumatoid fever and spinal meningitis.\n\nHe chronicles those struggles in his memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" which is set to be released in November of this year. Sutherland also shared details about his burgeoning teenage sexuality and his love for acting. He began acting on screen in the early 1960s.\n\nSutherland broke through in Hollywood with a small role in the 1967 World War II classic \"The Dirty Dozen,\" and broke big with a starring role as Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.\"\n\nHe worked with auteurs including Nicolas Roeg in \"Don't Look Now\" and Federico Fellini in \"Fellini's Casanova.\" And he appeared just as often in more popular fare, playing a spacey tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes,\" a demented arsonist in \"Backdraft\" and an authoritarian president in the \"Hunger Games\" films.\n\nMore recently, Sutherland worked on the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.", "source": {"uri": "fox35orlando.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 35 Orlando"}, He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8187560967", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:44:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/hollywood/donald-sutherland-star-of-m-a-s-h-and-the-hunger-games-dead-at-88-101718908791637.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, star of 'M*A*S*H' and 'The Hunger Games', dead at 88", "body": "-Donald Sutherland, one of Canada's most versatile and gifted actors, who charmed and enthralled audiences in movies such as \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute,\" \"Ordinary People\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at the age of 88.\n\nThe actor, whose lengthy career spanned from the 1960s into the 2020s, died on Thursday, his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, said on social media.\n\nA tall man with a deep voice, piercing blue eyes and a mischievous smile, Donald Sutherland switched effortlessly from character roles to romantic leads opposite the likes of Jane Fonda and Julie Christie. He also played his share of oddballs and villains.\n\nOne of the biggest stars in Hollywood in the 1970s, he remained in demand for film and TV projects into his 80s. Known for his unconventional looks and his versatility as an actor, Sutherland played a wide range of memorable characters.\n\nThese included a rascally Army surgeon in \"M*A*S*H\" , a quirky tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" , a small-town detective in \"Klute\" , a stoned and libidinous professor in \"Animal House\" , a local official facing an alien presence in \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" and a despairing father in \"Ordinary People\" . He won a new generation of fans with his glorious portrayal of a despotic president in \"The Hunger Games\" and its sequels.\n\n\"I wish I could say thank you to all of the characters that I've played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life,\" Sutherland said in his speech accepting an honorary Academy Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.\n\nKiefer Sutherland said his father was \"never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\"\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nDonald Sutherland was born on July 17, 1935, in Canada's New Brunswick province, and was raised in Nova Scotia. He performed in school productions in college, moved to Britain to hone his craft, then moved to the United States, where his first big break came as a member of a top-notch ensemble cast in the war film \"The Dirty Dozen\" .\n\nHe rocketed to fame three years later playing nonconformist surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in director Robert Altman's Korean War satire \"M*A*S*H\" . The film - later spun off into a TV series - depicted hijinks at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital, tapping into the anti-war sentiment among many Americans during the Vietnam War era.\n\nAlso in 1970, Sutherland starred alongside Telly Savalas and Clint Eastwood in \"Kelly's Heroes\" as Sergeant Oddball on a mission to steal gold from the Nazis.\n\nThe following year, he was paired with Fonda, one of Hollywood's luminaries, in \"Klute,\" and then in 1973 played a grieving father in \"Don't Look Now\" that included a sizzling sex scene with Christie. \"Klute\" sparked a romance with Fonda, with whom he was active in the anti-Vietnam War movement.\n\nHis 1978 films could not have been more different. In the uproarious comedy \"Animal House,\" Sutherland played a professor who sleeps with the girlfriend of a fraternity member. \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" was a successful sci-fi remake of a classic 1956 original, telling the story of alien pods that take over human beings.\n\nSutherland's performance in \"Ordinary People,\" Hollywood superstar Robert Redford's directorial debut, helped the 1980 film win four Academy Awards, including best picture. Sutherland starred alongside Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton in this exploration of the splintering of a Midwestern family.\n\nIn the 1990s he appeared in films including \"JFK\" , \"Backdraft\" , \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer\" , \"Outbreak\" , \"A Time To Kill\" and \"Instinct\" and won an Emmy Award for his performance in the 1995 HBO TV movie \"Citizen X.\" In the 2000s, he appeared in the acclaimed \"Cold Mountain\" and \"Pride & Prejudice\" .\n\nIn the \"Hunger Games\" films in the 2010s about a dystopian future in which teenagers are sent into a deadly competition as mass entertainment, he reveled in playing the villainous President Coriolanus Snow.\n\n\"The reality was he had a country to run. At least he was running it, which is more than you can say for some people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times in 2017.\n\n\"It was funny at the beginning with 'The Hunger Games' to walk through an airport and suddenly you feel this tug and you look down and it's some young person - always a girl, never a boy,\" Sutherland said. \"And her mother is standing there and they say, 'Could you take a photograph with my daughter?' And we'd be standing beside each other and I'd be looking at the camera and the girl would say, 'Could you look mean?'\"\n\nTributes to Sutherland came in across Hollywood and Canada on Thursday.\n\nRon Howard, who directed Sutherland in \"Backdraft,\" called him \"one of the most intelligent, interesting and engrossing film actors of all time.\"\n\nSutherland had \"incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence,\" Howard wrote on X.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, speaking to reporters in Nova Scotia, said Sutherland \"was a man with a strong presence, a brilliance in his craft and truly, truly a great Canadian artist.\"\n\nSutherland was considered among the best actors to never receive an Academy Award nomination for any of his roles. He was married three times and had five children, including Kiefer.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hindustan Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187598997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:19:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:19:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:18:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.thesouthafrican.com/lifestyle/celeb-news/international-celebs/rip-actor-donald-sutherland-dies-aged-88-breaking-news/", "title": "RIP: Actor Donald Sutherland dies aged 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland has died aged 88. Image: JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP / File\n\nDonald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"Fellini's Casanova\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died.\n\nHe was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death on Thursday.\n\nNo further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X.\n\n\"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomised the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down - but still eccentric - parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998.\n\n\"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom - time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher.\n\nRaised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981.\n\n\"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions.\n\nWhile studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress.\n\nThey married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting.\n\nSutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television.\n\nAfter a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic.\n\n1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970.\n\n\"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\"\n\nHe and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced.\n\nBut the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message.\n\nOutspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971.\n\nBanned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland's career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors - even if they didn't always do their best work with him.\n\nDonald Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas.\n\nHaving been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nHe did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two - again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991).\n\nHe again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Donald Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford.\n\nFor a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.", "source": {"uri": "thesouthafrican.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The South African"},
