{"uri": "8187490084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:48:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:48:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:46:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://statesville.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_38628e00-5b1b-523f-b6cd-e905b683dd1e.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... Don't throw out that mail: many NC families set to receive 'SUN Bucks' to help feed children this summer ALL-COUNTY BASEBALL: Cherry recognized as top player; Peck picked for coaching honor Statesville man facing a dozen drug charges in Iredell County Statesville City Council OKs 500 homes near airport Statesville woman found dead on Hickory Avenue; death considered homicide Closing a chapter: Much-loved Mooresville staple to close on Saturday Farm life brings Iredell father-son duo closer together Iredell-Statesville Schools accepts $143 million bid for high school in Troutman Former South Iredell coach Gary Sherrill dead at 85 North Carolina Public health restaurant and food-stand inspections in Iredell County, May 31-june 13 Novant ends $320 million bid to acquire Iredell hospitals Statesville Christian Women's Club to hear program on 'A Love Story Retold' NCHSAA rewards North Iredell teams for academic excellence Iredell commissioners reject plan for Troutman high school Out of Our Past: Drum's Supermarket closes after 50 years of continuous service\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8187486037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:45:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:45:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:43:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://scnow.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_840ec567-7ffd-5a06-9281-8d069605c979.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nPeople are also reading... I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland: A look at the award-winning actor's life and career, in photos 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1971: Donald Sutherland, Jane Fonda 1977: Donald Sutherland, Haskell Wexler 1978: Donald Sutherland, Bette Midler 1978: Donald Sutherland, John Belushi 1995: Donald Sutherland wins Emmy for \"Citizen X\" 1996: Donald Sutherland wins Golden Globe for \"Citizen X\" 1999: Donald Sutherland 2000: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2005: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland 2008: Donald Sutherland, William Baldwin 2008: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2009: Donald Sutherland in \"The Pillars of the Earth\" 2009: Donald Sutherland 2010: Donald Sutherland at Vancouver Olympics 2010: Donald Sutherland 2011: Donald Sutherland honored on Hollywood Walk of Fame 2012: Donald Sutherland 2012: Donald Sutherland at premiere of \"The Hunger Games\" 2014: Donald Sutherland 2014: Donald Sutherland 2015: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland, Kiefer Sutherland 2016: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland, Helen Mirren 2017: Donald Sutherland 2017: Donald Sutherland receives honorary Oscar 2018: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland, Mick Jagger 2019: Donald Sutherland 2019: Donald Sutherland Photos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.02745098039215677, "wgt": 208, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187542897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:29:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:29:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:28:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/entertainment/2024/06/actor-donald-sutherland-dies.html", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland dies | Newshub", "body": "Donald Sutherland, a veteran actor known for roles in \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died, according to a statement from his agency CAA.\n\nHe was 88.\n\nSutherland died Thursday in Miami after a long illness, according to his agency.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland, Donald Sutherland's son, wrote in a post on Instagram Thursday. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\"\n\nKiefer Sutherland continued to write that his father \"loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nDecorated resume\n\nTall, distinctive and known for his intensity on screen, Sutherland earned an Emmy for his role as a Soviet official in the fact-based 1995 TV movie \"Citizen X,\" as well as a pair of Golden Globes. His career spanned more than 60 years and nearly 200 film and TV credits, including recent roles in the limited series \"Trust\" as oil tycoon J. Paul Getty and HBO's \"The Undoing.\"\n\nSutherland's big break came when he was cast as one of \"The Dirty Dozen\" in the star-studded 1967 film, which became a major hit. He followed that with another war movie, \"Kelly's Heroes,\" before playing the wisecracking doctor Hawkeye Pierce in the movie version of \"M*A*S*H\" and opposite Jane Fonda in her Oscar-winning portrayal of a high-class \"call girl\" in the crime mystery \"Klute.\" (Fonda and Sutherland also had an off-screen relationship around the time that they made the film.)\n\nReflecting his ability to play all sorts of roles, Sutherland's 1970s resume included a chillingly effective remake of the horror film \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" and a memorable turn as a pot-smoking professor in the National Lampoon comedy \"Animal House.\"\n\nHe also starred opposite Julie Christie in director Nicolas Roeg's \"Don't Look Now,\" a 1973 movie that became somewhat notorious for the raciness of its sex scene, which had to be trimmed in order to avoid an X rating.\n\nA steady stream of roles followed in a wide variety of genres, from a small but pivotal part in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" to supporting work in \"Ordinary People\" (which won the Oscar for best picture), \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer,\" \"Backdraft\" and \"The Italian Job.\"\n\nSutherland also starred as the legendary lover for director Federico Fellini in \"Fellini's Casanova.\" Many younger filmgoers, meanwhile, will likely remember him as the evil president in \"The Hunger Games\" movies.\n\nBeginnings\n\nBorn in Saint John, New Brunswick, Sutherland endured several bouts of ill health as a child, including polio. He attended the University of Toronto, where he studied engineering before gravitating toward drama and appearing on stage, graduating with degrees in both.\n\nThe 6'4\" actor met his first wife, Lois Hardwick, in college, and the two married in 1959. He moved to London, where he found some stage work, and eventually to Hollywood in the 1960s, where \"Dirty Dozen\" and \"M*A*S*H\" put him on the map.\n\nIn the mid-1960s he divorced, marrying actress Shirley Douglas, whom he met while filming the horror movie \"Castle of the Living Dead.\" They had two children, actor Kiefer and Rachel, who also works in film as a post-production supervisor. That marriage also ended in divorce, and in 1972 Sutherland wed his third wife, actress Francine Racette, with whom he had three sons.\n\nIn a 2020 conversation with \"The Undoing\" costar Hugh Grant for Interview magazine, Sutherland said that he was always so nervous when a movie began shooting that he threw up the night before. He also discussed subtly altering his dialogue, as he put it, to \"try to make the lines that I've been given fit my mouth.\"\n\nSutherland appeared in three films with son Kiefer, beginning with the \"24\" star's small part in the comedy-drama \"Max Dugan Returns\" in 1983, followed by the John Grisham adaptation \"A Time to Kill.\" The two didn't perform in a scene together, however, until the 2016 western \"Forsaken.\"\n\n\"It was a memory and an experience that I will treasure for the rest of my life,\" Kiefer Sutherland told \"Good Morning America\" at the time, saying he spent years looking for something that the two could do together.\n\nAsked what advice he would give young actors, Sutherland told Reuters in 2019, \"Try and be as truthful as you possibly can, read, read a lot, learn, memorize things, enjoy your artistry, study dancing, be a circus performer, learn how to juggle, so many things, but mostly you have to observe.\"\n\nSutherland received an honorary award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences board in 2017 and was honored with the Order of Canada.\n\nIn 2022, Sutherland appeared alongside Halle Berry and Patrick Wilson in the space thriller \"Moonfall\" and in the Roku TV mini series \"Swimming with Sharks.\" His final credit came in 2023, with the actor starring in the Paramount+ western drama \"Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\"\n\nCNN", "source": "https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/entertainment/2024/06/actor-donald-sutherland-dies/_jcr_content/par/image.dynimg.1280.q75.jpg/v1718907529842/MixCollage-21-Jun-2024-06-18-AM-7122.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.01960784313725483, "wgt": 208, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187487934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:10:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:10:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:45:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13552095/Donald-Sutherland-towering-actor-career-spanned-M-A-S-H-Hunger-Games-dies-88.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down - but still eccentric - parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\nFILE - Actor Donald Sutherland appears at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Oct. 13, 2017. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP, File)\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom - time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director\u00b4s unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone\u00b4s expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors - even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two - again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford. For a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.\n\nFILE - Actor Donald Sutherland appears at the premiere of the film \"The Burnt Orange Heresy\" at the 76th edition of the Venice Film Festival, Venice, Italy, on Sept. 7, 2019. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Arthur Mola/Invision/AP, File)\n\nFILE - Donald Sutherland appears at the Oscars in Los Angeles on March 4, 2018. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP, File)\n\nFILE - Actor Donald Sutherland appears at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Oct. 13, 2017. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP, File)\n\nFILE - Actor Donald Sutherland appears at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Oct. 13, 2017. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP, File)\n\nFILE - Actor Donald Sutherland poses at the Wilshire Ebell Theater in Los Angeles on Oct. 16, 2001. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (AP Photo/Rene Macura, File)\n\nFILE - Actors, from left, James Garner, Donald Sutherland, Tommy Lee Jones and Clint Eastwood, from the film \"Space Cowboys,\" pose for photographers at the Venice Film Festival in Venice, Italy, on Aug. 30, 2000. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (AP Photo/Luca Bruno, File)\n\nFILE - Liam Hemsworth, from left, Jennifer Lawrence and Donald Sutherland appear at the premiere of \"The Hunger Games: Catching Fire\" in Los Angeles on Nov. 18, 2013. Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Matt Sayles/Invision/AP, File)\n\nFILE - Donald Sutherland, left, and his son Kiefer Sutherland pose for a portrait in Los Angeles to promote the film \"Forsaken.\" Donald Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. Donald's son Kiefer shared the news on a statement posted on X, 'With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. A life well lived.'\n\nActor Donald Sutherland, known for his roles in films such as \"The Dirty Dozen,\" Klute,\" \"Hunger Games,\" and many more, has died. His son, Kiefer Sutherland, shared the news on X, formerly known as Twitter, on Thursday.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" the tweet read.\n\nSutherland was 88 years old when he passed, according to Deadline.\n\nBorn in Saint John, Canada, Sutherland barely survived a series of childhood diseases, including infantile paralysis, rheumatoid fever and spinal meningitis.\n\nHe chronicles those struggles in his memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" which is set to be released in November of this year. Sutherland also shared details about his burgeoning teenage sexuality and his love for acting. He began acting on screen in the early 1960s.\n\nSutherland broke through in Hollywood with a small role in the 1967 World War II classic \"The Dirty Dozen,\" and broke big with a starring role as Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.\"\n\nHe worked with auteurs including Nicolas Roeg in \"Don't Look Now\" and Federico Fellini in \"Fellini's Casanova.\" And he appeared just as often in more popular fare, playing a spacey tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes,\" a demented arsonist in \"Backdraft\" and an authoritarian president in the \"Hunger Games\" films.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187539504", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:26:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:26:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.indiewire.com/news/breaking-news/donald-sutherland-tributes-1235018363/", "title": "Edgar Wright, Ron Howard, Margaret Atwood, and More Pay Tribute to Donald Sutherland: His 'Creative Courage' Is Remembered", "body": "Late star Donald Sutherland is being remembered by his peers.\n\nThe iconic actor died at age 88, as announced on June 20. Sutherland starred in films such as \"Ordinary People,\" \"The Dirty Dozen,\" \"MASH,\" \"JFK,\" and \"Klute,\" as well as \"Pride & Prejudice\" and \"The Hunger Games.\" Among his extensive filmography was also TV series \"Citizen X,\" \"The Undoing,\" and \"Trust.\"\n\nSutherland won an honorary Oscar in 2017 and was an Emmy winner for \"Citizen X.\"\n\nSutherland's son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, tweeted to confirm his passing.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nEdgar Wright wrote that Sutherland was an \"always fascinating\" actor, and cited \"Don't Look Now\" and 1978's \"Invasion Of The Body Snatchers\" as two of his \"favorite and most influential films\" ever, both starring Sutherland.\n\n\"So sorry to see you go Donald, but what a legacy you leave behind,\" Wright tweeted.\n\nSutherland's former collaborator, director Ron Howard, also took to social media to honor the late actor.\n\n\"I was blessed to direct him in 'Backdraft,'\" Howard penned. \"One of the most intelligent, interesting, & engrossing film actors of all time. Incredible range, creative courage, & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence.\"", "source": {"uri": "indiewire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "IndieWire"}, "authors": [{"uri": "samantha_bergeson@indiewire.com", "name": "Samantha Bergeson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Donald Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Undoing", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "The Undoing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "M*A*S*H (TV series)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klute", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Klute"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pride_and_Prejudice", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Pride and Prejudice"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hunger_Games", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "The Hunger Games"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiefer_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kiefer Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8187444941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:12:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:12:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:11:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://variety.com/2024/film/news/donald-sutherland-dead-mash-hunger-games-1236043323/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, Star of 'MASH,' 'Klute' and 'Hunger Games,' Dies at 88", "body": "Sidney Poitier, Oscar Winner Who Helped Tear Down Racial Barriers, Dies at 94 2 years ago\n\nDonald Sutherland, the tall, lean and long-faced Canadian actor who became a countercultural icon with such films as \"The Dirty Dozen,\" \"MASH,\" \"Klute\" and \"Don't Look Now,\" and who subsequently enjoyed a prolific and wide-ranging career in films including \"Ordinary People\" and \"Without Limits,\" has died, his agency, CAA, confirmed. He was 88.\n\nFor over a half century, Sutherland memorably played villains, antiheroes, romantic leads and mentor figures. His profile had recently increased with his supporting role as the evil President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise.\n\nSutherland won a supporting actor Emmy for HBO's \"Citizen X\" in 1995 and was also nominated in 2006 for the Lifetime miniseries \"Human Trafficking.\"\n\nAfter what Sutherland called \"a meandering little career,\" including roles in low-budget horror pics like 1963's \"Castle of the Living Dead\" and 1965's \"Die! Die! My Darling!,\" he landed a part as one of the bottom six in 1967's \"The Dirty Dozen.\"\n\nSutherland told the Guardian in 2005 that he originally had one line in the film, until Clint Walker refused to play a scene requiring him to impersonate a general. According to Sutherland, director Robert Aldrich, who didn't know his name, suddenly turned to him and said, \"You! With the big ears! You do it!\"\n\nThe smart-alecky role was a perfect fit for Sutherland, whose wolfish sideways smile and boyish charm caught the attention of producer Ingo Preminger, who cast him as the anti-authoritarian surgeon Capt. \"Hawkeye\" Pierce in 1970's comedy smash hit \"MASH.\"\n\n\"MASH\" turned Sutherland, and co-star Elliott Gould, who played Capt. \"Trapper\" John, into major stars. But the tradition-bound actors had trouble adjusting to director Robert Altman's improvisational and often chaotic approach. According to Sutherland, Altman tried to fire him during the shoot, but Preminger held firm.\n\nIn a 1976 Playboy interview, Altman gave a different view, recalling that Sutherland loved his directorial style. \"His improvisation was profound,\" Altman said. \"He's a hell of an actor.\"\n\nSutherland also co-starred with Gould in 1971's inspired Alan Arkin-helmed black comedy \"Little Murders\" and again in director Irvin Kershner's 1974 misfire \"SPYS.\"\n\nIn the 1970 WWII actioner \"Kelly's Heroes,\" Sutherland joined Clint Eastwood, portraying Sgt. Oddball, an absurdly conceived but scene-stealing proto-hippie tank commander. (Sutherland reteamed with Eastwood in 2000's \"Space Cowboys,\" this time playing a former hotshot pilot.)\n\nWith 1971's \"Klute,\" a thriller/character study directed by Alan J. Pakula and co-starring Jane Fonda, Sutherland emerged as a credible romantic leading man. He portrayed a troubled detective who falls in love with a call girl (Fonda) whom he's protecting from a sadistic killer.\n\nFonda later gave Sutherland credit for her Oscar-winning best actress performance, because of \"all the intense feelings I was experiencing\" with him.\n\nThe two were having a love affair at the time, and the relationship stoked Sutherland's antiwar politics. He got involved with Vietnam Veterans Against the War and, along with Peter Boyle and Howard Hesseman, Fonda and Sutherland put together a traveling revue called FTA (Free the Army, popularly known as F*@k the Army). The Pentagon unsuccessfully tried to keep troops away from the shows; the FBI put both Sutherland and Fonda under surveillance.\n\nIn Nicholas Roeg's influential 1973 psychological horror film \"Don't Look Now,\" Sutherland's intriguing passivity and pared-down acting style helped highlight Julie Christie's performance. They portray a grieving married couple who flee England to Venice after the death of their little girl.\n\nThe film became controversial for an integral explicit sex scene between them, edited in a fragmented style. Roeg intercut their post-coital dressing to go out to dinner as the sequence unfolds. Even in a sex-obsessed era, the scene became -- and remains -- one of the most memorable ever filmed.\n\nAt the height of his success, Sutherland began to make eccentric career choices. He turned down John Boorman for \"Deliverance\" and chose Paul Mazursky's flat \"Alex in Wonderland\" (1970) over Peckinpah's \"Straw Dogs.\" He acted with Fonda again in \"Steelyard Blues\" (1973) and played Christ in Dalton Trumbo's \"Johnny Got His Gun\" (1971). Both fizzled at the box office.\n\nSutherland received mixed notices for his role as a hick in John Schlesinger's \"Day of the Locust\" (1975), played the title character in 1976's arty bomb \"Fellini's Casanova\" and a psychopathic fascist in Bertolucci's \"1900\" (1977). He had a memorable cameo in 1978 hit \"National Lampoon's Animal House,\" playing a professor who is discovered having an affair with a student (Karen Allen). He took a small upfront fee for his work instead of an offered percentage of the profits. The actor estimated the choice cost him $14 million.\n\nSutherland rebounded with 1980's \"Ordinary People,\" convincing director Robert Redford to cast him as the grieving father trying to hold his family together after his older son's accidental death. Redford had originally offered him the part of the psychiatrist that eventually went to Judd Hirsch.\n\nIn 1981 WWII thriller \"Eye of the Needle,\" Sutherland gave one of his last romantic leading man performances on the bigscreen, albeit as a heavy -- a stranded German agent who falls for a lonely married woman (Kate Nelligan).\n\nAnother career peak came in 1998, when Sutherland convinced director-writer Robert Towne to cast him as coach and Nike co-founder Bill Bowerman in \"Without Limits,\" about U. of Oregon runner Steve Prefontaine (Billy Crudup). He was also memorable in 2005's \"Pride and Prejudice\" as Keira Knightley's father.\n\nSutherland made a lasting impression in smaller roles, such as Mister X, a high-placed Pentagon official who claims to know why JFK was murdered, in 1991's Oliver Stone-helmed \"JFK.\"\n\nRemarkably, Sutherland was never nominated for an Oscar, though his work in such films as \"Ordinary People\" and \"Without Limits\" is often cited by critics as among the finest of their respective decades.\n\nOther noteworthy roles include President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" (2012) and its sequels; a safecracker in \"The Italian Job\" (2003); the father in \"Six Degrees of Separation\" (1993); a stylish safecracker in \"The Great Train Robbery\" (1978); and the lead in Philip Kaufman's 1978 remake of \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers.\"\n\nSutherland also appeared with son Kiefer in 1996's \"A Time to Kill.\" He turned down an offer to play the father of Kiefer's character, Jack Bauer, in \"24,\" his son's successful TV series. The two appeared together in the 2014 Western \"Forsaken.\"\n\nIn 2014 the actor also starred with Brie Larson in the India-set musical comedy \"Basmati Blues,\" written and directed by Dan Baron.\n\nSutherland's TV work includes \"The Superlative Seven\" episode of \"The Avengers\" (1967) and two episodes of \"The Saint\" (1965, 1966). He starred as Patrick \"Tripp\" Darling III in \"Dirty Sexy Money\" (2007-09) and as Nathan Templeton in \"Commander in Chief\" (2005-06). His TV miniseries work includes 2010's \"The Pillars of the Earth,\" based on Ken Follett's epic novel.\n\nIn one of his best TV roles, Sutherland portrayed Clark Clifford in John Frankenheimer's \"Path to War\" (2002). In 1995, he won a supporting actor Emmy for \"Citizen X\" (HBO).\n\nHe was a series regular in Ed Bernero's European crime series \"Crossing Lines.\"", "source": {"uri": "variety.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Variety"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "M*A*S*H (TV series)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Fonda", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jane Fonda"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutherland", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sutherland"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Sutherland"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klute", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Klute"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Gould", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Elliott Gould"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Awards", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Academy Awards"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Improvisation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Improvisation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanticism", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Romanticism"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_J._Pakula", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Alan J. "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.07450980392156858, "wgt": 207, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187580746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:03:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:03:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:02:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/hollywood/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games-dies-at-88-101718909951314.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "Son Kiefer Sutherland confirmed the death Thursday. No details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Sutherland, who flashed a grin that could be sweet or diabolical, was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s. He never stopped working, ultimately appearing in nearly 200 films and series.\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- roles in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" is due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at age 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959 but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art to study acting. He began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis breakthrough was \"The Dirty Dozen\" , in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopath. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" a smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He was unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations.\n\nSutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, he along with actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\n\"I thought I was going to be part of a revolution that was going to change movies and its influence on people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times.\n\nHis career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini , Bernardo Bertolucci , Claude Chabrol and John Schlesinger .\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" . It was during filming that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. He and Douglas divorced in 1971 after having twins: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nNicolas Roeg's psychological horror film \"Don't Look Now\" was another high point. Sutherland starred with Julie Christie as a grieving married couple who move to Venice after their daughter's death. The film included a famous, explicit sex scene, artfully edited.\n\n\"Nic and I thought that maybe I would die in the process of it, so much were we committed,\" Sutherland once said. His admiration for the film and Roeg was such that he and his next wife, actress Francine Racette, named their first-born child Roeg.\n\nSutherland married Racette in 1972 and remained with her the rest of his life. She survives him. They had two other children together: Rossif, named after the director Frederic Rossif; and Angus Redford, named after Redford.\n\nRobert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" also dealt with the loss of a child. His directorial debut, starring Sutherland as the father of a family destroyed by tragedy, won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was never nominated for an Oscar but received an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and won two Golden Globes for \"Citizen X\" and the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\nSutherland's New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances. A down period in the '80s followed, with failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in \"JFK\" and played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\" Sutherland also increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's defense secretary, Clark Clifford.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hindustan Times"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8187502771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:58:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:58:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:57:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/donald-sutherland-dead-legendary-mash-171748940.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland dead: Legendary MASH and Hunger Games actor dies at 88", "body": "Legendary Hollywood actor Donald Sutherland, whose career stretched from the 1970s to the 2020s, has died at the age of 88 following \"a long illness\".\n\nSutherland burst onto the scene in the late 1960s before starring in several 70s classics such as Klute, MASH, Don't Look Now and Animal House.\n\nHe was considered one of the greatest actors to never have received an Academy Award nomination however he was bestowed with an honourary statuette in 2017.\n\nCanadian Sutherland is the father of Emmy-winning 24 actor Kiefer Sutherland.\n\nHe is survived by his wife Francine Racette, sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer and daughter Rachel. The star had four grandchildren.\n\nKiefer paid tribute to his father describing him as \"one of the most important actors in the history of film\".\n\nSharing a black and white photo of himself as a child with his father on X, formerly Twitter, he wrote: \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nKiefer is also known for his roles in films Phone Booth and The Three Musketeers.A private celebration of Sutherland's life will be held by the family, his agent confirmed to the PA news agency.\n\nA statement from the CAA group said: \"Acclaimed actor Donald Sutherland died today in Miami, Florida, after a long illness. He was 88 years old.\"\n\nSutherland won a Golden Globe for the television movie Path to War and an Emmy Award for his performance in the miniseries Citizen X.\n\nExtensive TV credits include The {"uri": "8187484158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:43:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:43:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:42:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://theeagle.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_61c81f4a-a85e-5f50-a00e-e6cd8212f9a0.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nPeople are also reading... "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Miami"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Miami"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Acting", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Acting", "wgt": 19}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Awards", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Awards", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Awards/Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Awards/Screen Actors Guild Awards", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Awards", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Television/Awards", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Awards", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Awards", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 91}], "image": "https://www.harrowtimes.co.uk/resources/images/18218197/", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-396283237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:27:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:27:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:32:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.oneidadispatch.com/2024/06/20/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games-dies-at-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two -- again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford. For a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.", "source": {"uri": "oneidadispatch.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oneida Dispatch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "https://www.oneidadispatch.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Obit_Donald_Sutherland_81378.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187593226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:14:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:14:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:13:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://whdh.com/entertainment/donald-sutherland-veteran-actor-known-for-roles-in-mash-klute-and-the-hunger-games-dead-at-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, veteran actor known for roles in 'M*A*S*H,' 'Klute' and 'The Hunger Games,' dead at 88 - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "(CNN) -- Donald Sutherland, a veteran actor known for roles in \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died, according to a statement from his agency CAA.\n\nHe was 88.\n\nSutherland died Thursday in Miami after a long illness, according to his agency.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland, Donald Sutherland's son, wrote in a post on Instagram Thursday. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\"\n\nKiefer Sutherland continued to write that his father \"loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nDecorated resume\n\nTall, distinctive and known for his intensity on screen, Sutherland earned an Emmy for his role as a Soviet official in the fact-based 1995 TV movie \"Citizen X,\" as well as a pair of Golden Globes. His career spanned more than 60 years and nearly 200 film and TV credits, including recent roles in the limited series \"Trust\" as oil tycoon J. Paul Getty and HBO's \"The Undoing.\"\n\nSutherland's big break came when he was cast as one of \"The Dirty Dozen\" in the star-studded 1967 film, which became a major hit. He followed that with another war movie, \"Kelly's Heroes,\" before playing the wisecracking doctor Hawkeye Pierce in the movie version of \"M*A*S*H\" and opposite Jane Fonda in her Oscar-winning portrayal of a high-class \"call girl\" in the crime mystery \"Klute.\" (Fonda and Sutherland also had an off-screen relationship around the time that they made the film.)\n\nReflecting his ability to play all sorts of roles, Sutherland's 1970s resume included a chillingly effective remake of the horror film \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" and a memorable turn as a pot-smoking professor in the National Lampoon comedy \"Animal House.\"\n\nHe also starred opposite Julie Christie in director Nicolas Roeg's \"Don't Look Now,\" a 1973 movie that became somewhat notorious for the raciness of its sex scene, which had to be trimmed in order to avoid an X rating.\n\nA steady stream of roles followed in a wide variety of genres, from a small but pivotal part in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" to supporting work in \"Ordinary People\" (which won the Oscar for best picture), \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer,\" \"Backdraft\" and \"The Italian Job.\"\n\nSutherland also starred as the legendary lover for director Federico Fellini in \"Fellini's Casanova.\" Many younger filmgoers, meanwhile, will likely remember him as the evil president in \"The Hunger Games\" movies.\n\nBeginnings\n\nBorn in Saint John, New Brunswick, Sutherland endured several bouts of ill health as a child, including polio. He attended the University of Toronto, where he studied engineering before gravitating toward drama and appearing on stage, graduating with degrees in both.\n\nThe 6'4\" actor met his first wife, Lois Hardwick, in college, and the two married in 1959. He moved to London, where he found some stage work, and eventually to Hollywood in the 1960s, where \"Dirty Dozen\" and \"M*A*S*H\" put him on the map.\n\nIn the mid-1960s he divorced, marrying actress Shirley Douglas, whom he met while filming the horror movie \"Castle of the Living Dead.\" They had two children, actor Kiefer and Rachel, who also works in film as a post-production supervisor. That marriage also ended in divorce, and in 1972 Sutherland wed his third wife, actress Francine Racette, with whom he had three sons.\n\nIn a 2020 conversation with \"The Undoing\" costar Hugh Grant for Interview magazine, Sutherland said that he was always so nervous when a movie began shooting that he threw up the night before. He also discussed subtly altering his dialogue, as he put it, to \"try to make the lines that I've been given fit my mouth.\"\n\nFamily connections\n\nSutherland appeared in three films with son Kiefer, beginning with the \"24\" star's small part in the comedy-drama \"Max Dugan Returns\" in 1983, followed by the John Grisham adaptation \"A Time to Kill.\" The two didn't perform in a scene together, however, until the 2016 western \"Forsaken.\"\n\n\"It was a memory and an experience that I will treasure for the rest of my life,\" Kiefer Sutherland told \"Good Morning America\" at the time, saying he spent years looking for something that the two could do together.\n\nAsked what advice he would give young actors, Sutherland told Reuters in 2019, \"Try and be as truthful as you possibly can, read, read a lot, learn, memorize things, enjoy your artistry, study dancing, be a circus performer, learn how to juggle, so many things, but mostly you have to observe.\"\n\nSutherland received an honorary award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences board in 2017 and was honored with the Order of Canada.\n\nIn 2022, Sutherland appeared alongside Halle Berry and Patrick Wilson in the space thriller \"Moonfall\" and in the Roku TV mini series \"Swimming with Sharks.\" His final credit came in 2023, with the actor starring in the Paramount+ western drama \"Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\"\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 CNN. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.)\n\nJoin our Newsletter for the latest news right to your inbox Email address Submit", "source": {"uri": "whdh.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WHDH 7 Boston"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "M*A*S*H (TV series)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiefer_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kiefer Sutherland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klute", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Klute"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hunger_Games", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "The Hunger Games"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Fonda", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jane Fonda"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Undoing", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "The Undoing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmy_Awards", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Emmy Awards"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heroes_(American_TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Heroes (American TV series)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Awards", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Golden Globe Awards"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Paul_Getty", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. Paul Getty"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_film", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "History of film"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federico_Fellini", {"uri": "8187585177", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:07:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:07:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:06:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://wsvn.com/entertainment/donald-sutherland-veteran-actor-known-for-roles-in-mash-klute-and-the-hunger-games-dead-at-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, veteran actor known for roles in 'M*A*S*H,' 'Klute' and 'The Hunger Games,' dead at 88 - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "(CNN) -- Donald Sutherland, a veteran actor known for roles in \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died, according to a statement from his agency CAA.\n\nHe was 88.\n\nSutherland died Thursday in Miami after a long illness, according to his agency.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland, Donald Sutherland's son, wrote in a post on Instagram Thursday. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\"\n\nKiefer Sutherland continued to write that his father \"loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nTall and known for his intensity on screen, Sutherland earned an Emmy for his role as a Soviet official in the fact-based HBO movie \"Citizen X,\" as well as a pair of Golden Globes. His career spanned more than 50 years and 140 film credits, including recent roles in the limited series \"Trust\" as oil tycoon J. Paul Getty and HBO's \"The Undoing.\"\n\nSutherland's big break came when he was cast as one of \"The Dirty Dozen\" in the star-studded 1967 film, which became a major hit. He followed that with another war movie, \"Kelly's Heroes,\" before playing the wisecracking doctor Hawkeye Pierce in the movie version of \"M*A*S*H\" and opposite Jane Fonda in her Oscar-winning portrayal of a high-class \"call girl\" in the crime mystery \"Klute.\" (Fonda and Sutherland also had an off-screen relationship around the time that they made the film.)\n\nReflecting his ability to play all sorts of roles, Sutherland's 1970s resume included a remake of the horror film \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" and a memorable turn as a pot-smoking professor in the National Lampoon comedy \"Animal House.\"\n\nHe also starred opposite Julie Christie in director Nicolas Roeg's \"Don't Look Now,\" a 1973 movie that became somewhat notorious for the raciness of its sex scene, which had to be trimmed in order to avoid an X rating.\n\nA steady stream of roles followed in a wide variety of genres, from a small but pivotal part in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" to supporting work in \"Ordinary People\" (which won the Oscar for best picture), \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer,\" \"Backdraft\" and \"The Italian Job.\"\n\nSutherland also starred as the legendary lover for director Federico Fellini in \"Fellini's Casanova.\" Many younger filmgoers, meanwhile, will likely remember him as the evil president in \"The Hunger Games\" movies.\n\nBorn in Saint John, New Brunswick, Sutherland endured several bouts of ill health as a child, including polio. He attended the University of Toronto, where he studied engineering before gravitating toward drama and appearing on stage, graduating with degrees in both.\n\nThe 6'4\" actor met his first wife, Lois Hardwick, in college, and the two married in 1959. He moved to London, where he found some stage work, and eventually to Hollywood in the 1960s, where \"Dirty Dozen\" and \"M*A*S*H\" put him on the map.\n\nIn the mid-1960s he divorced, marrying actress Shirley Douglas, whom he met while filming the horror movie \"Castle of the Living Dead.\" They had two children, Kiefer and Rachel, who also works in film as a post-production supervisor. That also ended in divorce, and in 1972 Sutherland wed his third wife, actress Francine Racette, with whom he had three sons.\n\nIn a 2020 conversation with \"The Undoing\" co-star Hugh Grant for Interview magazine, Sutherland said that he was always so nervous when a movie began shooting that he threw up the night before. He also discussed subtly altering his dialogue, as he put it, to \"try to make the lines that I've been given fit my mouth.\"\n\nSutherland appeared in three films with son Kiefer, beginning with the \"24\" star's small part in the comedy-drama \"Max Dugan Returns\" in 1983, followed by the John Grisham adaptation \"A Time to Kill.\" The two didn't perform in a scene together, however, until the 2016 western \"Forsaken.\"\n\n\"It was a memory and an experience that I will treasure for the rest of my life,\" Kiefer Sutherland told \"Good Morning America\" at the time, saying he spent years looking for something that the two could do together.\n\nAsked what advice he would give young actors, Sutherland told Reuters in 2019, \"Try and be as truthful as you possibly can, read, read a lot, learn, memorize things, enjoy your artistry, study dancing, be a circus performer, learn how to juggle, so many things, but mostly you have to observe.\"\n\nSutherland received an honorary award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences board in 2017 and was honored with the Order of Canada.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\n\n\"A life well lived.\"\n\nBorn Donald McNichol Sutherland in Saint John on July 17, 1935, the actor became a magnetic screen star whose penchant for a range of unconventional characters would sustain him throughout a seldom interrupted six-decade career. He starred in acclaimed movies of the 1970s and '80s, including M*A*S*H, Klute, Invasion of the Body Snatchers and Ordinary People.\n\nHis role as President Snow, the quietly sadistic antagonist in The Hunger Games franchise, made him a recognizable face among a new generation, as did his role in 2005's Pride and Prejudice.\n\nSutherland is survived by his five children -- Kiefer, Rossif, Angus,
