{"uri": "8187663006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:21:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/arts-culture/film-tv/2024/06/20/veteran-actor-donald-sutherland-dies-at-age-88/", "title": "Veteran actor Donald Sutherland dies at age 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the enigmatic actor whose long career included films including The Dirty Dozen and The Hunger Games, has died, his son said on Thursday. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" actor Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nThe elder Sutherland had a distinctive look - and piercing eyes - that brought a depth and mystery to the huge range of roles he played over more than half a century on the big screen.\n\nOne of Canada's most famous sons, he played dashing leading men as well as anti-heroes and villains, most recently making a name among a new generation of fans as the evil President Snow in The Hunger Games franchise.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote.\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nReaction to the Emmy and Golden Globe winner's death was swift, with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau praising his unique talents.\n\n\"I had the opportunity when I was much younger to meet Donald Sutherland, and even as a young man who hadn't had a full exposure to the depth of brilliance of Donald Sutherland, I was deeply, deeply star-struck,\" Mr Trudeau told a media conference.\n\n\"He was a man with a strong presence, a brilliance in his craft, and truly, truly, a great Canadian artist, and he will be deeply missed.\"\n\nAfter what he termed a \"meandering\" start to his acting career, Donald Sutherland came to prominence in Robert Aldrich's The Dirty Dozen, where 12 convicts are given the task of what appears to be a suicide mission in occupied France.\n\nStarring alongside luminaries such as Charles Bronson, Lee Marvin and Telly Savalas, Sutherland's impish charms caught the attention of producers of M*A*S*H.\n\nAlthough set in the Korean War, the 1970 film was widely seen as a sophisticated satire on the Vietnam War.\n\nHis casting opposite Elliott Gould turned Sutherland into a household name in 1970s America, and opened the door to a durable career that would see him work with some of the biggest names in show business.\n\nThey included Jane Fonda, with whom he starred in 1971's Klute, in which he played a detective who falls for the call girl he is supposed to be protecting.\n\nFonda won an Oscar for her performance, which she credited to her intense feelings for Sutherland, with whom she was in a relationship at the time.\n\nTheir off-screen chemistry brought Sutherland into her pacifist orbit, and he became active in anti-Vietnam War circles.\n\nThe pair put together a travelling revue, which irked the US government and landed them both under FBI surveillance.", "source": {"uri": "thenationalnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, "authors": [{"uri": A life well lived.\"\n\nDonald Sutherland died on Thursday, June 20 after a long illness. He was known for his work in Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Pride & Prejudice, The Hunger Games franchise, and more. Donald and Kiefer Sutherland shared the screen together in multiple pictures, including, 1983's Max Dugan Returns, the 1996 legal thriller A Time to Kill, and, most recently, their 2015 Western film Forsaken, in which they starred as father and son.\n\nRelatedDonald Sutherland Dies at 88 More from this section Travis & Taylor's date night dish revealed. {"uri": "8187577674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:59:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:59:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:58:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/ap/donald-sutherland-tv-film-actor-dies/article_e7ff989c-2f31-11ef-9291-172db156e153.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, a towering actor whose work spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nGreenville News Make a movie in 48 hours? This film project attracted dozens of filmmakers across SC. By Benjamin Simon bsimon@postandcourier.com\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\nArts & Entertainment For more than a century, Columbia actors work by day and dazzle onstage by night By August Krickel Special to Free Times\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nOfficer driving truck in deadly beach accident is Horry's longtime beach safety director Suspect in $100K firearm robbery at Palmetto State Armory re-arrested after standoff Carnival's Charleston-based cruise ship gives passengers a 30-minute warning King Street nights: see what happens when 50,000 people pile into Charleston's entertainment district Man hacked co-worker to death with a machete at worksite, N. Charleston police allege How a student ministry leader saved 2 teens from a Folly Beach rip current Activity ramps up in the Atlantic Basin. What does it mean for the Lowcountry? 5 arrested after more than 200 cars take over street near Cherrydale Racial displacement grows in Greenville even as city invests in Black communities Why do police officers drive trucks on the beach? SC woman's death brings calls for change.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nCharleston Scene Charleston's 'Outer Banks' star Madelyn Cline interviews vice president in new video By Kalyn Oyer koyer@postandcourier.com\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two -- again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nBusiness 'Outer Banks,' other SC productions set to 'Take 2' as long Hollywood strike ends By Megan Fernandes mfernandes@postandcourier.com\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford. For a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Acting", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Acting", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/postandcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/3b/13b112b5-a638-5c7c-9e34-331bf96d5176/6674773084a99.image.jpg?crop=1762%2C925%2C0%2C125&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9668644", "eventUri": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.06666666666666665, "wgt": 195, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187594263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:16:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:16:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:14:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/donald-sutherland-obituary-career-mash-hunger-games-b2566129.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland: Chameleonic actor who combined charm with menace", "body": "{{ #verifyErrors }}{{ message }}{{ /verifyErrors }}{{ ^verifyErrors }}Something went wrong. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nWhen Kiefer Sutherland announced the death of his father, Donald Sutherland, at the age 88, he called him \"one of the most important actors in the history of film.\" If the claim sounds hyperbolic, it is borne out by celluloid history. The elder Sutherland's film career began in the early 1960s and spanned seven decades and over 150 features to the present, with his final performance coming in last year's Western series Lawmen: Bass Reeves. His CV includes classics across several genres, including the 1970 anti-war satire MASH, the 1973 thriller Don't Look Now and his more recent appearances in The Hunger Games. At 6ft 4, he was a towering presence on screen and cast a lengthy shadow.\n\nDonald McNichol Sutherland was born in the Canadian east coast seaport of Saint John, New Brunswick on July 17, 1935. His parents were Dorothy and Frederick, who ran the local gas, electricity and bus company. His first word, he once told Esquire, was \"neck\". \"My mother turned around and said, 'What did he say?'\" Sutherland recalled. \"My sister said, 'He said, neck.' My neck was killing me. That was a sign of polio. One leg's a little shorter, but I survived.\" Keen to get involved in the entertainment business, his first job at the age of 14 was working as a DJ for local radio station CKBW.\n\nBy 1952, Sutherland was attending the University of Toronto, where he became a valued member of the UC Follies comedy troupe. He graduated in 1956 with a double major in engineering and drama, but it was clear which half of his degree had excited him most when he moved to the United Kingdom to continue his acting studies at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts. He married his first wife, Lois May Hardwick, in 1959 and the marriage lasted seven years.\n\nSutherland started his career in the theatre and had a handful of minor roles on British television before landing his first film role, playing both a young soldier and an old hag in the 1964 Italian horror The Castle of the Living Dead. Sutherland was so appreciative of the break that in 1966 he named his first son after the producer who hired him, Warren Kiefer.\n\nIn 1967, Sutherland became a Hollywood name following the release of Robert Aldrich's The Dirty Dozen, where Sutherland played a killer opposite Lee Marvin and John Cassavetes. Sutherland told The Guardian in 2005 that he originally had one line in the film until Clint Walker refused to play a scene requiring him to impersonate a general. According to Sutherland, Aldrich, who didn't know his name, turned to him and said, \"You! With the big ears! You do it!\"\n\nThree years later, his star rose still further with appearances in the Gene Wilder comedy Start the Revolution Without Me, and two more war films: Kelly's Heroes, playing the aptly named Sergeant Oddball, and as subversive surgeon \"Hawkeye\" Pierce in Robert Altman's hugely successful counter-culture farce MASH.\n\nSutherland used his rising profile to become a prominent anti-war activist, which made him a target for the US establishment. In 2022, Kiefer Sutherland told The Independent: \"Because of my father's politics, they felt he was a Social Democrat, a socialist, who believed in nationalised health care and large government, and those were not necessarily 'American values'.\"\n\nSutherland's second wife, Shirley Douglas, was also a high-profile campaigner. The daughter of Tommy Douglas, a socialist politician who was the architect of Canada's welfare state, Douglas was both an actor and a civil rights activist who was one of the founders of the fundraising group Friends of the Black Panthers. Documents declassified in 2017 showed that at the CIA's request, Donald Sutherland was placed on an NSA watch-list in the early 1970s.\n\nHe didn't let this unwanted attention deter him from speaking out. In 1971, Sutherland starred in Alan Pakula's thriller Klute opposite Jane Fonda, a fellow anti-war protestor with whom he had a two-year affair as his marriage to Douglas fell apart. In 1972, he co-wrote and co-produced an explosive anti-Vietnam War documentary F.T.A., working with Fonda once again.\n\nThroughout the 1970s, Sutherland starred in a string of films that each broke the mold in different ways. He starred alongside Julie Christie in Nicolas Roeg's chilling horror thriller Don't Look Now in 1973, a film that became as known for an explicit, emotionally tangled sex scene between Sutherland and Christie as it was for its sinister narrative.\n\nIn 2002, Roeg told The Independent that the scene had been inspired by a friend who had lost a child. \"They'd been told to try for another,\" recalled Roeg. \"That very often happens. And we [Donald Sutherland and Julie Christie] talked about that. I think that's why people have made so much of what is usually called the 'love scene' in the movie. Most love scenes are seduction scenes... But these two are in love. They have kids and they're happily married. And this awful thing happens to them, and it's more than they can bear.\"\n\nSutherland went on to work with the great Italian directors Bernardo Bertolucci (playing a Fascist in 1976's 1900) and Federico Fellini (1976's a made-up Lothario in Casanova), but also found time to play a dope-smoking college professor in John Landis's college comedy Animal House in 1978. The same year, he starred in Philip Kaufman's sci-fi horror Invasion of the Body Snatchers. In 1980, Sutherland won widespread acclaim for his portrayal of the long-suffering patriarch in Robert Redford's Oscar-winning Ordinary People, starring opposite Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton. Throughout the 1990s he had a pivotal role in Oliver Stone's provocative JFK (1991) and played a Van Helsing-type hunter in the original film version of Buffy the Vampire Slayer (1992). In 1995 he won both an Emmy and a Golden Globe for his work in the TV movie Citizen X (1995).\n\nFrom 2012, Sutherland became known to a new generation of fans President Snow, the main antagonist of The Hunger Games franchise. He appeared in a total of four films in the franchise, winning plaudits once again. Whether playing a villain, a hero, or an oddball combination of both, Sutherland was able to combine charm with menace in a way few actors can.\n\nIn 2015, at the age of 80, he told the BBC while promoting The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 that he was determined to keep working right to the end. \"It's a passionate endeavor,\" said Sutherland. \"Retirement for actors is spelt 'DEATH'.\"", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": {"uri": "8187641768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:01:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:01:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:00:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/entertainment/entertainment-news/2024/06/20/ron-howard-helen-mirren-son-kiefer-pay-tribute-to-donald-sutherland/", "title": "Ron Howard, Helen Mirren, son Kiefer pay tribute to Donald Sutherland - Medicine Hat News", "body": "FILE - Donald Sutherland, left, and his son Kiefer Sutherland pose for a portrait in Los Angeles to promote the film \"Forsaken.\" Donald Sutherland, the towering Canadian actor whose career spanned \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died at 88. (Photo by Matt Sayles/Invision/AP, File)Famous fans, colleagues and family pay tribute to actor Donald Sutherland, the star of \"M.A.S.H.\"\u009d \"Klute\"\u009d and \"The Hunger Games\"\u009d who died at age 88. \"I was blessed to direct him in #Backdraft. One of the most intelligent, interesting & engrossing film actors of all time. Incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence.\"\u009d - Ron Howard, on X. \"Donald Sutherland was one of the smartest actors I ever worked with. He had a wonderful enquiring brain, and a great knowledge on a wide variety of subjects. He combined this great intelligence with a deep sensitivity, and with a seriousness about his profession as an actor. This all made him into the legend of film that he became.\"\u009d - Actor Helen Mirren, who co-starred with Sutherland in 2017's \"The Leisure Seekers,\"\u009d in a statement. \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\u009d - Actor and Sutherland's son, Kiefer Sutherland, on X. \"He starred in two of my very favourite and most influential films - \"~Don't Look Now' and the 1978 \"~Invasion Of The Bodysnatchers'. But that is just the tip of the iceberg in terms of his legendary filmography. He was a funny, laconic, but also intense and dramatic presence in so many memorable movies.\"\u009d - Director Edgar Wright, on Instagram. \"aww man. farewell, Donald Sutherland.\"\u009d - Actor Elijah Wood on X. \"We lost a legend, a journeyman actor that created unique and believable characters every time he stepped in front of the camera.\"\u009d - Jon Cassar, who directed both Donald and Kiefer Sutherland in 2015's \"Forsaken,\"\u009d via X.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "canadian_press@medicinehatnews.com", "name": "Canadian Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Sutherland", "type": "person", "score": "eng-9668644", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1764705882352942, "wgt": 195, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8187562863", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:47:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:47:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:46:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/movies-tv/donald-sutherland-the-towering-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games/article_0e32bc47-140a-508f-a797-d1626edd9bfb.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nInvestigator tracked Kim Gardner to health clinic as St. Louis prosecutor's office crashed Here are 13 must-visit restaurants in the St. Louis area from Ian Froeb's newsletter New Channel 32? Established stations 11, 5, BSM? Sports TV intrigue continues: Media Views Cardinals broadcaster Bally Sports 'stuck in the middle' in dispute over contracts Hazelwood woman killed by tree branch in trimming accident UFL officials say they expect to grow after inaugural season, capped by Birmingham's title Police shoot, kill teen they say led them on chase and pointed gun in north St. Louis A sneak peek at St. Louis Zoo's new park, where animals are already busy Sam Page offered job to St. Louis County council candidate, asked her to weigh quitting race St. Louis paying 'guaranteed basic income' to 540 families is under fire in lawsuit St. Louis to pay homeless to clean streets and pick up trash The 'Bad Dad Joke House' brings laughter to St. Louis Cardinals, Andre Pallante left with plenty of what ifs after 5-1 loss to the Cubs How to watch Sunday's Cardinals-Cubs game, which airs exclusively on Roku McClellan: A simple life until a glitch got in the way\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nBorn in St. John, New Brunswick, Donald McNichol Sutherland was the son of a salesman and a mathematics teacher. Raised in Nova Scotia, he was a disc jockey with his own radio station at the age of 14.\n\n\"When I was 13 or 14, I really thought everything I felt was wrong and dangerous, and that God was going to kill me for it,\" Sutherland told The New York Times in 1981. \"My father always said, 'Keep your mouth shut, Donnie, and maybe people will think you have character.'\"\n\nSutherland began as an engineering student at the University of Toronto but switched to English and started acting in school theatrical productions. While studying in Toronto, he met Lois Hardwick, an aspiring actress. They married in 1959, but divorced seven years later.\n\nAfter graduating in 1956, Sutherland attended the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts to study acting. Sutherland began appearing in West End plays and British television. After a move to Los Angeles, he continued to bounce around until a series of war films changed his trajectory.\n\nHis first American film was \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), in which he played Vernon Pinkley, the officer-impersonating psychopathic. 1970 saw the release of both the World War II yarn \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"M.A.S.H.,\" an acclaimed smash hit that catapulted Sutherland to stardom.\n\n\"There is more challenge in character roles,\" Sutherland told The Washington Post in 1970. \"There's longevity. A good character actor can show a different face in every film and not bore the public.\"\n\nIf Sutherland had had his way, Altman would have been fired from \"M.A.S.H.\" He and co-star Elliott Gould were unhappy with the director's unorthodox, improvisational style and fought to have him replaced. But the film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message. Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theater Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two -- again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford. For a career launched by \"M.A.S.H.\" it was a fitting, if ironic bookend.\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-396296349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:42:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:42:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:34:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/1774631-donald-sutherland-kiefer-sutherland", "title": "Donald Sutherland Passes Away, Kiefer Sutherland Issues Statement", "body": "Legendary and beloved actor Donald Sutherland has passed away at the age of 88 following a battle with what is being described as a long illness.\n\nSutherland began his acting career in 1960 and has appeared in countless high-profile roles, including starring in films like The Dirty Dozen, MAS*H, Don't Look Now, JFK, The Italian Job, Pride & Prejudice, and most notably for audiences now, as President Snow in the Hunger Games franchise.\n\nThroughout his career, Sutherland has received tons of accolades for his work. In 1995, he won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Limited Series or Movie for his work in Citizen X. He's also won two Golden Globes for his roles in Citizen X and Path to War. In 2017, he received an honorary Academy Award for his longstanding career and work.\n\nWhat did Kiefer Sutherland say about Donald's passing?\n\nIn a statement on Sutherland's passing, Donald's son Kiefer -- also an accomplished actor -- confirmed the news on social media and praised his father for being an actor who was \"never daunted by a role, good, bad, or ugly.\"\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. A life well lived.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSutherland was 88 years old.\n\nBorn in Saint John, N.B. on July 17, 1935, Sutherland graduated with a double degree in engineering and drama from the University of Toronto.\n\nHis career started on the stage, but he soon starred in many memorable movie roles, including Hawkeye Pierce in \"M*A*S*H,\" Matthew Bennell in \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers,\" and more recently, President Snow in the \"Hunger Games\" franchise.\n\nIn 2000, he was honoured with the Governor General's Performing Arts Award. He also was named an officer of the Order of Canada in 1978. He was given a star on Canada's Walk of Fame in 2000.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAs the condolences pour in on social media, many are remembering their favourite movie role that Sutherland brought {"uri": "8187608340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:28:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:28:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:27:53Z", "dataType": "news", enduring legacy of playing both heroes and villains", "body": "Sutherland featured in The Hunger Games film franchise as dictator president Coriolanus Snow.\n\nCanadian actor Donald Sutherland has died aged 88 following \"a long illness\", his agent confirmed to the PA news agency.\n\nHe rose to fame after starring in films such as The Dirty Dozen (1967) and Kelly's Heroes (1970).\n\nHe is perhaps best known as the womanising Captain Benjamin Franklin \"Hawkeye\" Pierce Jr in the 1970 film version of M*A*S*H, and would eventually becoming a leading campaigner against war.\n\nMore recently, Sutherland featured in The Hunger Games film franchise as dictator president Coriolanus Snow, and as a judge in the 2023 TV show, Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\n\nThe actor had infantile paralysis and rheumatic fever before almost dying from spinal meningitis as a child.\n\nAfter graduating from university, he moved to Britain to study at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (Lamda), and began to land small roles in British films and TV shows.\n\nIn 1967, following a second appearance alongside Roger Moore in The Saint, Sutherland was handed the role of Vernon L Pinkley in The Dirty Dozen - a box office hit.\n\nHis later films included The Eagle Has Landed (1976), Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1978), National Lampoon's Animal House (1978), The First Great Train Robbery (1978) and JFK (1991).\n\nSutherland won a Golden Globe along with an Emmy Award for the mini-series Citizen X (1995), and another gong for the television movie Path To War (2002).\n\nSutherland's son, Kiefer, called his father \"one of the most important actors in the history of film\" following his death.\n\nIn 2019, Kiefer said he broke down in tears after discovering his father's acting work.\n\nThe actor said he was unaware of his father's career, and the \"extraordinary\" work he had done until he was old enough to watch his films.\n\nEqually adept at playing heroes and villains, Sutherland portrayed President Snow, the main antagonist of The Hunger Games film franchise, beginning in 2012.\n\nIn 2017, it was announced that Sutherland would receive an Honorary Oscar, from the Academy.\n\nSutherland was made an Officer of the Order of Canada in 1978, promoted to Companion of the Order of Canada in 2019.\n\nSutherland was about to publish his memoir, Made Up, But Still True, later this year, which was set to explore \"an unfiltered account of his memories of his life\" from how life-changing a role M*A*S*H had been along with \"his far too many brushes with death\".\n\nSutherland married three times.\n\nHe is survived by his wife, Francine Racette, and five children, including actors Kiefer, Rossif and Angus.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", {"uri": "8187554657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:39:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:39:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:38:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/film/2024/06/20/actor-donald-sutherland-star-of-hunger-games-and-dont-look-now-dies-aged-88/", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland, star of Hunger Games and Don't Look Now, dies aged 88", "body": "Sutherland's acting career spanned six decades and more than 190 films and TV shows\n\nHis acting career spanned six decades and included starring in such highly acclaimed films as Don't Look Now, M*A*S*H and The Hunger Games.\n\nHis son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, shared the news on X (formerly Twitter).\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nA prolific actor who appeared in more than 190 films and TV shows, Sutherland embodied an off-kilter appeal that served him brilliantly in a series of classic 1970s movies, which gradually evolved into a veteran gravitas in the latter stages of his career.\n\nHe did not win a major award for any of his film roles (and was never nominated for a conventional Oscar), but did win two Golden Globes for best supporting actor for the TV movies Citizen X (in 1996) and Path to War (in 2003). Sutherland received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nBorn in Canada in 1935, Sutherland studied engineering and drama at the University of Toronto, and opted to move to London in 1957 to join an acting class at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (Lamda).\n\nAfter a series of small roles on British TV shows including Man of the World, The Saint and The Avengers, and films such as the Hammer horror film Fanatic and the Amicus anthology Dr Terror's House of Horrors, Sutherland was cast in the action film The Dirty Dozen, as one of a group of prisoners trained up for a dangerous mission during the second world war.\n\nThe Dirty Dozen was a hit and Sutherland then appeared in two more war films with anti-heroic sensibilities: the massively influential Korean War comedy M*A*S*H, in which Sutherland played rule-bending surgeon \"Hawkeye\" Pierce, and Kelly's Heroes, as a whacked-out tank commander who joins Clint Eastwood's bank robbery.\n\nWhile working on the latter film, in 1968, Sutherland said he \"died for a few seconds\" as a result of contracting meningitis.\n\nSutherland's work became more radical: he played the title role in Klute, opposite Jane Fonda's sex worker, as a detective investigating a murder in the first of director Alan J Pakula's so-called \"paranoia trilogy\" and appeared with Fonda in the anti-Vietnam War documentary FTA.\n\nIn 2017, declassified documents showed that Sutherland, a vocal anti-war activist, was on the National Security Agency's \"watch list\" between 1971 and 1973.\n\nSutherland then embarked on a wide variety of roles as he attained leading man status.\n\nIn 1973 he starred opposite Julie Christie in Don't Look Now, the Nicolas Roeg-directed psychological horror, which contained a then-infamous sex scene, intercut with Christie and Sutherland getting dressed, which Sutherland was repeatedly forced to deny was authentic.\n\nHe then starred in Federico Fellini's Casanova, played murderous fascist Attila Melanchini in Bernardo Bertolucci's epic 1900, and featured alongside Michael Caine as a duplicitous IRA man in war thriller The Eagle Has Landed.\n\nHe played a dope-smoking professor in National Lampoon's Animal House, and fought \"pod people\" in a remake of the horror sci-fi Invasion of the Body Snatchers - giving rise to a popular gif of the film's final moments.\n\nIn 1980 he led an impressive ensemble cast in Robert Redford's directorial debut, Ordinary People, after Gene Hackman had dropped out of the role.\n\nIn the 1980s and 90s Sutherland was mostly cast in character roles, including an art dealer in Six Degrees of Separation, the mysterious Mr \"X\" in Oliver Stone's JFK who suggests there is a high-level coup inside the US government, and slayer trainer Merrick Jamison-Smythe in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer movie starring Kristy Swanson.\n\nSutherland also had prominent roles in the legal thriller A Time to Kill (alongside his son Kiefer), the astronaut drama Space Cowboys and the Jane Austen adaptation Pride & Prejudice.\n\nIn 2012 his role as the villainous President Snow in The Hunger Games introduced him to a new generation of filmgoers. He also starred in Stephen King horror Mr Harrigan's Phone and disaster thriller Moonfall in 2022.\n\nMost recently, he had a recurring role in TV series Lawmen: Bass Reeves with David Oyelowo.\n\nSutherland was married three times, to Lois Hardwick between 1959 and 1966, Shirley Douglas (1966-1970) and Francine Racette, whom he married in 1972. - Guardian", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187461708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:24:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:24:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:24:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/film/article/2024/jun/20/actor-donald-sutherland-dies-hunger-games-dont-look-now", "title": "Donald Sutherland, Don't Look Now and Hunger Games actor, dies aged 88", "body": "The prolific actor appeared in more than 190 films and TV shows and was a vocal anti-war activist\n\nDonald Sutherland, whose acting career spanned six decades including highly acclaimed films such as Don't Look Now, M*A*S*H and The Hunger Games, has died aged 88.\n\nHe died in Miami after a long illness, confirmed by his representatives.\n\nA prolific actor who appeared in more than 190 films and TV shows, Sutherland embodied an off-kilter appeal that served him brilliantly in a series of classic 1970s movies, which gradually evolved into a veteran gravitas in the latter stages of his career. He did not win a major award for any of his film roles (and was never nominated for a conventional Oscar), but did win two Golden Globes for best supporting actor for the TV movies Citizen X (in 1996) and Path to War (in 2003). Sutherland received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nBorn in Canada in 1935, Sutherland studied engineering and drama at the University of Toronto, and opted to move to London in 1957 to join an acting class at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (Lamda). After a series of small roles on British TV shows including Man of the World, The Saint and The Avengers, and films such as Hammer horror Fanatic and the Amicus anthology Dr Terror's House of Horrors, Sutherland was cast in action film The Dirty Dozen, as one of a group of prisoners trained up for a dangerous mission during the second world war.\n\nThe Dirty Dozen was a hit and Sutherland then appeared in two more war films with anti-heroic sensibilities: the massively influential Korean war comedy M*A*S*H, in which Sutherland played rule-bending surgeon \"Hawkeye\" Pierce, and Kelly's Heroes, as a whacked-out tank commander who joins Clint Eastwood's bank robbery. (While working on the latter film, in 1968, Sutherland said he \"died for a few seconds\" as a result of contracting meningitis.)\n\nSutherland's work became more radical: he played the title role in Klute, opposite Jane Fonda's sex worker, as a detective investigating a murder in the first of director Alan J Pakula's so-called \"paranoia trilogy\" and appeared with Fonda in the anti-Vietnam war documentary FTA. In 2017, declassified documents showed that Sutherland, a vocal anti-war activist, was on the National Security Agency's \"watch list\" between 1971 and 1973.\n\nSutherland then embarked on a wide variety of roles as he attained leading man status. In 1973 he starred opposite Julie Christie in Don't Look Now, the Nicolas Roeg-directed psychological horror, which contained a then-infamous sex scene, intercut with Christie and Sutherland getting dressed, which Sutherland was repeatedly forced to deny was authentic. He then starred in Federico Fellini's Casanova, played murderous fascist Attila Melanchini in Bernardo Bertolucci's epic 1900, and featured alongside Michael Caine as a duplicitous IRA man in war thriller The Eagle Has Landed. He played a dope-smoking professor in National Lampoon's Animal House, and fought \"pod people\" in a remake of horror-sci-fi Invasion of the Body Snatchers - giving rise to a popular gif of the film's final moments. In 1980 he led an impressive ensemble cast in Robert Redford's directorial debut, Ordinary People, after Gene Hackman had dropped out of the role.\n\nIn the 1980s and 90s Sutherland was mostly cast in character roles, including an art dealer in Six Degrees of Separation, the mysterious Mr \"X\" in Oliver Stone's JFK who suggests there is a high-level coup inside the US government, and slayer trainer Merrick Jamison-Smythe in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer movie starring Kristy Swanson. Sutherland also had prominent roles in legal thriller A Time to Kill (alongside his son Kiefer), astronaut drama Space Cowboys, and Jane Austen adaptation Pride & Prejudice.\n\nIn 2012 his role as the villainous President Snow in The Hunger Games introduced him to a new generation of filmgoers, and he appeared in all four films in the series.\n\nSutherland was married three times, to Lois Hardwick between 1959 and 1966, Shirley Douglas (1966-1970), and Francine Racette, who he married in 1972.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": {"uri": "8187607317", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:27:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:27:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:26:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://theblast.com/606615/donald-sutherland-tributes-ben-stiller-kiefer-sutherland-more/", "title": "Donald Sutherland Tributes: Ben Stiller, Kiefer Sutherland, & More", "body": "Donald Sutherland, best known for his work in \"A Time to Kill\" (1996) and \"The Hunger Games\" franchise (2012-2015), has passed away at the age of 88.\n\nAfter the news of Donald Sutherland's passing broke, many celebrities, including his son Kiefer Sutherland, paid tribute to the late actor.\n\nSutherland rose to fame in the 1960s and 1970s with notable performances in projects like \"The Odd Man\" (1960), \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967), and \"MAS*H\" (1970), where he played Captain Benjamin Franklin \"Hawkeye\" Pierce.\n\nHe went on to star in films such as \"Don't Look Now\" (1973), \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" (1978), \"Ordinary People\" (1980), \"JFK\" (1991), \"A Time to Kill\" (1996), and \"The Hunger Games\" series (2012-2015), where he played President Snow.\n\nThe late actor won a Golden Globe for \"Path to War\" and an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his performance in the miniseries \"Citizen X.\"\n\nThe cause of death is not yet known.\n\nShortly after the news broke, Kiefer Sutherland, Donald's son and \"24\" actor, shared a statement.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote on X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nHelen Mirren paid tribute to Sutherland in a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, \"Donald Sutherland was one of the smartest actors I ever worked with. He had a wonderful enquiring brain, and a great knowledge on a wide variety of subjects.\"\n\nShe added, \"He combined this great intelligence with a deep sensitivity, and with a seriousness about his profession as an actor. This all made him into the legend of film that he became. He was my colleague and became my friend. I will miss his presence in this world.\"\n\nJames Dreyfus, known for his role as Constable Kevin Goody in \"The Thin Blue Line,\" paid tribute to the late actor in an X post.\n\n\"This actor! This AMAZING actor. A staple in my life through incredible performances 'Ordinary People,' 'Don't Look Now,' 'Klute,' 'Die! Die! My Darling!,' Invasion of The Body Snatchers,' etc etc,\" he wrote. \"Quirky, versatile, always honest & brilliant. Wonderful. RIP Donald Sutherland.\"\n\nTurner Classic Movies also released a statement. \"We are deeply saddened to hear the loss of actor & activist Donald Sutherland,\" the company wrote. \"A versatile performer with unforgettable characters, his contributions across genres and generations will continue to inspire storytellers of all ages.\"\n\nActor Ben Stiller responded to Kiefer's statement, writing, \"Sending love and so much respect.\"\n\nActress Kristy Swanson shared, \"My heart is with you Kiefer. He was and will always be a beautiful man. May he rest in peace and love.\"\n\nHenry Winkler, known for his role in \"Happy Days,\" wrote, \"Stacey and I send you our deepest sympathies .. Your dad was indeed singular . Warmly , Henry.\"\n\nActor and filmmaker Edgar Wright shared a lengthy statement on X, paying tribute to the late actor.\n\n\"RIP the great Donald Sutherland, a favorite actor and always fascinating screen presence,\" he began. \"He starred in two of my very favorite and most influential films - 'Don't Look Now' and the 1978 'Invasion Of The Bodysnatchers.' But that is just the tip of the iceberg in terms of his legendary filmography.\"\n\n\"A funny, laconic, but also intense and dramatic presence in so many memorable movies, starting with his break-through in 'The Dirty Dozen', and then on an incredible run in the 70's, 80's and beyond with 'M*A*S*H', 'Kelly's Heroes', 'Little Murders', 'Klute', 'Don't Look Now', 'The Day Of The Locust', 'Ordinary People' and 'JFK', among many others,\" Wright added.\n\n\"I even adore his very early appearances in 'Dr. Terror's House Of Horrors' and 'The World Ten Times Over', as well as his very silly cameo in 'Kentucky Fried Movie'. I know many of you following me will feel the same way about this great screen legend's passing, so please list your favorite Donald Sutherland films.\"\n\nHe concluded, \"So sorry to see you go Donald, but what a legacy you leave behind.\"\n\nRon Howard, director of \"Backdraft,\" expressed how talented Donald Sutherland was and what an honor it was to work alongside the actor.\n\n\"I was blessed to direct him in 'Backdraft,'\" Howard said after hearing the news. \"One of the most intelligent, interesting & engrossing film actors of all time. Incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence.\"\n\nSutherland is survived by his wife Francine Racette; sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer; daughter Rachel; and four grandchildren. {"uri": "8187551082", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:36:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:36:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:35:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://celebrity.nine.com.au/latest/donald-sutherland-death-veteran-actor-known-for-roles-in-mash-klute-and-the-hunger-games-dead-aged-88/f7b832db-5ca0-4c3c-a254-7f166c82c012", "title": "M*A*S*H and Hunger Games star Donald Sutherland dead at 88", "body": "\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer Sutherland, Donald Sutherland's son, wrote in a post on Instagram on Thursday.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nTall and known for his intensity on screen, Sutherland earned an Emmy for his role as a Soviet official in the fact-based HBO movie Citizen X, as well as a pair of Golden Globes.\n\nHis career spanned more than 50 years and 140 film credits, including recent roles in the limited series Trust as oil tycoon J Paul Getty and HBO's The Undoing.\n\nSutherland's big break came when he was cast as one of The Dirty Dozen in the star-studded 1967 film, which became a major hit.\n\nHe followed that with another war movie, Kelly's Heroes, before playing the wisecracking doctor Hawkeye Pierce in the movie version of M*A*S*H and opposite Jane Fonda in her Oscar-winning portrayal of a high-class \"call girl\" in the crime mystery Klute.\n\nFonda and Sutherland also had an off-screen relationship around the time that they made the film.\n\nReflecting his ability to play all sorts of roles, Sutherland's 1970s resume included a chillingly effective remake of the horror film Invasion of the Body Snatchers and a memorable turn as a pot-smoking professor in the National Lampoon comedy Animal House.\n\nHe also starred opposite Julie Christie in director Nicolas Roeg's Don't Look Now, a 1973 movie that became somewhat notorious for the raciness of its sex scene, which had to be trimmed in order to avoid an X rating.\n\nA steady stream of roles followed in a wide variety of genres, from a small but pivotal part in Oliver Stone's JFK to supporting work in Ordinary People - which won the Oscar for best picture - Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Backdraft and The Italian Job.\n\nSutherland also starred as the legendary lover for director Federico Fellini in Fellini's Casanova. Many younger filmgoers, meanwhile, will likely remember him as the evil president in The Hunger Games movies.\n\nBorn in Saint John, New Brunswick, Sutherland endured several bouts of ill health as a child, including polio. He attended the University of Toronto, where he studied engineering before gravitating toward drama and appearing on stage, graduating with degrees in both.\n\nThe 193-centimetre actor met his first wife, Lois Hardwick, in college, and the two married in 1959. He moved to London, where he found some stage work, and eventually to Hollywood in the 1960s, where Dirty Dozen and M*A*S*H put him on the map.\n\nIn the mid-1960s he divorced, marrying actress Shirley Douglas, whom he met while filming the horror movie Castle of the Living Dead.\n\nThey had two children, actor Kiefer and Rachel, who also works in film as a post-production supervisor. That marriage also ended in divorce, and in 1972 Sutherland wed his third wife, actress Francine Racette, with whom he had three sons.\n\nIn a 2020 conversation with The Undoing costar Hugh Grant for Interview magazine, Sutherland said that he was always so nervous when a movie began shooting that he threw up the night before. He also discussed subtly altering his dialogue, as he put it, to \"try to make the lines that I've been given fit my mouth\".\n\nSutherland appeared in three films with son Kiefer, beginning with the 24 star's small part in the comedy-drama Max Dugan Returns in 1983, followed by the John Grisham adaptation A Time to Kill. The two didn't perform in a scene together, however, until the 2016 western Forsaken.\n\n\"It was a memory and an experience that I will treasure for the rest of my life,\" Kiefer Sutherland told Good Morning America at the time, saying he spent years looking for something that the two could do together.\n\nIn 2019, Reuters asked Sutherland what advice he would give young actors.\n\n\"Try and be as truthful as you possibly can, read, read a lot, learn, memorise things, enjoy your artistry, study dancing, be a circus performer, learn how to juggle, so many things, but mostly you have to observe,\" he responded.\n\nSutherland received an honorary award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences board in 2017 and was honored with the Order of Canada.\n\nIn 2022, Sutherland appeared alongside Halle Berry and Patrick Wilson in the space thriller Moonfall and in the Roku TV mini series Swimming with Sharks.", "source": {"uri": "celebrity.nine.com.au", "dataType": "news", "https://imageresizer.static9.net.au/7qjaNin59h4cneq3i4pLoTlKBH4=/0x40:1024x616/1200x628/smart/https%3A%2F%2Fprod.static9.net.au%2Ffs%2F1e5a5472-08f5-4a9a-b17a-e14026698df7", "originalArticle": null, {"uri": "8187652233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:11:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:11:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:10:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/us-celebrity-news/inside-donald-sutherlands-impressive-career-33075919", "title": "Donald Sutherland's impressive career after Hunger Games actor dies at age 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland left behind a lasting legacy after passing at 88\n\nLegendary Hollywood star Donald Sutherland, who was never nominated for an Oscar despite a stellar career, has died after a long illness.\n\nThe 88-year-old actor passed away yesterday (Thurs) in Miami, Florida. Confirming his death, his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, paid a moving tribute.\n\nHe said: \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"No details of his illness were given.\"\n\nFor all the latest on news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US.\n\nREAD MORE: Inside Donald Sutherland's marriage as 'dumb mistakes' led him to wife Francine\n\nSutherland never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" he said in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom - time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nA major figure in the New Hollywood of the 1970s who had worked steadily since, Sutherland was long considered among the best actors never to have been nominated for an Academy Award, despite appearing in several films that won the biggest of them.\n\nHe was bestowed with an honourary Oscar in 2017. He also has an Emmy and two Golden Globes. Tall at 6ft 4in with shock white hair and dropping piercing blue eyes, he was difficult to miss whether he played a zany oddball, an icy tyrant or a sadistic villain.\n\nHe often recalled that while growing up in eastern Canada, he once asked his mother if he was good-looking, only to be told, \"No, but your face has a lot of character.\"\n\nHe recounted how he was once rejected for a film role by a producer who said: \"This part calls for a guy-next-door type. You don't look like you've lived next door to anyone.\"\n\nHowever, it failed to stop Sutherland from finding global success, seeing him star in nearly 200 film or television roles.\n\nBorn in Saint John, a small fishing village in New Brunswick, Canada, he barely survived a series of childhood diseases, including infantile paralysis, rheumatoid fever and spinal meningitis. He said the town had only 5,000 residents, and \"that was when the train rolled into town.\"\n\nOne of four children, his mother Dorothy was a mathematician and his father Frederick was a salesman. From an early age, Sutherland displayed a keen interest in acting, a passion that would guide him throughout his life.\n\nHe attended Victoria University, an affiliated college of the University of Toronto, where he initially studied engineering but later switched to drama. His love of acting began in a Nova Scotia movie theatre when he was a teen, but his film aspirations seemed too lofty a pursuit, so he tried his luck in theatre instead.\n\n\"It's not that theatre was my first love. My first love was just to be an actor,\" he said.\n\n\"I was kind of dumb and cowish, and I didn't think movies were something I could ever be part of. I don't know why I presumed that the theatre would be. It was more ordinary, I suppose.\"\n\nHis academic journey took him to the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art in 1956, but he dropped out after nine months because he disliked its psychological approach to acting.\n\nHe went on to tour with various repertory companies and appeared in several BBC television productions, including bit parts in The Saint and The Avengers.\n\nIn 1966, Sutherland married Shirley Douglas, with whom he had two children before they divorced - twins Rachel, a production manager, and Stand By Me star Kiefer. Sutherland broke through in Hollywood with a small role in the 1967 Second World War classic The Dirty Dozen using a clip of his appearance on The Saint to land a role.\n\n\"I was a glorified extra in The Dirty Dozen,\" Sutherland once said. \"They hired legitimate actors to play the bottom six of the dozen.\"\n\nHis breakthrough came in 1970 with Robert Altman's satirical war film, M.A.S.H., where he portrayed the cocky surgeon Captain \"Hawkeye\" Pierce.\n\nThe film caught on beyond anyone's expectations and Sutherland identified personally with its anti-war message.Outspoken against the Vietnam War, Sutherland, actress Jane Fonda and others founded the Free Theatre Associates in 1971. Banned by the Army because of their political views, they performed in venues near military bases in Southeast Asia in 1973.\n\nAfter then playing neurotic platoon commander Oddball in Kelly's Heroes, the roles catapulted Sutherland to international fame.They established him as a leading man capable of comedic and dramatic performances.\n\nThroughout the 1970s and 1980s, he continued to build an impressive body of work. His role as the chilling, emotionless hitman in Klute, in which he starred opposite Fonda, showcased his range and depth as an actor. Two years later, in Don't Look Now, the actor delivered a haunting performance that remains one of the most critically acclaimed of his career.\n\nHis portrayal of the benevolent yet enigmatic John Baxter in Nicolas Roeg's supernatural thriller is often cited as a masterclass in subtle, understated acting. From the dystopian sci-fi classic Invasion of the Body Snatchers in 1978 to his role as the authoritarian fascist in 1900 and his comedic turn in Animal House, Sutherland continually defied typecasting.\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down - but still eccentric - parts in Robert Redford's Ordinary People and Oliver Stone's JFK. His ability to embody such a wide array of characters made him one of his generation's most respected and sought-after actors.\n\nIn the 1990s and 2000s, the star continued to deliver memorable performances in both film and television. More lately, his role as the ruthless President Snow in The Hunger Games series introduced him to a new generation of fans. He brought complexity to the character, transforming what could have been a one-dimensional villain into a nuanced and formidable antagonist.\n\nSutherland's work in television was equally impressive. His portrayal of the enigmatic Mr X in the hit series The X-Files and his Emmy-winning performance in the HBO film Citizen X demonstrated his enduring appeal and adaptability.\n\n\"It's characters who make pictures,\" he said in 1995. \"Essentially my job is to provide information about them.\"\n\nDespite his lengthy career, Sutherland had a dearth of accolades, winning but a few major acting awards for his performances - an Emmy and a Golden Globe for the 1995 miniseries Citizen X and another Globe for 2002's Path to War. But the lack of awards didn't trouble him.\n\nHe recalled: \"My career has been all downhill since the age of 11. I did my first play, The Male Animal, at Toronto University's Hart House Theatre.\n\n\"The audience laughed and applauded when I came on, they applauded when I went off, and they applauded when I came on again. I've never had it as good since.\"\n\nWithin minutes of the news of his death, tributes began to pour in.\n\nHollywood director Ron Howard wrote: \"I was blessed to direct him in Backdraft. One of the most intelligent, interesting ad engrossing film actors of all time. Incredible range, creative courage and dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence.\"\n\nPiers Morgan added: \"One of my all-time favourite actors who played so many great roles. What a sad loss.\"\n\nBeyond his acting, Sutherland was devoted to his family. He married his first wife, Lois Hardwick, in 1959, but the marriage ended in divorce. After wedding Shirley Douglas, the daughter of Canadian political icon Tommy Douglas, the couple had two twins Rachel and Kiefer, before their divorce in 1970. Sutherland married Francine Racette in 1972, and they had three sons: Roeg, Rossif, and Angus.\n\nHis children have followed in his footsteps, making their own marks in the entertainment industry, particularly Kiefer, who has achieved global fame with his roles.\n\nSutherland's dedication to acting was matched by his commitment to various philanthropic endeavours. He was a vocal advocate for numerous causes, including environmental conservation, human rights, and healthcare reform.\n\nThroughout his career, numerous awards and honours recognised his contributions to the arts and his support for emerging talent. Despite his star status and career demands, Sutherland remained humble. He was known for his humility, warmth, and wit, which endeared him to colleagues and fans alike.\n\nHe is survived by his wife Francine Racette, sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer and daughter Rachel. The star had four grandchildren.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "christopher_bucktin@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Christopher Bucktin", {"uri": "8187594716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:15:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:15:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:14:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.cjme.com/2024/06/20/legendary-canadian-actor-donald-sutherland-dead-at-88/", "title": "Legendary Canadian actor Donald Sutherland dead at 88", "body": "New Brunswick-born actor Donald Sutherland has died at the age of 88. His son Kiefer Sutherland, also a well-regarded Hollywood actor, made the announcement Thursday on social media.\n\nSutherland was known for his starring roles in films like 'The Dirty Dozen,' 'M*A*S*H,' 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers,' 'Animal House' and 'The Hunger Games,\" as well as for his distinctive baritone voice and six-foot-four height.\n\nIn a social media post, Kiefer said his father was \"one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" who was \"never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly.\"\n\nDespite appearing in more than 100 films, many critically acclaimed, Sutherland was never nominated for an Academy Award, though he did receive an honourary Oscar in 2017.\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that,\" Keifer added. \"A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland was an officer of the Order of Canada and he spent time in Saskatchewan during the filming of 1974's 'Alien Thunder,' in which he played an RCMP officer. Filming took place in Saskatoon, Battleford and Duck Lake.\n\nREAD MORE:\n\nIt was on the set of 'Alien Thunder' that Sutherland met his third wife, Canadian actor Francine Racette. Previously, he was married to Shirley Douglas, the daughter of former Saskatchewan NDP Premier Tommy Douglas.\n\nSutherland leaves behind five children, including actors Kiefer, Rossif and Angus He starred in more than 200 movies and TV shows.\n\nAcclaimed veteran actor Donald Sutherland, famous for his roles in \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Ordinary People,\" and \"The Hunger Games\" among more than 200 TV shows and movies, died Thursday in Miami. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" his son, fellow actor Kiefer Sutherland posted to Instagram. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film.\n\n\"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" he said.\n\nThe Canadian actor disappeared into a wide variety of roles throughout his lengthy and prolific career, becoming the wise-cracking Dr. Hawkeye Pierce in the \"M*A*S*H\" movie, a detective in \"Klute\" alongside Jane Fonda, a pod person in the 1978 horror remake \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers,\" a convicted felon in \"The Dirty Dozen,\" a pyromaniac in Ron Howard's \"Backdraft,\" a vampire slayer's watcher in the \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer\" movie, an 18th-century Venetian explorer in 1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\" with director Frederico Fellini, a pot-smoking professor in \"Animal House,\" a grieving father in \"Ordinary People,\" a legendary safecracker in the 2003 remake of \"The Italian Job,\" and the authoritarian villain President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise, among many others.\n\nDirector Ron Howard praised Sutherland on X, formerly Twitter, Thursday, calling him \"one of the most intelligent, interesting & engrossing film actors of all time. Incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence.\"\n\nAmazingly, Sutherland never received even a single Academy Award nomination, although he received an Honorary Award in 2017. He did win an Emmy and Golden Globe for his work in \"Citizen X\" and a Golden Globe for \"Path to War.\"\n\nSutherland is survived by his wife Francine Racette, his sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer, and his daughter Rachel.\n\nSutherland was often spotted in the area at arts events and local venues. {"uri": "2024-06-396286483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:31:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:31:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:24:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://toofab.com/2024/06/20/donald-sutherland-dead-stars-pay-tribute-hunger-games-mash-star/", "title": "Donald Sutherland Dead at 88, Stars Pay Tribute to Hunger Games & MASH Actor", "body": "Hollywood is mourning the death of legendary film and TV actor Donald Sutherland, who passed on Thursday at the age of 88.\n\nAccording to TMZ, his talent agency, CAA, announced the news of his death on Thursday, sharing that the Canadian actor -- who amassed nearly 200 acting credits throughout his career -- away in Miami, Florida after battling a long, undisclosed illness. The actor's son, Kiefer Sutherland, also confirmed his father's passing on social media.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer, 57, wrote alongside a black-and-white throwback photo of himself nd his late father. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nDuring his over 70-year career, Sutherland appeared in several dozen films, including The Hunger Games franchise, Pride & Prejudice, Ordinary People, M*A*S*H, Animal House, and Klute, and a handful of television series, such as Citizen X, Uprising, and Path to War.\n\nHe won a Primetime Emmy Award for his role in Citizen X (1995), and a Golden Globe for 2002's Path to War. While Sutherland never won an Academy Award or received a nomination, he was awarded an Honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nIn addition to Kiefer, Sutherland is also survived by his wife Francine Racette, his sons, Roeg, Rossif, and Angus, his daughter Rachel, and four grandchildren.\n\nFollowing the news of Sutherland's passing, stars took to social media to pay tribute.\n\n\"#RIPDonaldSutherland. I was blessed to direct him in #Backdraft. One of the most intelligent, interesting & engrossing film actors of all time,\" filmmaker Ron Howard wrote on X, formerly Twitter. Incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence.\n\nFilmmaker Edgar Wright wrote a lengthy message on X, calling Sutherland \"a favorite actor and [an] always fascinating screen presence\" as well as a \"great screen legend.\" He also listed his favorite Sutherland films, along with many other standouts in his long-spanning career.\n\n\"[It] is just the tip of the iceberg in terms of his legendary filmography; a funny, laconic, but also intense and dramatic presence in so many memorable movies,\" Wright wrote.\n\nHenry Winkler sent a message to Kiefer, writing, \"Stacey and I send you our deepest sympathies .. Your dad was indeed singular . {"uri": "8187558809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:43:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:43:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:42:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.thestandard.co.zw/life-amp-style/article/200028576/actor-donald-sutherland-dies-aged-88", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland dies aged 88", "body": "Actor Donald Sutherland, star of films including The Hunger Games and Don't Look Now, has died at 88 after a long illness.His son, the actor Kiefer Sutherland, announced his father's death in a statement.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" he said.\"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland starred in films including The Dirty Dozen, MASH and Klute.\n\nOne of the Canadian actor's breakout roles was as Hawkeye Pierce, a surgeon in the 1970 film version of MASH, a comedy about medics in the Korean War.\n\nBorn in New Brunswick, Canada, Sutherland started as a radio news reporter before leaving Canada to travel to London in 1957. There, he studied at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art.\n\nHe then took on small roles in British film and television.\n\nSutherland starred in The Dirty Dozen, a World War II action film that premiered in 1967.\n\nHis off-kilter presence saw him land another war film role as the appropriately named Sergeant Oddball, in Kelly's Heroes.\n\nYet he was on more restrained form in 1971's Klute, playing a detective whose hunt for a missing person is assisted by a high-priced call girl.\n\nJane Fonda was Sutherland's co-star in Alan J Pakula's film and won an Oscar for her role.\n\nHe dated Fonda for two years before the couple split.\n\nIn the 1973 thriller Don't Look Now, a sex scene of such frankness had viewers believe he and co-star Julie Christie had had sex for real - a rumour Sutherland later discounted.\n\nThe 1970s also saw him play an IRA member in The Eagle Has Landed, a pot-smoking college professor in National Lampoon's Animal House, and the lead in the 1978 remake of Invasion of the Body Snatchers.\n\nIn the 1980s, Sutherland played the father of a suicidal teenager in the Oscar-winning Ordinary People.\n\nHe turned to television in the 2000s, appearing in such series as Dirty Sexy Money and Commander-in-Chief.\n\nSutherland has four sons and one daughter.\n\nDespite his numerous roles, the Canadian actor was never nominated for an Oscar but did receive an honorary Academy Award in 2017.\n\nHis death comes months before his memoir, Made Up, But Still True, a book about his personal journey as an actor, was scheduled to be published.", {"uri": "2024-06-396263999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:06:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:06:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:05:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/donald-sutherland-dead-at-88-son-kiefer-calls-him-one-of-most-important-actors/a1981110995.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland dead at 88: Son Kiefer calls him one of most important actors", "body": "Kiefer Sutherland has called his father Donald Sutherland \"one of the most important actors in the history of film\" following the Canadian actor's death aged 88.\n\nThe star of Ordinary People, M*A*S*H, The Hunger Games film series and Six Degrees Of Separation died on Thursday in Miami, Florida, following a \"long illness\", his agent CAA said.\n\nIn a tribute, the 24 TV show star Kiefer wrote on Instagram: \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland won a Golden Globe for the TV movie Path To War for playing presidential adviser Clark Clifford and another gong along with an Emmy Award for the the mini-series Citizen X.\n\nIn 2017, he received an Academy Honorary Award for his acting but failed to get an Oscar nod during his lengthy career.\n\nSutherland's most recent roles included The Hunger Games film franchise as dictator president Coriolanus Snow, and as a judge in the 2023 TV show Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\n\nHe also had roles in thriller The Mechanic, Roman epic The Eagle, war film The Dirty Dozen, satire The Day Of The Locust, horror Invasion Of The Body Snatchers, period drama Pride & Prejudice and drama Space Cowboys.\n\nSutherland is perhaps best known as the womanising Captain Benjamin Franklin \"Hawkeye\" Pierce Jr in the 1970 film version of M*A*S*H, and would eventually becoming a leading campaigner against war.\n\nIn 2012, he became a Commander of the Arts in France and was praised by the French culture minister Frederic Mitterrand for his \"extraordinary\" career.\n\nA statement from CAA said: \"Acclaimed actor Donald Sutherland died today in Miami, Florida after a long illness. He was 88 years old.\"\n\nIt also said: \"Sutherland is survived by his wife Francine Racette, sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer, daughter Rachel, and four grandchildren.\n\n\"A private celebration
