{"uri": "8187616277", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:37:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:37:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:35:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/actor-donald-sutherland-dead-at-age-88/article_eb0d0f9d-8e05-5776-a457-b2d0c8d3bea2.html", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland dead at age 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the enigmatic actor whose lengthy career encompassed films including \"The Dirty Dozen\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died, his son said Thursday. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" actor Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nThe elder Sutherland had a distinctive look -- and piercing eyes -- that brought a depth and mystery to the huge range of roles he inhabited over more than half a century on the big screen.\n\nOne of Canada's most famous sons, he played dashing leading men as well as antiheroes and villains, most recently making a name among a new generation of fans as the evil President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" wrote Kiefer Sutherland.\n\nReaction to the Emmy and Golden Globe-winner's death was swift, with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau hailing his unique talents.\n\n\"I had the opportunity when I was much younger to meet Donald Sutherland, and even as a young man who hadn't had a full exposure to the depth of brilliance of Donald Sutherland, I was deeply, deeply star struck,\" he told a press conference.\n\n\"He was a man with a strong presence, a brilliance in his craft, and truly, truly, a great Canadian artist, and he will be deeply missed.\"\n\nAfter what he himself termed a \"meandering\" start to his acting career, Donald Sutherland came to prominence in Robert Aldrich's \"The Dirty Dozen,\" where 12 convicts are tasked with carrying out what appears to be a suicide mission in occupied France.\n\nMore from this section Diplomats say at least 550 pilgrims died during hajj, mostly Egyptians Rural county in northern Alberta opens nurse practitioner clinic Another Study Finds CRISPR Gene Therapy Fights Sickle Cell\n\nStarring alongside luminaries such as Charles Bronson, Lee Marvin and Telly Savalas, Sutherland's impish charms caught the attention of producers of \"M*A*S*H.\"\n\nThough set in the Korean War, the 1970 film was widely seen as a sophisticated satire on the Vietnam War.\n\nHis casting opposite Elliott Gould turned Sutherland into a household name in 1970s America, and opened the door to a durable career that would see him work with some of the biggest names in show business.\n\nThey included Jane Fonda, with whom he starred in 1971's \"Klute,\" in which he played a detective who falls for the call girl he is supposed to be protecting.\n\nFonda won an Oscar for her performance, which she credited to her intense feelings for Sutherland, with whom she was in a relationship at the time.\n\nTheir off-screen chemistry brought Sutherland into her pacifist orbit, and he became active in anti-Vietnam War circles.\n\nThe pair put together a travelling revue, which irked the US government and landed them both under FBI surveillance.\n\nhg/des", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8187493853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:51:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:51:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:49:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.etonline.com/donald-sutherland-mash-and-hunger-games-star-dead-at-88-227719", "title": "Donald Sutherland, 'M*A*S*H' and 'Hunger Games' Star, Dead at  88", "body": "According to multiple reports, Sutherland died Thursday in Miami following a long illness. The cause of death was not disclosed. Sutherland's death comes just months before his memoir, Made Up, But Still True, was set to be published.\n\nThe Lost Boys and 24 star Kiefer Sutherland, one of Sutherland's five children, shared the news on social media.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Kiefer tweeted. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nHe first made his mark in the 1967 World War II classic, The Dirty Dozen. That film would eventually help him land the role of Hawkeye Pierce in the 1970 war comedy, M*A*S*H. That same year, Sutherland appeared as the hippie tank commander \"Oddball\" in Kelly's Heroes and then starred opposite Gene Wilder in the comedy, Start the Revolution Without Me.\n\nAstonishingly, Sutherland was never nominated for an Academy Award, though he masterfully performed in films that would earn gold statuettes. In 1971, Sutherland starred opposite Jane Fonda in the Alan J. Pakula-directed psychological thriller Klute, which went on to be nominated for two Academy Awards -- Best Original Screenplay and Best Actress, which went to Fonda. Sutherland was honored with an Honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nSutherland earned a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or Movie in 1995's Citizen X. perfectly, and he soon landed a similar role in 1970's \"MASH.\" Back-to-back smash performances turned Sutherland into a bit of a leading man throughout the 1970s and '80s, when he starred in {"uri": "8187489502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:47:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:47:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.tvfanatic.com/2024/06/donald-sutherland-dies-beloved-actor-was-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland Dies; Beloved Actor Was 88", "body": "Sad news out of Hollywood today, as one of the industry's most beloved stars, Donald Sutherland, has passed away at the age of 88.\n\nSutherland accumulated more than 180 film and television credits in a career that spanned seven decades.\n\nHe is often cited as one of the best actors to have never won an Academy Award.\n\nAfter rising to fame in the late '60s and early '70s with memorable roles in films such as The Dirty Dozen (1967), M*A*S*H (1970), and Kelly's Heroes (1970), Sutherland branched out with a wide array of films that ran the gamut from high drama to slapstick comedy.\n\nWith Klute (1971), Don't Look Now (1973), The Day of the Locust (1975), Animal House (1978), Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1978), and Ordinary People (1980), Sutherland established himself as one of the most versatile stars in Hollywood.\n\nRelated: Will Movies and Shows of Today Be Classics Tomorrow?\n\nHis star continued to rise throughout the '80s and '90s and 2000s, with work in such hit films as Backdraft (1991), JFK (1991), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Without Limits (1998), The Italian Job (2003), and Pride & Prejudice (2005), and The Hunger Games (2012).\n\nA dedicated artist who stayed busy until the very end, Sutherland most recently appeared on the 2023 Paramount+ series Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\n\nEarly in his career, Sutherland developed a reputation as an actor's actor.\n\nHe was the sort of star who loved honing his craft and mentoring young stars on set.\n\nSutherland is survived by his five children, one of whom, Kiefer Sutherland, has also enjoyed remarkable success as an actor.\n\nIt was Kiefer who shared the news of his father's death earlier today.\n\nNo cause of death has been revealed, and details of Donald's final days are scarce at the moment.\n\nKiefer's daughter, Sarah Sutherland, has kept the family business alive with acclaimed work on the HBO series Veep and The Newsroom.\n\nRelated: 27 Saddest TV Deaths EVER\n\nDonald is also survived by Francine Racette, his wife of more than 50 years.\n\nWithin moments of Kiefer's announcement, Donald's name became a worldwide trending topic on X (formerly Twitter).\n\nTributes from friends, family, and a legion of adoring fans have been flooding in from all over the world.\n\nDonald Sutherland leaves behind such a vast and varied body of work that we're sure film buffs will enjoy debating and dissecting his finest roles for many years to come.\n\nOur thoughts go out to his family at this enormously difficult time.\n\nPlease hit the comments section below to share your favorite Donald Sutherland memories.\n\nTyler Johnson is an Associate Editor for TV Fanatic and the other Mediavine O&O sites. {"uri": "8187512235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:06:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:06:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:04:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.news18.com/movies/donald-sutherland-star-of-mash-and-the-hunger-games-dies-at-88-son-kiefer-pays-moving-tribute-8939247.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland, Star of 'MASH' and 'The Hunger Games', Dies at 88; Son Kiefer Pays Moving Tribute - News18", "body": "Kiefer Sutherland took to social media to remember his late father, the legendary actor Donald Sutherland, who died on June 20.\n\nDonald Sutherland, one of Canada's most versatile and gifted actors, who charmed and enthralled audiences in films such as \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Klute,\" \"Ordinary People\" and the \"Hunger Games\" films, has died at the age of 88.\n\nThe Canadian actor, whose lengthy career spanned from the 1960s into the 2020s, died on Thursday, his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, said on social media.\n\nThe tall actor with a deep voice, piercing blue eyes and mischievous smile managed to switch effortlessly from character roles to romantic leads, opposite the likes of Jane Fonda and Julie Christie. He also played his share of oddballs and villains during a career that began in the 1960s.\n\nOne of the biggest stars in Hollywood in the 1970s, he remained in demand for film and TV projects into his 80s. Known for his unconventional looks and his versatility as an actor, Sutherland played a wide range of memorable characters.\n\nThese included a rascally Army surgeon in \"M*A*S*H\" (1970), a quirky tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" (1970), a small-town detective in \"Klute\" (1971), a stoned and libidinous professor in \"Animal House\" (1978), a local official facing an alien presence in \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" (1978) and a despairing father in \"Ordinary People\" (1980). He won a new generation of fans with his glorious portrayal of a despotic president in \"The Hunger Games\" (2012) and its sequels.\n\n\"I wish I could say thank you to all of the characters that I've played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life,\" Sutherland said in his speech accepting an honorary Academy Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.\n\nSutherland was born on July 17, 1935, in Canada's New Brunswick province, and was raised in Nova Scotia. He performed in school productions in college, moved to Britain to hone his craft, then moved to the United States, where his first big break came as a member of a top-notch ensemble cast in the war film \"The Dirty Dozen\" (1967).\n\nHe rocketed to fame three years later playing nonconformist surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in director Robert Altman's Korean War satire \"M*A*S*H\" (1970). The film - later spun off into a TV series - depicted hijinks at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital, tapping into the anti-war sentiment among many Americans during the Vietnam War era.\n\nAlso in 1970, Sutherland starred alongside Telly Savalas and Clint Eastwood in \"Kelly's Heroes\" as Sergeant Oddball on a mission to steal gold from the Nazis.\n\nThe following year, he was paired with Fonda, one of Hollywood's luminaries, in \"Klute,\" and then in 1973 played a grieving father in \"Don't Look Now\" that included a sizzling sex scene with Christie. \"Klute\" sparked a romance with Fonda, with whom he was active in the anti-Vietnam War movement.\n\nHis 1978 films could not have been more different. In the uproarious comedy \"Animal House,\" Sutherland played a professor who sleeps with the girlfriend of a fraternity member. \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" was a successful sci-fi remake of a classic 1956 original, telling the story of alien pods that take over human beings.\n\nSutherland's performance in \"Ordinary People,\" Hollywood superstar Robert Redford's directorial debut, helped the 1980 film win four Academy Awards including best picture. Sutherland starred alongside Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton in this exploration of the splintering of a Midwestern family.\n\nIn the 1990s he appeared in films including \"JFK\" (1991), \"Backdraft\" (1991), \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer\" (1992), \"Outbreak\" (1995), \"A Time To Kill\" (1996) and \"Instinct\" (1999) and won an Emmy Award for his performance in the 1995 HBO TV movie \"Citizen X.\" In the 2000s, he appeared in the acclaimed \"Cold Mountain\" (2003) and \"Pride & Prejudice\" (2005).\n\nIn the \"Hunger Games\" films in the 2010s about a dystopian future in which teenagers are sent into a deadly competition as mass entertainment, he reveled in playing the villainous President Coriolanus Snow.\n\n\"The reality was he had a country to run. At least he was running it, which is more than you can say for some people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times in 2017.\n\n\"It was funny at the beginning with 'The Hunger Games' to walk through an airport and suddenly you feel this tug and you look down and it's some young person - always a girl, never a boy,\" Sutherland said. \"And her mother is standing there and they say, 'Could you take a photograph with my daughter?' And we'd be standing beside each other and I'd be looking at the camera and the girl would say, 'Could you look mean?'\"\n\nSutherland was considered among the best actors to never receive an Academy Award nomination for any of his roles. He was married three times and had five children, including Kiefer.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187512669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:06:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:06:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:05:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/06/20/1234123393/donald-sutherland-dead", "title": "Donald Sutherland, a subtle and sardonic star, has died at 88", "body": "Actor Donald Sutherland at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 2017.\n\nDonald Sutherland, who starred in more than 200 movies and TV shows, has died. He was 88.\n\n\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that,\" his son Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X. \"A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland's often cynical, subversive presence had been a mainstay in American cinema for seven decades. During his long career, which kicked off during the Vietnam War, he acted alongside dozens of Oscar winners. But Sutherland himself was never nominated for one, although the Academy presented him with an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\n\"I wish I could say thank you to all the characters I've played,\" Sutherland said during his acceptance speech. \"Thank them for using their lives to inform my lives.\"\n\nAt first, the Canadian actor spent a lot of time playing American soldiers. In his breakout role, in 1967's The Dirty Dozen, Sutherland played a convict turned soldier sent on a suicide mission ahead of Operation D-Day.\n\nImpressed by his performance, director Robert Aldrich cast Sutherland in the 1970 film M*A*S*H, where he played wisecracking combat surgeon Hawkeye. That same year, Sutherland played a rogue tank commander named Oddball in the movie Kelly's Heroes. All of these movies were released as the Vietnam War raged in the background.\n\nDespite playing so many soldiers, Sutherland was a vocal opponent of the Vietnam War. In 1971, He performed in a traveling roadshow opposite Jane Fonda in front of U.S. military soldiers. It was a leftist response to Bob Hope's pro-war USO tour.\n\nThe show consisted of skits, songs and interviews with soldiers. It was made into a documentary, F.T.A., in 1972.\n\nSutherland and Fonda, who were in the midst of an affair at the time, were put on National Security Agency watchlists for two years because of their anti-war activities.\n\nSutherland's political activities did not adversely affect his career. He ascended to leading roles, including as a sullen police officer in Klute, an aspiring artist in The Day of the Locust, and grieving fathers in Ordinary People and Don't Look Now.\n\nSutherland was probably most well known for his portrayal of off-kilter authority figures; over the years, he played doctors, sadistic prison wardens, and paranoid government figures, as in Oliver Stone's film JFK. A new generation of fans, including actress Jennifer Lawrence, embraced his bone-chilling portrayal of the tyrannical President Snow in The Hunger Games film franchise.\n\n\"Donald is the most committed, professional, kind person I have ever met,\" Lawrence said at the 2017 Governers Awards that gave Sutherland his honorary Oscar.\n\nSutherland's children followed in his footsteps, including his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland. The elusive Oscar aside, he won other awards, including Emmy and Golden Globe awards, but Donald Sutherland's subtle, dry performances went beyond easy approbation. They made audiences amused and uncomfortable, exactly as intended.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mansee_khurana@npr.org", "name": "Mansee {"uri": "2024-06-396262611", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:04:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:04:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:51:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240620-actor-donald-sutherland-dead-at-age-88-son", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland dead at age 88: son", "body": "Los Angeles (AFP) - Donald Sutherland, the enigmatic Canadian actor whose lengthy career encompassed films including \"The Dirty Dozen\" and \"The Hunger Games,\" has died, his son said Thursday. He was 88.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" actor Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nThe elder Sutherland had a distinctive look -- and piercing eyes -- that brought a depth and mystery to the huge range of roles he essayed over half a century on the big screen.\n\nHe played dashing leading men as well as antiheroes and villains, most recently making a name among a new generation of fans as the evil President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise.\n\n\"I personally think (he was) one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" wrote Kiefer Sutherland.\n\nAfter what he himself termed a \"meandering\" start to his acting career, Donald Sutherland came to prominence in Robert Aldrich's \"The Dirty Dozen,\" where 12 convicts are tasked with carrying out what appears to be a suicide mission in occupied France.\n\nStarring alongside luminaries such as Charles Bronson, Lee Marvin and Telly Savalas, Sutherland's impish charms caught the attention of producers of \"MASH.\"\n\nThe sophisticated satire on the Vietnam War, in which he was cast opposite Elliott Gould, turned Sutherland into a household name in 1970s America, and opened the door to a durable career that would see him work with some of the biggest names in show business.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8187603787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:24:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:24:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:23:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-21/donald-sutherland-dead-at-88/104005196", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the actor whose career spanned M.A.S.H. to Hunger Games, dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the Canadian actor whose wry, arresting screen presence spanned more than half a century from M.A.S.H. to The Hunger Games, has died. He was 88.\n\nSon Kiefer Sutherland confirmed the death on Thursday.\n\nNo details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X.\n\n\"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Sutherland, who flashed a grin that could be sweet or diabolical, was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's M.A.S.H. the hippie tank commander in Kelly's Heroes and the stoned professor in Animal House.\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomised the unpredictable, anti-establishment cinema of the 1970s.\n\nHe never stopped working, ultimately appearing in nearly 200 films and series.\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- roles in Robert Redford's Ordinary People and Oliver Stone's JFK.\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the Hunger Games films.\n\nA memoir, Made Up, But Still True, is due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998.\n\n\"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nThe actor enjoyed his breakthrough role in the 1970s, when he played a surgeon called 'Hawkeye' Pierce in the hit TV show 'M*A*S*H'.\n\nSutherland ultimately became one of the most sought-after leading men in the movie business, as he starred in the horror film 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' and in the National Lampoon comedy 'Animal House'.\n\nHe also appeared alongside Sir Sean Connery in the heist comedy film 'The First Great Train Robbery', which proved to be a critical and commercial success.\n\nIn the 90s, Sutherland played a snobbish art dealer in the comedy-drama 'Six Degrees of Separation', while he starred opposite Michael Douglas and Demi Moore in the thriller film 'Disclosure'.\n\nWhat's more, Sutherland played a central role in the Oliver Stone-directed thriller 'JFK', which examined the investigation into the assassination of John F Kennedy, the former US President.\n\nSutherland won numerous accolades during his career, including a Primetime Emmy Award and two Golden Globe Awards. However, he is widely regarded as one of the best actors never to have been nominated for an Oscar.\n\nSutherland is survived by his wife, Francine Racette, as well as his sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, {"uri": "8187511274", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:04:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:04:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:04:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/donald-sutherland-the-canadian-actor-whose-career-spanned-m-a-s-h-to-hunger-games-dies-at-88-post-5672317", "title": "Donald Sutherland, the Canadian Actor Whose Career Spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games,' Dies at 88", "body": "NEW YORK -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death on June 20. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Mr. Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Mr. Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Mr. Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187662642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:23:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:23:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:20:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/donald-sutherland-his-most-memorable-10-films-from-m-a-s-h-to-the-hunger/article_76a30ff0-2f34-11ef-9d0b-0b2365237493.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland: His most memorable 10 films, from \"M*A*S*H\" to \"The Hunger Games\"", "body": "Sutherland's career spanned decades and genres. He died Thursday at 88.\n\nDonald Sutherland has died.\n\nThe Canadian actor, born in Saint John, N.B., commanded the screen for six decades, starring in films from 1967's \"The Dirty Dozen\" to the Hunger Games series of the 2010s. He won a Golden Globe and Emmy, and despite never being nominated for an Oscar, he received an honorary award from the Academy in 2017.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nHere are some of Sutherland's most memorable films.\n\nThe Dirty Dozen (1967)\n\nAfter a handful of small roles in shows and TV movies, Sutherland played Vernon L. Pinkley, a convict-turned-soldier, in \"The Dirty Dozen.\" The World War II film was a box office hit.\n\nM*A*S*H (1970)\n\n\"M*A*S*H,\" a black comedy set during the Korean War, won the Oscar for best screenplay and became a starring turn for Sutherland, who played Hawkeye Pierce, despite a shoot he found difficult.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW Klute (1971)\n\nSutherland played titular character John Klute, a private detective who ends up in a relationship with Bree Daniels, played by Jane Fonda, who won an Oscar for the role. Fonda and Sutherland had an off-screen relationship, too.\n\nMovies Donald Sutherland, towering legend of cinema, dead at 88 Peter Howell Don't Look Now (1973)\n\nIn \"Don't Look Now,\" a supernatural horror film set in Venice, Sutherland portrayed John Baxter. He disregards two sisters who claim to have had visions of his dead daughter, but soon experiences psychic visions himself.\n\nInvasion of the Body Snatchers (1978)\n\nSutherland starred as Matthew Bennell, a public health inspector, in this remake of a 1956 horror film. His friend complains of her husband suddenly changing -- a concerning trend that starts to infiltrate San Francisco society.\n\nNational Lampoon's Animal House (1978)\n\nSutherland had only a cameo in this comedy as a professor who has an affair with a student. The film was wildly successful at the box office, grossing more than US$140 million on an estimated $3 million budget.\n\nOrdinary People (1980)\n\nIn the Robert Redford-directed \"Ordinary People,\" which won best picture at the Oscars, Sutherland starred as Calvin Jarrett, a father trying to hold a family together after the death of his son and fault lines that are pulling them apart.\n\nJFK (1991)\n\nSutherland played X, a mysterious, powerful figure in Washington, who helps unfold a conspiracy to kill John F. Kennedy. While controversial, the Oliver Stone-directed movie was nominated for eight Oscars, winning for best cinematography and best film editing.\n\nWithout Limits (1998)\n\nIn this biography of Steve Prefontaine, the legendary American long-distance runner who set records in every distance from 2,000 meters to 10K, Sutherland played his coach, Bill Bowerman. Sutherland was nominated for a Golden Globe, although he lost to Ed Harris, who won for \"The Truman Show.\"\n\nThe Hunger Games (2012)\n\nSutherland played oppressive leader President Snow in the Hunger Games series, beginning in 2012. {"uri": "8187550996", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:37:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:37:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:35:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.kgun9.com/obituaries/donald-sutherland-star-of-the-hunger-games-ordinary-people-dies-at-88", "title": "Donald Sutherland, star of 'The Hunger Games,' 'Ordinary People,' dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland -- the beloved actor who starred in films like \"MASH,\" \"The Dirty Dozen,\" \"The Hunger Games,\" and \"Ordinary People\" -- has died after battling a long illness.\n\nThe Canadian actor passed away in Miami after a battle with an illness. He was 88 years old.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" his son, Kiefer, said on X. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nThrough a career spanning over seven decades, Sutherland will be remembered as one of entertainment's most versatile and respected actors -- and one of the best to have never received an Academy Award.\n\nIn 2017, however, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awarded him an Honorary Oscar \"for a lifetime of indelible characters, rendered with unwavering truthfulness.\"\n\nHis other accolades include a Supporting Actor Emmy for HBO's \"Citizen X,\" a Golden Globe for the same role, a Best Supporting Actor Golden Globe for HBO's \"Path to War,\" seven other Golden Globe nominations and another Emmy nomination.\n\nLast year, Canada Post issued a stamp in Sutherland's honor. Other honors the legend racked up in his career included stars on the Canadian and Hollywood Walks of Fame and being made an Officer of the Order of Canada.\n\nBeyond the trophies though, Sutherland's work speaks for itself. He often appeared in multiple titles annually, playing everything from the villain President Snow in \"The Hunger Games\" franchise to a hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes,\" an ex-con hoping to be a demolition derby driver in \"Steelyard Blues\" to a caring father in a grieving family in \"Ordinary People,\" and an an anti-authoritarian Army medic in \"MASH\" -- a leading role that turned him into a major star in 1970.\n\nOther works on his impressive resume include \"National Lampoon's Animal House,\" \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers,\" \"JFK,\" \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer,\" \"The Day of the Locust,\" \"Pride and Prejudice,\" \"Human Trafficking,\" \"Space Cowboys,\" \"Man on the Train,\" \"Horrible Bosses,\" \"The Undoing,\" and most recently last year, \"Miranda's Victim\" and \"Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\"\n\nHe is survived by his wife since 1972 Francine Racette, his daughter, Hollywood production manager Rachel Sutherland, his four sons -- Emmy-winning \"Designated Survivor\" {"uri": "2024-06-396289513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:35:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:35:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.surreynowleader.com/entertainment/canadian-acting-icon-donald-sutherland-dead-at-88-7400783", "title": "Canadian acting icon Donald Sutherland dead at 88", "body": "Towering actor whose career spanned 'M.A.S.H.' to 'Hunger Games' won Oscar in 2017\n\nDonald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nHe received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nREAD ALSO: Film legend Donald Sutherland gets Canada Post stamp of approval", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-396295899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:42:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:42:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:35:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://ca.movies.yahoo.com/donald-sutherland-dead-88-son-180048010.html", "title": "Donald Sutherland dies as son Kiefer pays heartfelt tribute to Hunger Games star", "body": "Kiefer Sutherland has called his father Donald Sutherland \"one of the most important actors in the history of film\" following the Canadian actor's death aged 88.\n\nThe star of Ordinary People, M*A*S*H, The Hunger Games film series and Six Degrees Of Separation died on Thursday in Miami, Florida, following a \"long illness\", his agent CAA said.\n\nIn a tribute, the 24 TV show star Kiefer wrote on Instagram: \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland won a Golden Globe for the TV movie Path To War for playing presidential adviser Clark Clifford and another gong along with an Emmy Award for the the mini-series Citizen X.\n\nIn 2017, he received an Academy Honorary Award for his acting but failed to get an Oscar nod during his lengthy career.\n\nSutherland's most recent roles included The Hunger Games film franchise as dictator president Coriolanus Snow, and as a judge in the 2023 TV show Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\n\nHe also had roles in thriller The Mechanic, Roman epic The Eagle, war film The Dirty Dozen, satire The Day Of The Locust, horror Invasion Of The Body Snatchers, period drama Pride & Prejudice and drama Space Cowboys.\n\nSutherland is perhaps best known as the womanising Captain Benjamin Franklin \"Hawkeye\" Pierce Jr in the 1970 film version of M*A*S*H, and would eventually becoming a leading campaigner against war.\n\nIn 2012, he became a Commander of the Arts in France and was praised by the French culture minister Frederic Mitterrand for his \"extraordinary\" career.\n\nSutherland was about to publish his memoir Made Up, But Still True, later this year, which was set to explore \"an unfiltered account of his memories of his life\" from how life-changing a role M*A*S*H had been along with \"his far too many brushes with death\".\n\nThe actor had infantile paralysis and rheumatic fever before almost dying from spinal meningitis as a child, and later left Canada for the UK to study at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (Lamda).\n\nSutherland's early roles in the 1960s included European and UK productions such as Castle Of The Living Dead, which starred Christopher Lee, and Fanatic with Tallulah Bankhead, before he was cast in The Dirty Dozen as one of the American convicts sent on a secret mission as part of the D-Day landings in the Second World War.\n\nA statement from CAA said: \"Acclaimed actor Donald Sutherland died today in Miami, Florida after a long illness. He was 88 years old.\"\n\nIt also said: \"Sutherland is survived by his wife Francine Racette, sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer, daughter Rachel, and four grandchildren.\n\n\"A private celebration of life will be held by the family.\"\n\nSutherland's son Roeg is an executive at the talent agency CAA, and his sons Rossif and Angus have also worked as actors.", "source": {"uri": "ca.movies.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8187570677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:54:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:54:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:52:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "http://mynewsla.com/hollywood/2024/06/20/iconic-actor-donald-sutherland-dies-at-88-3/", "title": "Iconic Actor Donald Sutherland Dies at 88 - MyNewsLA.com", "body": "The entertainment world lost a giant Thursday with the death of legendary actor Donald Sutherland, who parlayed guest spots on television programs throughout the 1960s into appearances in iconic films including \"The Dirty Dozen,\" \"M*A*S*H,\" \"Kelly's Heroes\" and \"Animal House.\"\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" Sutherland's son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, wrote on social media Thursday morning. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland was 88. According to various reports, Sutherland died in Miami following a long illness.\n\nSutherland, who received an honorary Oscar in 2017, was known to younger moviegoers for his more recent work as President Snow in \"The Hunger Games.\" But his resume includes many of the most notable films Hollywood has produced, including \"Klute,\" \"Ordinary People,\" \"Pride & Prejudice,\" \"The Day of the Locust\" and \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers.\"\n\nHe won an Emmy Award in 1995 for his supporting work in HBO's \"Citizen X.\"\n\nBorn in Canada, Sutherland's big film break came when he was cast as a condemned Army prisoner in 1967's war classic \"The Dirty Dozen,\" joining a star-studded cast that included Lee Marvin, Telly Savalas and Charles Bronson, among others.\n\nThe success of that film helped him land top billing in another Army film, playing the original Hawkeye Pierce in the big-screen version of \"M*A*S*H.\" Yet another war epic followed with his appearance as the appropriately named Sgt. Oddball, a flighty tank squadron commander in \"Kelly's Heroes.\" The behind-the-lines quest for wartime gold also had an all-star cast, led by Clint Eastwood and including Savalas and Don Rickles.\n\nThe following year he appeared opposite Jane Fonda in \"Klute.\"\n\nSutherland was a nine-time Golden Globe Award nominee, winning in 2003 for his supporting role in \"Path to War,\" chronicling the events leading to U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War.\n\nHis other film roles included \"Space Cowboys\" -- re-teaming with Eastwood, \"The Italian Job,\" \"Cold Mountain,\" \"Buffy the Vampire Slayer,\" \"Disclosure\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nHe most recently portrayed a judge on the series \"Lawman: Bass Reeves.\"\n\nSutherland is survived by his wife Francine Racette; {"uri": "8187568565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:51:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:51:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:50:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://in-cyprus.philenews.com/international/canadian-actor-donald-sutherland-dies-at-88/", "title": "Canadian actor Donald Sutherland dies at 88", "body": "The tall, lanky, Canadian actor Donald Sutherland, known for his diverse roles in films like \"MASH\", \"Klute\", and \"The Hunger Games\", died on Thursday at the age of 88 after a long illness, his agent confirmed.\n\nSutherland's career spanned seven decades. He was a prolific actor, appearing in over 190 films and television shows. He was known for his ability to portray a wide range of characters, from memorable villains and antiheroes to romantic leads and wise figures.\n\nHis stature grew in recent years with his supporting role as the villainous President Snow in the popular \"The Hunger Games\" franchise (2012-2015). Other notable films include \"MASH\" (1970), \"Klute\" (1971), \"Don't Look Now\" (1973), \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers\" (1978), and \"Ordinary People\" (1980).\n\nSutherland was also an anti-war activist. He was married to French actress Francine Racette since 1972. His son, Kiefer Sutherland, a renowned actor himself, announced his father's passing on Twitter.\n\n\"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away. I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nSutherland received numerous awards throughout his career, including an Honorary Academy Award in 2017 for his overall contribution to cinema. {"uri": "8187596354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:17:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:17:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:16:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.pehalnews.in/entertainment/thespian-donald-sutherland-passes-at-88/2863/", "title": "Thespian Donald Sutherland Passes at 88 - Pehal News", "body": "The luminary of cinematic masterpieces such as \"The Hunger Games\" and \"Animal House\" has succumbed to a protracted ailment.\n\nActor Donald Sutherland, illustrious for his roles in \"The Hunger Games\" and \"Don't Look Now,\" has departed this world at the age of 88 following an extended illness.\n\nHis progeny, fellow actor Kiefer Sutherland, conveyed the somber news in an official communiqu\u00e9.\n\n\"With profound sorrow, I must inform you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has departed. In my estimation, he stands among the paramount actors in the annals of cinema,\" he expressed.\n\n\"Unafraid of any role, whether virtuous, villainous, or ambiguous, he embraced his craft with fervor. A life well-lived, indeed.\"\n\nThe announcement prompted a deluge of condolences and tributes in honor of Donald Sutherland.\n\nActor Cary Elwes expressed his sorrow on Instagram.\n\n\"Our hearts are heavy for you,\" he penned in a comment to Kiefer. \"Immensely grateful for the privilege of knowing and collaborating with him. Sending our love.\"\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau acknowledged Sutherland's passing during a press conference in Westville, N.S., reminiscing about feeling \"profoundly, profoundly starstruck\" upon their first meeting.\n\n\"My thoughts are with Kiefer and the entire Sutherland family, as well as with all Canadians who, like myself, are deeply saddened by this news,\" he stated.\n\n\"He possessed a formidable presence, a brilliance in his craft, and was truly an extraordinary Canadian artist,\" he added.\n\nRon Howard, who directed Sutherland in the 1991 action film \"Backdraft,\" paid homage to Sutherland on X, formerly known as Twitter.\n\n\"One of the most intelligent, intriguing, and captivating film actors of all time,\" he wrote. \"Incredible range, creative bravery, and unwavering dedication to the narrative and the audience.\"\n\nSutherland's oeuvre encompassed nearly 200 credits, including iconic films like \"The Dirty Dozen,\" \"MAS*H,\" and \"Klute.\"\n\nHailing from New Brunswick, Canada, Sutherland began his career as a radio news reporter before venturing to London in 1957 to study at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art.\n\nHe subsequently secured minor roles in British film and television.\n\nHis initial cinematic forays often revolved around military themes. He featured in \"The Dirty Dozen,\" a 1967 World War II action film, and in the 1970 film \"MAS*H,\" depicting medics during the Korean War.\n\nJane Fonda co-starred with Sutherland in Alan J. Pakula's 1971 thriller \"Klute,\" where he portrayed a detective aided by a high-priced call girl in his search for a missing person.\n\nSutherland and Fonda were romantically involved for two years before parting ways.\n\nThe 1970s also saw him embodying an IRA operative in \"The Eagle Has Landed,\" a cannabis-enthusiast professor in \"National Lampoon's Animal House,\" and the protagonist in the 1978 remake of \"Invasion of the Body Snatchers.\"\n\nIn the 1980s, Sutherland depicted the father of a suicidal adolescent in the Academy Award-winning \"Ordinary People.\"\n\nHis career transitioned to television in the 2000s, with appearances in series such as \"Dirty Sexy Money\" and \"Commander-in-Chief.\"\n\nDespite his prolific career, the Canadian actor never received an Oscar nomination, though he was honored with an honorary Academy Award in 2017.\n\nSutherland was renowned for his political activism, notably protesting the US war in Vietnam alongside Fonda. Their efforts were documented in the 1972 film \"F.T.A.\"\n\nSutherland infused his roles with his convictions, including his portrayal of the despotic President Snow in \"The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2,\" released in 2015. In this film, Sutherland's character becomes the target of heroine Katniss Everdeen, played by Jennifer Lawrence, who aims to overthrow the oppressive regime.\n\nIn a 2015 interview with BBC News, Sutherland expressed his hope that the film's socio-political message would awaken young viewers to global realities. In the narrative, Panem is depicted as a society where an elite minority subjugates the impoverished majority.\n\n\"I have believed for the past 30 years that the younger generation lacked political awareness,\" Sutherland remarked. \"Our collective aim was to engage them. As Bruce Springsteen said, 'Blind faith in your leaders... will get you killed.'\"\n\nSutherland's demise precedes the upcoming November release of his memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" chronicling his personal journey as an actor.\n\nIn his 2015 BBC News interview, Sutherland noted a significant shift in the industry, observing that contemporary actors are amassing substantial wealth.\n\n\"I don't think any of my contemporaries became actors for financial gain. It never crossed my mind. I earned \u00a38 a week on stage in London. When I headlined a play at the Royal Court, I made \u00a317 a week, that was in 1964,\" he recounted.\n\nAt that time, he had no intentions of retiring from acting.\n\n\"It's a passionate pursuit. For actors, retirement is tantamount to 'DEATH',\" he declared.", "source": {"uri": "pehalnews.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pehal News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": A life well lived,\" he said.\n\nThe Canadian-born actor earned around 200 film and TV credits over more than 60 years in the industry.\n\nHis big break came in 1967, when he secured a role in Robert Aldrich's star-packed 1967 World War II drama The Dirty Dozen, playing Vernon Pinkley opposite Lee Marvin, Ernest Borgnine, Charles Bronson, George Kennedy, Telly Savalas and others.\n\nThis is a breaking story. {"uri": "8187483352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:42:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:42:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:41:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://mix108.com/ixp/442/p/donald-sutherland-dies/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, Star of 'MASH' and 'Hunger Games,' Dies at 88", "body": "One of the most prolific actors of the last half century has died. Generations of movie and TV fans have known Donald Sutherland from an eclectic mix of films and television series, playing roles ranging from tortured leading men to sardonic pot smokers. Sadly, Sutherland died on Thursday at the age of 88. His passing was confirmed by Deadline; no cause of death was given.\n\nThe Canadian-born Sutherland studied drama in England, and made his earliest screen appearances in BBC and Hammer productions. His Hollywood breakthrough was his role in The Dirty Dozen, the Lee Marvin-led war film about a group of convicts recruited for a suicide mission during World War II.\n\nA few years after The Dirty Dozen, Sutherland starred in Robert Altman's MASH, one of the defining films of the early 1970s. This war film was a satire; set during the Korean War, it was intended as a spoof of the Vietnam War and military policy of the time, with Sutherland starring as Hawkeye Pierce, the latest addition to the team of doctors in an overworked and very rowdy MASH unit. The film was a massive hit, and spawned an even more popular TV series (although there Hawkeye was played by Alan Alda).\n\nMASH made Sutherland an instant star, and he continued to make big movies all through the 1970s, including the hit thriller Klute, the cult classic horror film Don't Look Now, and the superb remake of Invasion of the Body Snatchers.\n\nThat same year, Sutherland had a small but very memorable role in another era-defining hit: 1978's National Lampoon's Animal House. There Sutherland played a hippie college professor who introduced some of his students to drugs.\n\nREAD MORE: 10 '70s Classics That Could Never Get Made Today\n\nYounger movie fans probably know Sutherland best as the evil President Snow from The Hunger Games franchise.\n\nIf we attempted to list all of Sutherland's memorable performances, we would be here forever. A few of the other highlights include Kelly's Heroes, The Day of the Locust, Ordinary People, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, JFK, Outbreak, A Time to Kill, The Italian Job.\n\nOn television he starred on countless TV movies, and was a member of the casts of shows like Dirty Sexy Money, Commander in Chief, and Crossing Lines. And, of course, Sutherland is also well-known as the father of fellow actor Kiefer Sutherland as well.\n\nSutherland's body of work is enormous; it's hard to imagine that anyone reading this doesn't know him from sight or by from the sound of his smooth voice, which he used to such great effect in films like The Hunger Games franchise. Remarkably, Sutherland never received an Oscar nomination in his entire career, despite all those acclaimed (and often award-winning) movies he starred in. He did receive an honorary award from the Academy in 2017.\n\nThat feels like an impossible oversight; he surely is one of the best actors in history never to even be nominated for an Oscar. But proper Academy Award recognition or not, the work he did will surely endure for years to come.", "source": {"uri": "mix108.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MIX 108"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-396327411", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:25:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:25:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:24:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.chesterstandard.co.uk/news/national/24401637.donald-sutherland-dies-88-one-important-actors-son-kiefer-says/", "title": "Donald Sutherland dies at 88: 'One of the most important actors' son Kiefer says", "body": "Kiefer Sutherland has called his father Donald Sutherland \"one of the most important actors in the history of film\" following the Canadian actor's death aged 88.\n\nThe star of Ordinary People, M*A*S*H, The Hunger Games film series and Six Degrees Of Separation died on Thursday in Miami, Florida, following a \"long illness\", his agent CAA said.\n\nIn a tribute, the 24 TV show star Kiefer wrote on Instagram: \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nDuring his esteemed career, Sutherland won a Golden Globe for the TV movie Path To War for playing presidential adviser Clark Clifford and another gong along with an Emmy Award for the the mini-series Citizen X.\n\nIn 2017, he received an Academy Honorary Award for his acting but failed to get an Oscar nod during his lengthy career.\n\nSutherland's most recent roles included The Hunger Games film franchise, playing dictator president Coriolanus Snow, and as a judge in the 2023 TV show Lawmen: Bass Reeves.\n\nHe also had roles in thriller The Mechanic, Roman epic The Eagle, war film The Dirty Dozen, satire The Day Of The Locust, horror Invasion Of The Body Snatchers, period drama Pride & Prejudice and drama Space Cowboys.\n\nSutherland is perhaps best known as the womanising Captain Benjamin Franklin \"Hawkeye\" Pierce Jr in the 1970 film version of M*A*S*H, and would eventually become a leading campaigner against war.\n\nIn 2012, he became a Commander of the Arts in France and was praised by the French culture minister Frederic Mitterrand for his \"extraordinary\" career.\n\nSutherland was about to publish his memoir Made Up, But Still True, later this year, which was set to explore \"an unfiltered account of his memories of his life\" from how life-changing a role M*A*S*H had been along with \"his far too many brushes with death\".\n\nThe actor had infantile paralysis and rheumatic fever before almost dying from spinal meningitis as a child, and later left Canada for the UK to study at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (Lamda).\n\nSutherland's early roles in the 1960s included European and UK productions such as Castle Of The Living Dead, which starred Christopher Lee, and Fanatic with Tallulah Bankhead, before he was cast in The Dirty Dozen as one of the American convicts sent on a secret mission as part of the D-Day landings in the Second World War.\n\nA statement from CAA said: \"Acclaimed actor Donald Sutherland died today in Miami, Florida after a long illness. He was 88 years old.\"\n\nIt also said: \"Sutherland is survived by his wife Francine Racette, sons Roeg, Rossif, Angus, and Kiefer, daughter Rachel, and four grandchildren.\n\n\"A private celebration {"uri": "8187449860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:15:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:15:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:15:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.slashfilm.com/1606775/donald-sutherland-actor-dead-at-88/", "title": "Donald Sutherland, Legendary Actor Of Incredible Range, Has Died At 88 - SlashFilm", "body": "Not even legends live forever. Donald Sutherland, the acclaimed Canadian actor with decades worth of roles and awards to his name, has died at age 88, Deadline reports. He is survived by his wife Francine Racette, who he'd been with since 1972. Sutherland had been married twice before meeting Racette, first to Lois Hardwick from 1959 to 1966 and then to the late Shirley Douglas from 1966 to 1970.\n\nSutherland also leaves behind five children: Kiefer (\"24\"), Rachel, Rossif (\"Three Pines\"), Angus (\"1917\"), and Roeg. All of Sutherland's children followed him into the entertainment business: Kiefer, Rossif, and Angus are actors (as is Kiefer's own daughter, Sarah), Rachel is a production manager, and Roeg is a talent agent.\n\nBorn in Saint John, New Brunswick on July 17, 1935, Sutherland had a middle-class upbringing -- his father Frederick was a salesman and his mother Dorothy was a teacher. However, he was also a sickly child, suffering at different points from polio, rheumatic fever, hepatitis, pneumonia, and scarlet fever. None were able to keep him down, though. He went on to study Engineering and Drama at Victoria University in Toronto, graduating in 1956. Choosing his passion over a steady career choice, he continued to study acting at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art.\n\nAfter a string of small-time work during the 1960s, Sutherland broke out after appearing in 1967's \"The Dirty Dozen\" and his career never looked back. Honors to his name include stars on both Hollywood's and Canada's Walk(s) of Fame, two Golden Globes (one in 1995 for \"Citizen X,\" the other in 2002 for \"Path to War\"), an Emmy (also for \"Citizen X\"), and an Academy Honorary Award in 2017, \"for a lifetime of indelible characters, rendered with unwavering truthfulness.\"", "source": {"uri": "slashfilm.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8187532303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:20:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5032730", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland Dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday, The Associated Press reported.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Pierce in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\" More, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films. He never retired, working regularly up until his death. A memoir, \"Made Up, But Still True,\" was due out in November.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"\n\nSutherland career as a leading man peaked in the 1970s, when he starred in films by the era's top directors -- even if they didn't always do their best work with him. Sutherland, who frequently said he considered himself at the service of a director's vision, worked with Federico Fellini (1976's \"Fellini's Casanova\"), Bernardo Bertolucci (1976's \"1900\"), Claude Chabrol (1978's \"Blood Relatives\") and John Schlesinger (1975's \"The Day of the Locust\").\n\nOne of his finest performances came as a detective in Alan Pakula's \"Klute\" (1971). It was during filming on \"Klute\" that he met Fonda, with whom he had a three-year-long relationship that began at the end of his second marriage to actor Shirley Douglas. Having been married in 1966, he and Douglas divorced in 1971.\n\nSutherland had twins with Douglas in 1966: Rachel and Kiefer, who was named after Warren Kiefer, the writer of Sutherland's first film, \"Castle of the Living Dead.\"\n\nIn 1974, the actor began living with actress Francine Racette, with whom he remained ever after. They had three children: Roeg, born in 1974 and named after the director Nicolas Roeg (\"Don't Look Now\"); Rossif, born in 1978 and named after the director Frederick Rossif; and Angus Redford, born in 1979 and named after Robert Redford.\n\nIt was Redford who, to the surprise of some, cast Sutherland as the father in his directorial debut, 1980's \"Ordinary People.\" Redford's drama about a handsome suburban family destroyed by tragedy won four Oscars, including best picture.\n\nSutherland was overlooked by the academy throughout most of his career. He was never nominated but was presented with an honorary Oscar in 2017. He did, though, win an Emmy in 1995 for the TV film \"Citizen X\" and was nominated for seven Golden Globes (including for his performances in \"M.A.S.H.\" and \"Ordinary People\"), winning two -- again for \"Citizen X\" and for the 2003 TV film \"Path to War.\"\n\n\"Ordinary People\" also presaged a shift in Sutherland's career toward more mature and sometimes less offbeat characters.\n\nHis New York stage debut in 1981, though, went terribly. He played Humbert Humbert in Edward Albee's adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's \"Lolita,\" and the reviews were merciless; it closed after a dozen performances.\n\nA down period in the '80s followed, thanks to failures like the 1981 satire \"Gas\" and the 1984 comedy \"Crackers.\"\n\nBut Sutherland continued to work steadily. He had a brief but memorable role in Oliver Stone's \"JFK\" (1991). He again played a patriarch for Redford in his 1993 movie \"Six Degrees of Separation.\" He played track coach Bill Bowerman in 1998's \"Without Limits.\"\n\nIn the last decade, Sutherland increasingly worked in television, most memorably in HBO's \"Path to War,\" in which he played President Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford.", "source": {"uri": "english.aawsat.com", {"uri": "2024-06-396251618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:51:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:51:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:40:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://nationwideradiojm.com/hunger-games-star-donald-sutherland-dies-at-88/", "title": "Hunger Games Star Donald Sutherland Dies at 88", "body": "Donald Sutherland, whose acting career spanned six decades and included starring in such highly acclaimed films as Don't Look Now, M*A*S*H and The Hunger Games, has died aged 88.\n\nHe died in Miami after a long illness, confirmed by his representatives.\n\nHis son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, also shared the news on X. \"With a heavy heart, I tell you that my father, Donald Sutherland, has passed away,\" he wrote. \"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived.\"\n\nA prolific actor who appeared in more than 190 films and TV shows, Sutherland embodied an off-kilter appeal that served him brilliantly in a series of classic 1970s movies, which gradually evolved into a veteran gravitas in the latter stages of his career. He did not win a major award for any of his film roles (and was never nominated for a conventional Oscar), but did win two Golden Globes for best supporting actor for the TV movies Citizen X (in 1996) and Path to War (in 2003). Sutherland received an honorary Oscar in 2017.\n\nBorn in Canada in 1935, Sutherland studied engineering and drama at the University of Toronto, and opted to move to London in 1957 to join an acting class at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (Lamda). After a series of small roles on British TV shows including Man of the World, The Saint and The Avengers, and films such as the Hammer horror film Fanatic and the Amicus anthology Dr Terror's House of Horrors, Sutherland was cast in the action film The Dirty Dozen, as one of a group of prisoners trained up for a dangerous mission during the second world war.\n\nIn 2012 his role as the villainous President Snow in The Hunger Games introduced him to a new generation of filmgoers. He also starred in Stephen King horror Mr Harrigan's Phone and disaster thriller Moonfall in 2022. Most recently, he had a recurring role in TV series Lawmen: Bass Reeves with David Oyelowo.\n\nSutherland was married three times, to Lois Hardwick between 1959 and 1966, Shirley Douglas (1966-1970) and Francine Racette, whom he married in 1972.", "source": {"uri": "nationwideradiojm.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Nationwide 90FM"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-396241833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:40:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:40:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:34:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/news/nation-world/donald-sutherland-dead-hunger-games-mash-actor/507-b35ab281-c6d9-4b63-b362-59e12182141e", "title": "Actor Donald Sutherland has died at age 88, family says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Donald Sutherland, the prolific film and television actor whose long career stretched from \"M.A.S.H.\" to \"The Hunger Games,\" has died. He was 88.\n\nKiefer Sutherland, the actor's son, confirmed his father's death Thursday. No further details were immediately available.\n\n\"I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film,\" Kiefer Sutherland said on X. \"Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that.\"\n\nThe tall and gaunt Canadian actor with a grin that could be sweet or diabolical was known for offbeat characters like Hawkeye Piece in Robert Altman's \"M.A.S.H.,\" the hippie tank commander in \"Kelly's Heroes\" and the stoned professor in \"Animal House.\"\n\nBefore transitioning into a long career as a respected character actor, Sutherland epitomized the unpredictable, antiestablishment cinema of the 1970s .\n\nOver the decades, Sutherland showed his range in more buttoned-down -- but still eccentric -- parts in Robert Redford's \"Ordinary People\" and Oliver Stone's \"JFK.\"\n\nMore, recently, he starred in the \"Hunger Games\" films and the HBO limited series \"The Undoing.\" He never retired and worked regularly up until his death.\n\n\"I love to work. I passionately love to work,\" Sutherland told Charlie Rose in 1998. \"I love to feel my hand fit into the glove of some other character. I feel a huge freedom -- time stops for me. I'm not as crazy as I used to be, but I'm still a little crazy.\"", "source": {"uri": "fox61.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "fox61.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@fox61.com", "name": Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. {"uri": "8187670706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:30:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:30:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:28:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.deccanherald.com/world/donald-sutherland-star-of-mash-and-the-hunger-games-dead-at-88-3074934", "title": "Donald Sutherland, star of 'M*A*S*H' and 'The Hunger Games', dead at 88", "body": "\"He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" Kiefer Sutherland wrote on X.\n\nDonald Sutherland was born on July 17, 1935, in Canada's New Brunswick province, and was raised in Nova Scotia. He performed in school productions in college, moved to Britain to hone his craft, then moved to the United States, where his first big break came as a member of a top-notch ensemble cast in the war film The Dirty Dozen (1967).\n\nHe rocketed to fame three years later playing nonconformist surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in director Robert Altman's Korean War satire M*A*S*H (1970). The film - later spun off into a TV series - depicted hijinks at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital, tapping into the anti-war sentiment among many Americans during the Vietnam War era.\n\nAlso in 1970, Sutherland starred alongside Telly Savalas and Clint Eastwood in Kelly's Heroes as Sergeant Oddball on a mission to steal gold from the Nazis.\n\nThe following year, he was paired with Fonda, one of Hollywood's luminaries, in Klute, and then in 1973 played a grieving father in Don't Look Now that included a sizzling sex scene with Christie. Klute sparked a romance with Fonda, with whom he was active in the anti-Vietnam War movement.\n\nHis 1978 films could not have been more different. In the uproarious comedy Animal House, Sutherland played a professor who sleeps with the girlfriend of a fraternity member. Invasion of the Body Snatchers was a successful sci-fi remake of a classic 1956 original, telling the story of alien pods that take over human beings.\n\nSutherland's performance in Ordinary People, Hollywood superstar Robert Redford's directorial debut, helped the 1980 film win four Academy Awards, including best picture. Sutherland starred alongside Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton in this exploration of the splintering of a Midwestern family.\n\nIn the 1990s he appeared in films including JFK (1991), Backdraft (1991), Buffy the Vampire Slayer (1992), Outbreak (1995), A Time To Kill (1996) and Instinct (1999) and won an Emmy Award for his performance in the 1995 HBO TV movie Citizen X. In the 2000s, he appeared in the acclaimed Cold Mountain (2003) and Pride & Prejudice (2005).\n\nIn the Hunger Games films in the 2010s about a dystopian future in which teenagers are sent into a deadly competition as mass entertainment, he reveled in playing the villainous President Coriolanus Snow.\n\n\"The reality was he had a country to run. At least he was running it, which is more than you can say for some people,\" Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times in 2017.\n\n\"It was funny at the beginning with The Hunger Games to walk through an airport and suddenly you feel this tug and you look down and it's some young person - always a girl, never a boy,\" Sutherland said. \"And her mother is standing there and they say, 'Could you take a photograph with my daughter?' And we'd be standing beside each other and I'd be looking at the camera and the girl would say, 'Could you look mean?'\"\n\nTributes to Sutherland came in across Hollywood and Canada on Thursday.\n\nRon Howard, who directed Sutherland in \"Backdraft,\" called him \"one of the most intelligent, interesting and engrossing film actors of all time.\"\n\nSutherland had \"incredible range, creative courage & dedication to serving the story & the audience with supreme excellence,\" Howard wrote on X.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, speaking to reporters in Nova Scotia, said Sutherland \"was a man with a strong presence, a brilliance in his craft and truly, truly a great Canadian artist.\"\n\nSutherland was considered among the best actors to never receive an Academy Award nomination for any of his roles. He was married three times and had five children, including Kiefer.", "source": {"uri": "deccanherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deccan Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@deccanherald.com", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutherland", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sutherland"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Sutherland"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klute", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Klute"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "M*A*S*H (TV series)"}}, {"uri": 3, "label": {"eng": "Telly Savalas"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_cast", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ensemble cast"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_film", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "War film"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-war_movement", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": I personally think one of the most important actors in the history of film. Never daunted by a role, good, bad or ugly. He loved what he did and did what he loved, and one can never ask for more than that. A life well lived,\" he wrote on X (formerly Twitter)\n\nHe reportedly turned down the offer to play the father of his son's character, Jack Bauer, in the TV series 24.\n\nSutherland is survived by {"uri": "8187530176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:19:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:19:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:18:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3267429/donald-sutherland-star-mash-hunger-games-and-ordinary-people-dead-88", "title": "Donald Sutherland, star of M*A*S*H and The Hunger Games, dead at 88", "body": "The Canadian actor, who played an army surgeon in 1970 Korean-war satire M*A*S*H, died on Thursday said his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland\n\nDonald Sutherland, one of Canada\u2019s most versatile and gifted actors, who charmed and enthralled audiences in films such as M*A*S*H, Klute, Ordinary People and The Hunger Games films, has died at the age of 88.\n\nThe Canadian actor, whose lengthy career spanned from the 1960s into the 2020s, died on Thursday, his son, actor Kiefer Sutherland, said on social media.\n\nThe tall actor with a deep voice, piercing blue eyes and mischievous smile managed to switch effortlessly from character roles to romantic leads, opposite the likes of Jane Fonda and Julie Christie. He also played his share of oddballs and villains during a career that began in the 1960s.\n\nOne of the biggest stars in Hollywood in the 1970s, he remained in demand for film and television projects into his 80s. Known for his unconventional looks and his versatility as an actor, Sutherland played a wide range of memorable characters.\n\nThese included a rascally army surgeon in M*A*S*H (1970), a quirky tank commander in Kelly\u2019s Heroes (1970), a small-town detective in Klute (1971), a libidinous professor in Animal House (1978), a local official facing an alien presence in Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1978) and a despairing father in Ordinary People (1980). He won a new generation of fans with his glorious portrayal of a despotic president in The Hunger Games (2012) and its sequels.\n\n\u201cI wish I could say thank you to all of the characters that I\u2019ve played, thank them for using their lives to inform my life,\u201d Sutherland said in his speech accepting an honorary Academy Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.\n\nSutherland was born on July 17, 1935, in Canada\u2019s New Brunswick province, and was raised in Nova Scotia. He performed in school productions in college, moved to Britain to hone his craft, then moved to the United States, where his first big break came as a member of a top-notch ensemble cast in the war film The Dirty Dozen (1967).\n\nHe rocketed to fame three years later playing nonconformist surgeon Hawkeye Pierce in director Robert Altman\u2019s Korean war satire M*A*S*H (1970), set during the 1950s. The film \u2013 later spun off into a television series \u2013 depicted high jinks at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital, tapping into the anti-war sentiment among many Americans at that time during the Vietnam war era.\n\nAlso in 1970, Sutherland starred alongside Telly Savalas and Clint Eastwood in Kelly\u2019s Heroes as Sergeant Oddball on a mission to steal gold from the Nazis.\n\nThe following year, he was paired with Fonda, one of Hollywood\u2019s luminaries, in Klute, and then in 1973 played a grieving father in Don\u2019t Look Now that included a sizzling sex scene with Christie. Klute sparked a romance with Fonda, with whom he was active in the anti-Vietnam war movement.\n\nHis 1978 films could not have been more different. In the uproarious comedy Animal House, Sutherland played a professor who sleeps with the girlfriend of a fraternity member. Invasion of the Body Snatchers was a successful sci-fi remake of a classic 1956 original, telling the story of alien pods that take over human beings.\n\nSutherland\u2019s performance in Ordinary People, Hollywood superstar Robert Redford\u2019s directorial debut, helped the 1980 film win four Academy Awards including best picture. Sutherland starred alongside Mary Tyler Moore and Timothy Hutton in this exploration of the splintering of a Midwestern family.\n\nIn the 1990s he appeared in films including JFK (1991), Backdraft (1991), Buffy the Vampire Slayer (1992), Outbreak (1995), A Time To Kill (1996) and Instinct (1999) and won an Emmy Award for his performance in the 1995 HBO television film Citizen X. In the 2000s, Sutherland appeared in the acclaimed Cold Mountain (2003) and Pride & Prejudice (2005).\n\nIn the Hunger Games films in the 2010s about a dystopian future in which teenagers are sent into a deadly competition as mass entertainment, he revelled in playing the villainous President Coriolanus Snow.\n\n\u201cThe reality was he had a country to run. At least he was running it, which is more than you can say for some people,\u201d Sutherland told the Los Angeles Times newspaper in 2017.\n\n\u201cIt was funny at the beginning with The Hunger Games to walk through an airport and suddenly you feel this tug and you look down and it\u2019s some young person \u2013 always a girl, never a boy,\u201d Sutherland said. \u201cAnd her mother is standing there and they say: \u2018Could you take a photograph with my daughter?\u2019 And we\u2019d be standing beside each other and I\u2019d be looking at the camera and the girl would say: \u2018Could you look mean?\u2019\u201d\n\nSutherland was considered among the best actors to never receive an Academy Award nomination for any of his roles. He was married three times and had five children, including Kiefer.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
